<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
2 + 3 \times 4 - 1
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 23 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Does not need brackets</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+5 x-6}{x-3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+3x-4}{x-4} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that when you cancel identical terms from the numerator and denominator, they just disappear</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+5 x+6}{x+3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the \( 5 \) plants with these heights:
\( 24 \mathrm{~cm}, 17 \mathrm{~cm}, 42 \mathrm{~cm}, 26 \mathrm{~cm}, 13 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Tom says if all the plants were cut in half, the range would change.
Katie says if all the plants grew by \( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range would change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Emily are discussing the \( 5 \) trees with these heights:
\( 15 \mathrm{~m}, 20 \mathrm{~m}, 25 \mathrm{~m}, 10 \mathrm{~m}, 30 \mathrm{~m} \)
Sam says if all the trees were cut in half, the range wouldn't change.
Emily says if all the trees grew by \( 5 \mathrm{~m} \) each, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Sam and Emily</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Sarah and Mark are discussing the \( 5 \) trees with these heights:
\( 35 \mathrm{~cm}, 22 \mathrm{~cm}, 50 \mathrm{~cm}, 30 \mathrm{~cm}, 18 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Sarah says if all the trees were cut in half, the range wouldn't change.
Mark says if all the trees grew by \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range would change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Mark is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you add the same value to all numbers in the dataset the range will change</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Recall and use the intersecting diagonals properties of a rectangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
The angles highlighted on this rectangle with different length sides can never be... ![A rectangle with the diagonals drawn in. The angle on the right hand side at the centre is highlighted in red and the angle at the bottom at the centre is highlighted in yellow.]()
</Question>
<Answer>obtuse</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a rectangle</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Recall and use the properties of the interior angles of a square</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
The sum of the interior angles of a square is always...
</Question>
<Answer>270 degrees</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall and use the intersecting diagonals properties of a rhombus</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
The angles highlighted on this rhombus with different length diagonals can never be... ![A rhombus with the diagonals drawn in. The angle on the right hand side at the centre is highlighted in red and the angle at the bottom at the centre is highlighted in yellow.]()
</Question>
<Answer>90 degrees</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a rhombus</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
The equation \( f=2 r^{3}-1 \) is used to find values in the table below. What is the value covered by the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( r \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( f \) & \( 1 \) & \( 15 \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 47 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can find missing values in a given table by treating the row as linear and adding on the difference between the first two values given.</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Identify a unit of area</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Emma has answered a question on the area of a rectangle and got an answer of \( 60 \).

Behind the star she has written the units that she used.

\(
60 \, \bigstar
\)

Which of the following units could be correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( cm \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know units of area should be squared</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of area</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Sophia has calculated the area of a rectangle and got an answer of \( 80 \).

Behind the star she has written the units that she used.

\(
80 \, \bigstar
\)

Which of the following units could be correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know units of area should be squared</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Identify a unit of area</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Emma has answered a question on the area of a rectangle and got an answer of \( 32 \).

  Behind the star she has written the units that she used.

  \(
  32 \, \bigstar
  \)

  Which of the following units could be correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{m}^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know units of area should be squared</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Convert two digit integer percentages to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this percentage to a fraction
\( 75 \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{75}{10} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert two digit integer percentages to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this percentage to a fraction
\( 85 \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{8}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they can convert a 2 digit percentage to a fraction by writing one number over the other.</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert two digit integer percentages to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this percentage to a fraction
\( 75 \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide decimals by 10</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 54.8 \div 10= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.548 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divided by 100 rather than 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide decimals by 10</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 54.6 \div 10= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 44.6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide decimals by 10</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 54.7 \div 10= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 54.07 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a decimal by a multiple of 10, just divides the fractional place values</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\frac{2}{7}-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{\bigstar}{28}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\frac{3}{7}-\frac{2}{5}=\frac{\bigstar}{35}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 29 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\frac{3}{7}-\frac{2}{5}=\frac{\bigstar}{35}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify horizontal translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=f(x)
\)
to the graph of
\(
y=f(x+2)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Translation by vector
\(
\left[\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
2
\end{array}\right]
\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes f(x - a) translates the function up a units</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify horizontal translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=f(x)
\)
to the graph of
\(
y=f(x+4)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Translation by vector
\(
\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
4
\end{array}\right]
\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes f(x + a) translates the function up a units</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify horizontal translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=f(x)
\)
to the graph of
\(
y=f(x-3)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Translation by vector
\(
\left[\begin{array}{r}
3 \\
0
\end{array}\right]
\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes f(x) + a translates the function right a units</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand products of three binomials in the form (x + a)(x + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Triple Brackets and more</Subject>
<Question>
Sarah is expanding these three brackets:
\(
(x+4)(x-2)(x+7)
\)

She finds it helpful to split the first bracket and view the problem as follows:
\(
x(x-2)(x+7)+4(x-2)(x+7)
\)

She expands the brackets further. Before she simplifies, what are the terms that contain an \( \boldsymbol{x}^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}+7 x^{2} \\ +2 x^{2} \\ +4 x^{2}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a non-prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![A square connected to a trapezoid]()
</Question>
<Answer>Rectangular prism</Answer>
<Misconception>Struggles to visualise nets of 3D shapes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a non-prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![A square attached to a rectangle]()
</Question>
<Answer>Cylinder</Answer>
<Misconception>Struggles to visualise nets of 3D shapes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a non-prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![A square touching a smaller square]()
</Question>
<Answer>Cube</Answer>
<Misconception>Struggles to visualise nets of 3D shapes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Jane and John are discussing corresponding angles.
Jane says angles \( a \) and \( b \) are corresponding.

John says angles \( a \) and \( b \) are equal.
Who is correct? ![Shows two non parallel lines that are intersected by another line. Angles A and B are both on the outside of the lines and on opposite sides of the transversal.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
John</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks alternate angles are always equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify alternate angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing alternate angles.
Emma says angles \( a \) and \( b \) are alternate.

Jake says angles \( a \) and \( b \) are equal.
Who is correct? ![Shows two non parallel lines that are intersected by another line. Angles A and B are both on the outside of the lines and on opposite sides of the transversal.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks alternate angles are always equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify alternate angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing alternate angles.
Emma says angles \( a \) and \( b \) are alternate.

Jake says angles \( a \) and \( b \) are not equal.
Who is correct? ![Shows two non parallel lines that are intersected by another line. Angles A and B are both on the outside of the lines and on opposite sides of the transversal.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jake is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks only angles on parallel lines can be alternate</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from hours to minutes</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Sam's trip to the park is \( 2 \) hours and \( 30 \) minutes.
Alex's trip to the park is \( 150 \) minutes.
What is the difference in their trips in minutes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 70 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=3-\frac{2}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=1 \), what is the solution to \( x=3-\frac{2}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.83 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Stops iteration too early when solving equations</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=5-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=2 \), what is the solution to \( x=5-\frac{1}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=5-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=2 \), what is the solution to \( x=5-\frac{1}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (significant figures rather than decimal places)</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
How would you calculate the area of this triangle? ![A right triangle, base 8m, hypotenuse 10m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{8 \times 10}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used slant height (hypotenuse) and base to find area of a triangle rather than perpendicular height and base</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a rectangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
How would you calculate the area of this rectangle? ![A rectangle, length 8m, width 5m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{8 \times 5 \times 8 \times 5}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a quantity into two parts for a given a ratio, where each part is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
In the diagram, PQ : QR = 2 : 3
What is the distance PQ? ![A line that begins with point P, ends with point R, and has point Q in between. The entire length of the line measures 60 m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides total amount by each side of the ratio instead of dividing by the sum of the parts</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a quantity into two parts for a given a ratio, where each part is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
In the diagram, XY : YZ \( =4: 6 \)
What is the distance YZ? ![A line that begins with point X, ends with point Z, and has point Y in between. The entire length of the line measures 60 m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a quantity into two parts for a given a ratio, where each part is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
In the diagram, XY : YZ \( =2: 7 \)
What is the distance XY? ![A line that begins with point X, ends with point Z, and has point Y in between. The entire length of the line measures 63 m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds one part of a ratio but doesn't multiply that by the number of parts needed</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving odd and even numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these shows part of the proof that the sum of two even numbers is odd?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}2 n+(2 m) \\ =2(n+m)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that 2n represents an even number</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving odd and even numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these shows part of the proof that the sum of two odd numbers is even?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}(2n+1)(2m+1) \\ = 4mn + 2n + 2m + 1 \\ = 2(2mn + n + m) + 1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word "sum"</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving odd and even numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these shows part of the proof that the difference of two odd numbers is even?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Odd - Odd } \\ =\text { even }\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that 2n represents an even number</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Number line with -15 and -10 marked. Starting at -15, follow an arrow pointing to the right labelled +12. Then there is an arrow labelled b pointing to the left, which ends at -10 on the number line.]() What is the value of \( b \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes that an arrow on a number line starts at zero</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Number line with -15 and -8 marked. Starting at -15, follow an arrow pointing to the right labelled +12. Then there is an arrow labelled b pointing to the left, which ends at -8 on the number line.]() What is the value of \( b \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the starting number when counting backwards</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{2}{x}-\frac{y}{5} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2-y}{5x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and multiplies the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{2}{x}-\frac{y}{5} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2x-5y}{5x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they should multiply each numerator by its original denominator when adding/subtracting fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{2}{x}-\frac{y}{5} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2-y}{x-5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the volume of a cuboid, work out missing information</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
The volume of this cuboid is \( 40 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)

What length should replace the star? ![A cuboid, depth 4cm and height 5cm. The width is labelled with a star.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating volume instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² + bx + c where a is prime</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Step 1: Factorise the following expression

\(
5 x^{2}+7 x+2
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (5 x+2)(5 x+1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic with a non-unit coefficient of x squared, believes that coefficient will be in front of both x terms in the factorised form</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the solution to one problem, deduce the answer to a related problem using the same operation</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing related calculations
Tom says if you know that \( 2589+342=2931 \), then \( 2589+343 \) must equal \( \mathbf{2 9 3 2} \)

Katie says if you know that \( 2589-342=2247 \), then \( 2589 \) - \( 343 \) must equal \( \mathbf{2 2 4 6} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that adding a larger number gives a larger answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the solution to one problem, deduce the answer to a related problem using the same operation</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing related calculations
Emma says if you know that \( 2539+348=2887 \), then \( 2539+349 \) must equal \( \mathbf{2 8 8 8} \)

Jake says if you know that \( 2539-348=2191 \), then \( 2539 \) - \( 349 \) must equal \( \mathbf{2 1 9 2} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that subtracting a larger number will give a smaller answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret sloping linear sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows the distance of a car from a starting point over time.
What might the negative-sloping section represent? ![A graph with time (secs) on the horizontal axis and distance (m) on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels in a straight line up and right, travels horizontally, then travels in a straight line down and right back to the x-axis. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>The car has stopped moving</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses rest and movement on a distance time graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret sloping linear sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how far Fido the dog is from his home.
What might the negative-sloping section represent? ![A graph with time (secs) on the horizontal axis and distance (m) on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels in a straight line up and right, travels horizontally, then travels in a straight line down and right back to the x-axis. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Fido is accelerating</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a distance-time graph is the acceleration</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret sloping linear sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how far Luna the cat is from her starting point.
What might the negative-sloping section represent? ![A graph with time (secs) on the horizontal axis and distance (m) on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels in a straight line up and right, travels horizontally, then travels in a straight line down and right back to the x-axis. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Luna is walking away from her starting point</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a downward slope on a distance-time graph means travelling away</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve missing number mental multiplication questions</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star?
\[
\bigstar \times 4=108
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 432 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve missing number mental multiplication questions</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star?
\[
\bigstar \times 5 = 65
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate speed where distance and time are in the appropriate units</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
The formula for speed is
\(
\text { Speed }=\frac{\text { Distance }}{\text { Time }}
\)
A turtle travels \( 5 \mathrm{~m} \) in \( 20 \) hours. What was its speed?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \) metres per hour</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes speed is distance multiplied by time</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate speed where distance and time are in the appropriate units</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
The formula for speed is
\(
\text { Speed }=\frac{\text { Distance }}{\text { Time }}
\)
A bird flies \( 60 \mathrm{~km} \) in \( 3 \) hours. What was its speed?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.05 \) kilometres per hour</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a circle with centre at the origin, write its equation in the form x² + y² = r²</Construct>
<Subject>Equation of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this circle? ![A set of axes with a circle drawn. The circle goes through the points (5,0), (0, -5), (-5,0) and (0,5). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+y^{2}=\sqrt{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the square root of the radius with the radius squared in the equation of a circle</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a circle with centre at the origin, write its equation in the form x² + y² = r²</Construct>
<Subject>Equation of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this circle? ![A set of axes with a circle drawn. The circle goes through the points (3,0), (0, -3), (-3,0) and (0,3). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+y^{2}=6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a circle with centre at the origin, write its equation in the form x² + y² = r²</Construct>
<Subject>Equation of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this circle? ![A set of axes with a circle drawn. The circle goes through the points (6,0), (0, -6), (-6,0) and (0,6). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+y^{2}=6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the radius with the radius squared in the equation of a circle</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
If \( d=-3 \) what is the value of \( 8-3 d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Count backwards in steps of of something other than one</Construct>
<Subject>Counting</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is counting backwards in steps of \( 3 \).
She starts at the number \( 57,214 \) what is the next number she will say?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 57,213 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts on by 1, when asked to count forward/backwards in a step other than 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Count backwards in steps of of something other than one</Construct>
<Subject>Counting</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is counting backwards in steps of \( 3 \).
She starts at the number \( 37,482 \) what is the next number she will say?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 37,479 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the starting number when counting backwards</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable where the unknown appears on both sides of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
4x + 5 \leq 2x - 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \leq x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable where the unknown appears on both sides of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
4x - 5 \leq 3x + 2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \leq 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can multiply/divide through by a negative number without changing the direction of the inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable where the unknown appears on both sides of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
3x - 5 \geq 2x + 4
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \geq x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine the function of a single function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing this function machine ![A function machine with an input of n-4, no function labelled and an output of 5n-20]() Emma says the function could be \( +16 \)
Jake says the function could be \( \times 5 \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

\[620 \mathrm{~cm}=\] \[\square \mathrm{~m}\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 62 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10cm in a metre</Misconception>

```

<Question>
\[320 \mathrm{~cm}=\] \[\square \mathrm{~m}\]
```

<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\[5 \mathrm{~km}=\] \[\square \mathrm{~m}\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5000000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies when converting to a larger unit</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{3x+2}{4}=1+x\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3x}{4}=3+x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{3x + 4}{7} = 5 - x\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21x + 28 = 35 - 7x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly clears fractions from equations</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{3x+1}{4} = 5 + x\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(3x+1 = 20 + x\)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation with a fraction, thinks you don't need to multiply every term on both sides when multiplying by the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Water is poured into a glass at a constant rate.

This graph shows how the depth \( (d) \) of water in a glass changes over time \( (t) \).

Which of the following glasses is this most likely to be the graph of? ![A depth-time graph which is a curve starting at (0, 0), with a steep gradient to begin with but then the gradient decreases and the graph levels off to almost horizontal.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![A conical glass sitting on its circular base.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not interpret a sloping gradient as a change in rate</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
A bucket is being filled with water at a constant rate.

This graph shows how the height \( (h) \) of water in the bucket changes over time \( (t) \).

Which of the following buckets is this most likely to be the graph of? ![A height-time graph which is a curve starting at (0, 0), with a steep gradient to begin with but then the gradient decreases and the graph levels off to almost horizontal.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![A narrow cylindrical bucket with a wide cylindrical section on top.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not spot the difference between a gradual change of gradient and 2 distinct line segments with different constant gradients</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 less than a given number</Construct>

<Question>
What number is \( 1,000 \) less than \( 5,687 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4,687 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a power of 10, subtracts from the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 less than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 1,000 \) less than \( 50,678 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 51,678 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 less than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 1,000 \) less than \( 50,678 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50.678 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than subtracts when given the command 'less than'</Misconception>

\[
x+x+x+x
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \times x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Question>

\[
x+x+x+x
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes the variable before the coefficient in an algebraic term</Misconception>

\[
a+a+a+a
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( a^{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses collecting like terms with multiplication</Misconception>

\(
\frac{8}{10}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{5} \)</Answer>

\frac{15}{20}
\)

<Answer>\( \frac{15}{20} \)</Answer>

\(
\frac{2}{3 x}+\frac{5}{x}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{4 x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Add algebraic fractions where one denominator is a multiple of the other</Construct>

<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{5}{3 y}+\frac{2}{y}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{3 y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to change the numerators when finding equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out a subtraction problem with positive integers where the answer is less than 0</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
\( 325-700= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 375 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the smaller number is always subtracted from the larger, regardless of the order of the calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out a subtraction problem with positive integers where the answer is less than 0</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
\( 654-1200= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -556 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out a subtraction problem with positive integers where the answer is less than 0</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
\( 234-678= \)
</Question>
<Answer>This problem cannot be solved</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes it is impossible to subtract a bigger number from a smaller number</Misconception>

<Construct>Read values off a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
John pays at one rate for the first \( 50 \) units of water he uses. He pays at a different rate for all the other units of water he uses.

How much must he pay for using a total of \( 150 \) units of water? ![A graph showing how the cost changes for different numbers of units. The first 50 units cost £0.50 per unit. Then the rate changes to £0.25 per unit.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
The \( 1^{\text {st }} \) term in a linear sequence is \( 5 \).

The \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term of the sequence is \( 17 \).

What is the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term of the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is a multiplicative relationship between values of terms in a linear sequence e.g. 10th term is double 5th term</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
The \( 1^{\text {st }} \) term in a linear sequence is \( 5 \).

The \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term of the sequence is \( 17 \).

What is the \( 7^{\text {th }} \) term of the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 43 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you multiply the constant difference by the term number to get the term value</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a gradient, state the gradient of a line parallel to it</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
A line has a gradient of \( 3 \)

A line parallel to this line would have a gradient of...
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes parallel lines have gradients of opposite signs</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a gradient, state the gradient of a line parallel to it</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
A line has a gradient of \( 3 \)

A line parallel to this line would have a gradient of...
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes parallel lines have gradients that multiply to give -1</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a gradient, state the gradient of a line parallel to it</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
A line has a gradient of \( -2 \)

A line parallel to this line would have a gradient of...
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know parallel lines have equal gradients</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides both the numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Question>
Calculate: \( \frac{3}{9} \div 3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides the denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle when presented non-conventionally</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
\( E F G H \) is a square.
What type of triangle is triangle \( \mathrm{EFH} \) ? ![Square EFGH with the diagonal shown using a red dotted line]()
</Question>
<Answer>Scalene</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses scalene and right angle triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle when presented non-conventionally</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
\( P Q R S \) is a square.
What type of triangle is triangle \( \mathrm{QRS} \) ? ![Square PQRS with the diagonal shown using a red dotted line]()
</Question>
<Answer>Isosceles</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and right angle triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle when presented non-conventionally</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
\( E F G H \) is a square.
What type of triangle is triangle \( \mathrm{EFH} \) ? ![Square EFGH with the diagonal shown using a red dotted line]()
</Question>
<Answer>Equilateral</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and right angle triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "3b + 4" written inside it. The middle rectangle has "✕ 3" written inside it and the final rectangle is empty and has "output" written above it.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9b+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "3b + 4" written inside it. The middle rectangle has "✕ 3" written inside it and the final rectangle is empty and has "output" written above it.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3b + 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6b+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies when multiplying algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent an equation using a bar model</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
![Tom and Katie are discussing bar models.]() Tom says this bar model represents \( 3 x \) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline \( 3 \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Katie says this bar model represents \( 3 x \) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline \( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

\hline
\end{tabular} Who do you agree with?

<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>

\hline \( 3 \) & \( y \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Ben says this bar model represents \( 3 y \) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline \( y \) & \( y \) & \( y \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the whole amount, given a fraction of the amount</Construct>
<Subject>Fractions of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star?
\(
\frac{1}{4} \text { of } \color{yellow}\bigstar\)\(=30
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 102 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits multiply to 10 or more during a multiplication problem, does not add carried value to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the whole amount, given a fraction of the amount</Construct>
<Subject>Fractions of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star?
\(
\frac{1}{3} \text { of } \color{yellow}\bigstar\)\(=27
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine the input of a double function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
input \(\Rightarrow-5 \Rightarrow \times 5 \Rightarrow 25b-50 \) What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 b-45 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not apply the inverse function to every term in an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine the input of a double function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
input \(\Rightarrow-2 \Rightarrow \times 2 \Rightarrow 4x-8 \) What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2x-8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has completed only one of the two operations.</Misconception>

<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
input \(\Rightarrow 5 \Rightarrow +2 \Rightarrow 7b+10 \) What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5b + 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has completed only one of the two operations.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 150+250+10 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>

\(
c \div d
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d \div c \)</Answer>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
c \div d
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{d}{c} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a fraction means dividing the denominator by the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
x \div y
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( y x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that we can remove a division symbol and just write the variables next to each other</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would a rectangle belong? ![Venn diagram with two circles labelled with 'exactly two lines of symmetry' and 'rotational symmetry of order 2'. A is in the only exactly two lines of symmetry region, B is in the intersection, C is in the only rotational symmetry of order 2 region and D is outside the two circles.]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks rectangles have rotational symmetry or order 4</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would a rectangle belong? ![Venn diagram with two circles labelled with 'exactly two lines of symmetry' and 'rotational symmetry of order 2'. A is in the only exactly two lines of symmetry region, B is in the intersection, C is in the only rotational symmetry of order 2 region and D is outside the two circles.]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks rectangles have line symmetry in the diagonals</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent written scenarios as ratios</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise ratio in worded problem can be simplified</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \operatorname{Sin} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses sin when tan is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a numberline</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the following diagrams represents \( x<3 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Image of a number line. At 3 there is a red, filled circle drawn, with a arrow pointing to the left, towards the lower negative numbers in the number line.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the number of siblings a group of students has.
If calculating the mean number of siblings, what would replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 8 \) & \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) & \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \)
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) & \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2+3=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the fx column for calculating mean is value + frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the number of siblings a group of students has.
If calculating the mean number of siblings, what would replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 8 \) & \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) & \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \)
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) & \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2-3=(-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the fx column for calculating mean is value - frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the number of siblings a group of students has.
If calculating the mean number of siblings, what would replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 8 \) & \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) & \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \)
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \div 5=0.6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the fx column for calculating mean is value/frequency</Misconception>

\(-\) & \(4\) & \(5\) & \(7\) & \(\bigstar\)\\
\(\space\) & \(4\) & \(7\) & \(7\) & \(3\)\\
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

\(\space\) & \(4\) & \(7\) & \(7\) & \(3\)\\
\end{tabular}

<Construct>Subtract integers up to 4 digits using a written method where carrying is needed</Construct>

What number should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{cccc}
\(\space\) & \( 8 \) & \( 7 \) & \( 6 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\(-\) & \(3\) & \(9\) & \(8\) & \(\bigstar\)\\
\(\space\) & \(4\) & \(7\) & \(7\) & \(4\)\\
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>It is not possible</Answer>

\[

\]

<Answer>\( p=\frac{3}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, involving positive decimals</Construct>

<Question>
Solve the equation:
\[
0.6=0.2 p
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=0.12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, multiplies instead of dividing</Misconception>

\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( -10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is 1</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Vera wants to solve this equation using the quadratic formula.
\(
h^{2}+4=5 h
\)

What should replace the triangle? ![The image shows the structure of the quadratic formula. It says plus or minus the square root, and the triangle is the first thing after the square root sign, with a minus sign after it.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using the formula to solve a quadratic equation, believes that a, b and c are always taken from the 1st, 2nd and 3rd terms, respectively, of the quadratic.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using completing the square in the form (x + q)² + r</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>

One of these equations has no real solutions
Which is it?

<Answer>\( (x-3)^{2}=0 \)</Answer>

<Question>
A local gym wants to know the exercise habits of its members.
\( 30 \) members in Gym \( X \) are asked if they exercise regularly. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Gym X } \\
\hline Do you exercise regularly? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 24 \) \\
\hline No & \( 6 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} \( 150 \) members in Gym \( Y \) are asked if they exercise regularly. \begin{tabular}{|cc|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Gym Y } \\
\hline Do you exercise regularly? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 110 \) \\
\hline No & \( 40 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which results are more reliable?
</Question>
<Answer>Gym X</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that sample size affects reliability</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare relative frequencies in order to determine which prediction is likely to be more reliable</Construct>
<Subject>Experimental Probability and Relative Frequency</Subject>
<Question>
A local cafe wants to determine the popularity of their new coffee blend
\( 40 \) people in City \( X \) are asked if they liked the coffee. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ City X } \\
\hline Liked the coffee? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 28 \) \\
\hline No & \( 12 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} \( 150 \) people in City \( Y \) are asked if they liked the coffee. \begin{tabular}{|cc|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ City Y } \\
\hline Liked the coffee? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 105 \) \\
\hline No & \( 45 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which results are more reliable?
</Question>
<Answer>They are the same</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that sample size affects reliability</Misconception>

<Answer>The results from Town A are more reliable because the frequency of people who do not eat meat is lower.</Answer>

<Answer>\( 800 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks when finding a percentage you divide by the percentage being asked</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
![A line graph with title "Distance of a car".
The x-axis is titled "Time in minutes" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 60 minutes in steps of 10 minutes.
The y-axis is titled "Distance in kilometres" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 120 in steps of 20 kilometres. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0, 0), (10, 20), (20, 40), (30, 60), (40, 80), (50, 100), (60, 120).
]() How many kilometres did the car travel between \( 20 \) and \( 50 \) minutes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 140 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts when asked to find the difference</Misconception>

<Question>
![A line graph with title "Temperature over time".
The x-axis is titled "Time in hours" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 10 hours in steps of 1 hour.
The y-axis is titled "Temperature in degrees Celsius" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 50 in steps of 10 degrees. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0, 10), (1, 15), (2, 20), (3, 25), (4, 30), (6, 40), (8, 50), (10, 45).
]() How many degrees Celsius did the temperature change between \( 2 \) and \( 6 \) hours?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points.</Misconception>

<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>

![A line graph with title "Height of rocket".

The y-axis is titled "Height in metres" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 60 in steps of 10 metres. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0, 0), (10, 10), (20, 30),(30, 40), (40, 50), (60, 60).
]() How many metres did the rocket travel between \( 20 \) and \( 50 \) seconds?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points.</Misconception>

<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
The area of the rectangle on the right is \( 10 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \).

To find the value of \( x \), John uses:
\(x_{n+1}=\frac{10}{11}-\frac{x^{3}{ }_{n}}{11}\)

If \( x_{0}=0 \), what is the value of \( x \) to \( 3 \) decimal places? ![A rectangle with the base labelled x and the perpendicular height labelled x^2 + 11]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.873 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Stops iteration too early when solving equations</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify perpendicular lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>

\[

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=\frac{1}{4} x-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradients of perpendicular lines are reciprocals of the same sign</Misconception>

\[

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=2 x-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of parallel and perpendicular</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding a missing side of a parallelogram given the area completes an extra step of dividing by 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a parallelogram, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
The area of this parallelogram is \( 30 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)

What measurement should replace the star? ![Parallelogram with base length 5cm and the perpendicular height has a star symbol.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the area of a parallelogram finds base x perpendicular height but divides the answer by 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a parallelogram, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
The area of this parallelogram is \( 30 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)

What measurement should replace the star? ![Parallelogram with base length 5cm and the perpendicular height has a star symbol.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise we can find a missing length if we know the base of a parallelogram and its area.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-3x-4
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
y=x^{2}-3x-4 \leq 0 ?
\) ![The is a parabolic graph that crosses the x axis at the points (-1,0) and (4,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{-1 \leq x \leq 4\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution of a quadratic inequality is always the interval between the roots</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-x-6
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
y=x^{2}-x-6 \leq 0 ?
\) ![The is a parabolic graph that crosses the x axis at the points (-2,0) and (3,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -6).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{-2 \leq x \leq 3\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes any two inequalities can be combined into a double inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-2x-8
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
y=x^{2}-2x-8 \leq 0 ?
\) ![This is a parabolic graph that crosses the x axis at the points (-2,0) and (4,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -8).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x \leq -2\} \cup \{x \geq 4\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would \( \mathbf{2 5} \) belong? ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Square number and one labelled Odd number. Square Number without the intersection is labelled A, Odd Number without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]()
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know what a square number is</Misconception>

<Construct>Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would \( \mathbf{2 5} \) belong? ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Square number and one labelled Odd number. Square Number without the intersection is labelled A, Odd Number without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know what a square number is</Misconception>

<Construct>Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would \( \mathbf{4} \) belong? ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Square number and one labelled Odd number. Square Number without the intersection is labelled A, Odd Number without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]()
</Question>
<Answer>D</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up odd and even numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Order integers with a different number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these options show the numbers
23,456
2,345
234,567
23,450
in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}234,567 \\ 23,450 \\ 23,456 \\ 2,345\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Orders integers based on first digits without taking into account place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Order integers with a different number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these options show the numbers
12,435
435
123,435
4,350
in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}123,435 \\ 4,350 \\ 435 \\ 12,435\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following shows " \( x \) is greater than \( 5 \) "?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x<5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following shows " \( x \) is less than \( 5 \) "?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \leq 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using inequality notation, thinks "greater than/less than or equal to" symbols are instead the "greater than/less than" symbols and vice versa</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 300099 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 400000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 350067 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 350100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounded to nearest 100 instead of 1sf</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of vertical lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A graph of a vertical line going through 5 on the x axis. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=5y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes the y variable when giving the equation of a vertical line</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of vertical lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A graph of a vertical line going through 5 on the x axis. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = ? is a horizontal line through ?</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A graph of a horizontal line going through 5 on the y axis. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=5 y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the equation of a horizontal line is in the form x = ay, where a is the y intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence given by this rule:
\[
4-5n
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the first term of a sequence must be 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence given by this rule:
\[
3-5n
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the nth term of a linear sequence, thinks that the first term is the coefficient in front of n.</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Add proper fractions with the same denominator</Construct>

\(
\frac{3}{13}+\frac{5}{13}
\)
Write your answer in its simplest form.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{8}{26} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph, f(x), write down the solutions to f(x) = b</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
According to the graph, what is the approximate solution to
\(x^{2}-2x+3=5\) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-2x+3 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-1, \quad x=3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Solves for y=0 instead of given y-value when reading from a quadratic graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph, g(x), write down the solutions to g(x) = b</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
According to the graph, what is the approximate solution to
\(x^{2}-2x-3=4\) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-2x-3 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the y intercept when asked to read the solution to a quadratic equation from a graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of other prisms when the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>
![A rectangular based prism]() Emily remembers the formula for the volume of a prism:

Volume of a prism = Area of cross section \( X \) depth

In this shape, what length is the "depth"?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks depth always goes front to back in a diagram of a 3D shape</Misconception>
