</Question>
<Answer>\( 60^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates angle rather than calculating</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{(x+2)(x+4)}{(x+2)(x+8)}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x+3}{x+7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misunderstands the concept of common factors in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{(x+2)(x+4)}{(x+2)(x+8)}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x^{2}+6x+8}{x^{2}+10x+16} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Expands when asked to simplify</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The height is 5cm, the depth is 4cm and the width is 7cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (7 \times 5)+(7 \times 4)+(5 \times 4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating surface area, only includes visible faces</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The height is 5cm, the depth is 2cm and the width is 7cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \times 2 \times 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds volume when asked for surface area</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The height is 4cm, the depth is 3cm and the width is 6cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (6 \times 4) + (6 \times 3) + (4 \times 3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating surface area, only includes visible faces</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
5 - 3 \div (2 + 1) =
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 - 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
5 + 3 \times (2 - 1) =
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \times 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
5-3 \div (2+1)=
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>It doesn't matter: you get the same answer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
\frac{1}{3} x = 6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x = 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 8 \div 2 - 3 = \)
Problem Q: \( 8 \times 2 + 3 = \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 8 \div 2 \)
Problem Q: \( 8 \times 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 8-3+2= \)
Problem Q: \( 8+3 \times 2= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 3+2 \)
Problem Q: \( 8+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of any other operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 8-3+2= \)
Problem Q: \( 8+3 \div 2= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 3+2 \)
Problem Q: \( 3 \div 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Ben is trying to work out if \( 112 \) is a term in the sequence \( 4n + 3 \)

Below is his working out. What conclusion should Ben draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 4n + 3 & = 112 \\ 4n & = 109 \\ n & = 27.25\end{aligned} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 27.25 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 112^{\text {nd }} \) term</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 53 \) is a term in the sequence \( 4 n+3 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 4 n+3 & =53 \\ 4 n & =50 \\ n & =12.5\end{aligned} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 53 \) is not in the sequence because \( 12.5 \) is an integer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the position of a sequence cannot be an integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Sam is trying to work out if \( 55 \) is a term in the sequence \( 4n + 3 \)

Below is his working out. What conclusion should Sam draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 4n + 3 & = 55 \\ 4n & = 52 \\ n & = 13 \end{aligned} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Sam's method does not answer this question</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to calculate the position of a term in a sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+3 x+2}{x+2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x+1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly cancels what they believe is a factor in algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+3 x+2}{x+2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+4 x+4}{x+2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Does not simplify</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise factorising a quadratic</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation gives the fraction that replaces the question mark? ![A horizontal bar divided into 4 equal sections with vertical lines. The left hand section of these is coloured green and is further divided into 3 equal sections with vertical dotted lines. A curly bracket shows that the width of one of these green sections is denoted by a question mark.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand parts must be equal in a fraction diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation gives the fraction that replaces the question mark? ![A horizontal bar divided into 3 equal sections with vertical lines. The left hand section of these is coloured green and is further divided into 3 equal sections with vertical dotted lines. A curly bracket shows that the width of one of these green sections is denoted by a question mark.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \div \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation gives the fraction that replaces the question mark? ![A horizontal bar divided into 5 equal sections with vertical lines. The left hand section of these is coloured green and is further divided into 3 equal sections with vertical dotted lines. A curly bracket shows that the width of one of these green sections is denoted by a question mark.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{5} \div 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand parts must be equal in a fraction diagram</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square ABCD. E lies 1/3 from B on the line BC and is connected to D by a line. Attached to the square at line BC is a triangle BCE. The angle highlighted is the entire, interior angle at C.]()
</Question>
<Answer>CBE</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives 3-letter angle notation in the wrong order</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of triangle ABC. D lies on the line BC and is connected to A by a line. The angle highlighted is the entire, interior angle at B.]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives the vertex instead of the 3-letter angle notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Alex are debating about how to calculate the number of squares in Pattern \( 20 \).
Sam does: \( 20 \times 2 + 5 \)
Alex does: \( (20+3) \times 2 - 5 \)
Who is correct? ![The 5th and 6th terms in a sequence of patterns. Each pattern is made from blue squares. Pattern 5 is 15 squares: they are arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 4 squares wide and then 3 more squares, 1 each side of the middle squares (vertically). Pattern 6 is 18 squares arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 5 squares wide and then 3 more squares, 1 each side of the middle squares.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Sam</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes nth term rules for patterns must be given in standard an + b form</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Linda and Mark are debating the correct formula to find the number of squares in Pattern \( 20 \).
Linda suggests: \( 20 \times 2 + 5 \)
Mark suggests: \( (20 + 3) \times 2 - 5 \)
Who is correct? ![The 5th and 6th terms in a sequence of patterns. Each pattern is made from blue squares. Pattern 5 is 15 squares: they are arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 5 squares wide. Pattern 6 is 18 squares arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 6 squares wide.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes nth term rules for patterns must be given in standard an + b form</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 28 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Convert the remainders from written division problems into decimals</Construct>

<Question>
Sarah has been asked to work out the answer to:
\[
193 \div 4
\]
She gets the answer \( 48 \) remainder \( 1 \)
What is the exact value of that remainder?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes the remainder as the digit after the decimal point</Misconception>

\[
165 \div 4
\]
She gets the answer \( 41 \) remainder \( 1 \)
What is the exact value of that remainder?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand remainders in division</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 1 \)
Which of the options is a correct first step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\frac{2}{x+1}-\frac{4}{x-3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2-4}{x+1-x+3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 1 \)
Which of the options is a correct first step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\frac{4}{x+1}-\frac{2}{x-4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4(x+1)}{x(x-4)}-\frac{2(x-4)}{x(x-4)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to maintain equivalence in fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 1 \)
Which of the options is a correct first step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\frac{4}{x+3}-\frac{2}{x-1}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4(x-1)-2(x+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Removes the common denominator when making equivalent algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the numbers is the same when rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places or to \( 2 \) significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.125 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the numbers is the same when rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places or to \( 2 \) significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.046 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the first significant value is the first non-zero digit number</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.0476 \)</Answer>

\( 3.27 + 4.11 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7.38 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding decimals, just adds the digits and ignores place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals with the same number of decimals places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 2.47 + 1.65 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.012 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which option gives a correct substitution into the quadratic formula to solve the quadratic equation?

\(
4 x^{2}+3 x-7=0
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \pm \frac{\sqrt{3^{2}-4(4)(-7)}}{2(4)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1</Construct>

\(
4 x^{2}+3 x-1=0
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \pm \frac{\sqrt{3^{2}-4(4)(-1)}}{2(4)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

\(
4 x^{2}+3 x-7=0

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 \pm \sqrt{3^{2}-4(4)(-7)}}{2(4)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

\(

\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, multiplies instead of dividing</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.8 \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 480 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(cx + d)</Construct>

<Question>
Alison is expanding these two brackets.

What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The two brackets are (6q-2)(3q-5). The arrows are pointing at the 6q in the first bracket and the -5 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( +30q \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(cx + d)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Alison is expanding these two brackets.

What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The two brackets are (3x + 2)(4x - 5). The arrows are pointing at the 3x in the first bracket and the -5 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Question>

\[
0.5 \times 20
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying decimals, ignores place value and just multiplies the digits</Misconception>

<Question>
Work out:
\[
0.5 \times 10
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a decimal less than 1 by an integer, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.1 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise \( x^{2}+13x+40 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+5)(x+8) \)
</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise \( x^{2}+13 x+42 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+1)(x+42) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise \( x^{2}+17 x+60 \) Factorise \( x^{2}+17 x+60 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+10)(x+20) \) \( (x+10)(x+20) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a rhombus from a description of the properties</Construct>

<Question>

<Answer>Rectangle</Answer>

<Answer>Square</Answer>

<Construct>Identify a rhombus from a description of the properties</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following quadrilaterals could not be classified as a rhombus?
</Question>
<Answer>None of them are rhombuses</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not believe a shape can have two correct names e.g. rectangle and parallelogram</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the number of degrees in fractions of a turn</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 795^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a 1/4 of a whole is 25</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the number of degrees in fractions of a turn</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
How many degrees are there in \( \frac{3}{4} \) of a full turn?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 75^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there are 100 degrees in a full turn</Misconception>

<Construct>Find a negative reciprocal</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{3}{4} \times \star=-1 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 100</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{8 9 9 . 9 9 9} \) rounded to the nearest hundred?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 800 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{9 9 9 . 9 9 9} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When rounding up from a 9, does not add one on to the digit to the left</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{4 4 4 . 4 4 4} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 440 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{8}+\frac{1}{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{8}+\frac{1}{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not consider the denominator when adding/ subtracting fractions. Adds/subtracts the numerator and makes the denominator the one with the highest value.</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{12}+\frac{1}{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 0.6 + 0.4 \times 0.5 \equiv (0.6 + 0.4) \times 0.5 \)
Katie says: \( 0.6 + 0.4 \times 0.5 \equiv 0.6 + (0.4 \times 0.5) \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing the order of operations
Emma says: \( 0.4 + 0.5 \times 0.6 \equiv 0.4 + (0.5 \times 0.6) \)
Jake says: \( 0.4 + 0.5 \times 0.6 \equiv 0.5 \times 0.6 + 0.4 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition right to left if priority order means doing a calculation to the right first</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 0.4 + 0.5 \times 0.6 \equiv (0.4 + 0.5) \times 0.6 \)
Katie says: \( 0.4 + 0.5 \times 0.6 \equiv 0.5 \times 0.6 + 0.4 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Tom is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
3 \frac{3}{7}-\frac{2}{21}=3 \frac{1}{\bigstar}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 19 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
3 \frac{3}{4}-\frac{1}{8}=3 \frac{1}{\bigstar}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgot to simplify the fraction</Misconception>

```xml
<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
3 \frac{3}{7} - \frac{2}{21} = 3 \frac{1}{\bigstar}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when simplifying a fraction you can divide the numerator and denominator by different values</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5}^{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{7}^{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{7}^{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>The equation is undefined at this value</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x}{4}-7=16
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{4}=23 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( x-7=64 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x}{4} - 7 = 15
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{4} = 22 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( x - 7 = 60 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Lucas are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x}{4}-3=9
\)

Emma says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{4}=12 \)

Lucas says a correct next line of working could be: \( x-3=36 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.45 - 0.12 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.35 - 0.7 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -0.45 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you subtract the smaller digit from the larger digit in column subtraction, regardless of position</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.35 - 0.7 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting decimals with a different number of decimal places, lines up the digits incorrectly</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent positive unit fractions on a number line</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of picking a red ball is \( \frac{1}{4} \) Where is this value on the probability scale? ![B
c
D]()
</Question>
<Answer>D</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using the denominator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing mental addition and subtraction strategies.

Jo says a good way to add \( 19 \) is to add \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Paul says a good way to subtract \( 19 \) is to subtract \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \) and then add \( 1 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Anna and Ben are discussing mental addition and subtraction strategies.

Anna says a good way to add \( 29 \) is to add \( 20 \), then another \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Ben says a good way to subtract \( 29 \) is to subtract \( 20 \), then another \( 10 \) and then add \( 1 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Ben</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Lily and Max are discussing mental addition and subtraction strategies.

Lily says a good way to subtract \( 29 \) is to subtract \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \), and then add \( 1 \).

Max says a good way to add \( 29 \) is to add \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \), and then subtract \( 1 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Lily is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
![A pictogram where one smiley face = 8 people. Game 1 has 3 faces. Game 2 has 2.5 faces. Game 3 has 2 faces. Game 4 has 2.75 faces.]() The pictogram shows the number of people who went to watch a netball match.
How many people went to game 3?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts partial symbols as if they were whole on pictograms</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
![A pictogram where one star = 5 visitors. Day 1 has 3 stars. Day 2 has 2 stars. Day 3 has 1.5 stars.]() The pictogram shows the number of visitors to a museum.
How many visitors were there on Day 3?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores partial symbols on pictograms</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
![A pictogram where one smiley face =8 people. Game 1 has 4 faces. Game 2 has 3 faces. Game 3 has 2 faces. Game 4 has 2.75 faces.]() The pictogram shows the number of people who went to watch a netball match.
How many people went to game 4?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.75 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
Sara and Alex are discussing percentages.
Sara says \( 45 \%=0.045 \)
Alex says \( 45 \%>\frac{4}{9} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Sara</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides by 1000 instead of 100 when converting a percentage to a decimal</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Equivalent Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Complete the statement \( \frac{3}{4}=\frac{}{8} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4}=\frac{1}{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Can identify the multiplier used to form an equivalent fraction but does not apply to the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Equivalent Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Complete the statement \( \frac{3}{5}=\frac{}{15} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{5}=\frac{3}{15} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Equivalent Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Complete the statement \( \frac{2}{3}=\frac{}{15} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{3}=\frac{7}{15} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes equivalent fractions are formed with addition not multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a term</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe \( 4 x \) in this: \( 9 + 4 x \)
</Question>
<Answer>Variable</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a term with a variable</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a term</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe \( 5 h \) in this: \( 8+5 h \)
</Question>
<Answer>Expression</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses an expression with a term</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a term</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe \( 5 h \) in this: \( 10 + 5 h \)
</Question>
<Answer>Equation</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a term with an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( y \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -2 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, -2), (4, -2), (3, -1). Point (3, -1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The square is reflected in the line \( x = 3 \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -2 to 2. Four points are plotted and joined to make a square: (1, 1), (1, 3), (3, 3), (3, 1). Point (3, 1) is labelled with the letter "Q". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (1,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the line \( x = 1 \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -2 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, -2), (4, -2), (3, -1). Point (3, -1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
![A grid of 7 squares across and 7 squares up. A red vertical line goes from the bottom to the top of the grid, it is 4 squares left from the edge of the grid. An orange rectangle (3 squares width and 2 squares height) is drawn to the left of the red line, with its right-hand side on the red line.  The bottom side of the rectangle is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid. The top right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter P, which is 5 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. The bottom right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter Q, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. ]() Tom and Katie are discussing reflections

Tom says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( P \) stays in the same position

Katie says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( Q \) stays in the same position
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Tom is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

Which of the following is an obtuse angle?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 80^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

Which of the following is an obtuse angle?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 180^{\circ} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Identify a rectangle when presented non-conventionally</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
What shape do you get if you join up the midpoints of the sides of this shape? ![An irregular quadrilateral drawn on a grid]()
</Question>
<Answer>Rhombus</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not remember that a rhombus has equal sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a rectangle when presented non-conventionally</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
What shape do you get if you join up the midpoints of the sides of this shape? ![An irregular quadrilateral drawn on a grid]()
</Question>
<Answer>Parallelogram</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the properties of a kite</Misconception>

<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
What shape do you get if you join up the midpoints of the sides of this shape? ![A trapezoid drawn on a grid]()
</Question>
<Answer>Square</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a square</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{8 7 . 4 9} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 100</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{4 5 6 . 7 5} \) rounded to the nearest hundred?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 400 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 100</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{4 5 3 . 7 8} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 500 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Kate and Isaac share some yoghurt in the ratio \( 2: 5 \).
Kate has \(_____\) of the total yoghurt
What fraction completes the sentence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the displacement \( (s) \), of a particle when initial velocity \( (u)=2.9 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), final velocity \( (v)=3.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), and the time \( (t) \) taken is \( 5.2 \) seconds. \( s=\frac{1}{2}(u+v) t \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}s=\frac{1}{2}(2.9+3.5)+5.2 \\ s=8.4\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks two variables next to each other represent addition</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the displacement \( (s) \), of a particle when initial velocity \( (u)=2.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), final velocity \( (v)=3.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), and the time \( (t) \) taken is \( 4.7 \) seconds. \( s=\frac{1}{2}(u+v) t \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}s=\frac{1}{2}(2.5+3.8+4.7) \\ s=5.5\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks two variables next to each other represent addition</Misconception>

How many days in a leap year?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 360 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( \frac{3}{8} \).

What is the probability of the event not occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that probabilities of an event occurring or not occurring must be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( \frac{3}{8} \).

What is the probability of the event not occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives probability as an integer instead of a fraction</Misconception>

<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( (12)^{2}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=x^{2}+5\) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -7 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes addition comes before indices, in orders of operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>

<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=x^{2}+2\) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -23 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts half-squares as full squares when calculating area on a square grid</Misconception>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Underestimates the area of shapes when counting squares when some squares are neither wholes nor halves</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Calculate the area of a triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this shape? ![Triangle drawn on square grid with area of 8 half-squares]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts half-squares as full squares when calculating area on a square grid</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( -(25)^{2}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( -(20)^{2}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 400 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the negative outside the bracket means answer will be negative</Misconception>

<Question>
Which quadrilateral has the highest order of rotational symmetry?
</Question>
<Answer>![Kite]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Rotational Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these shapes has the highest order of rotational symmetry?
</Question>
<Answer>![Trapezoid]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Rotational Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
Which polygon has the highest order of rotational symmetry: a pentagon or a hexagon?
</Question>
<Answer>They each have the same order of rotational symmetry</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the number of sides gives the order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is the arrow pointing to? ![A number line from 300 to 400 with an arrow pointing to the value 380]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 376 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 260 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>

<Question>
What number is the arrow pointing to? ![A number line from 200 to 300 with an arrow pointing to the value 270]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 262 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct way of writing:

\( a \) multiplied by \( b \), then subtract \( 3 \)

using algebraic convention?
</Question>
<Answer>\( a(b-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not account for grammar when writing algebra e.g. ,then making a group</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct way of writing:

\( x \) multiplied by \( y \), then subtract \( 3 \)

using algebraic convention?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \times y - 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a transversal</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Line \( A B \) is... ![A pair of parallel lines are drawn with the arrows pointing up to the right.
A straight red line, AB, is drawn so that it diagonally crosses the pair of parallel lines. The red line rises from A on the left up to B.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Perpendicular</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes any lines that cross are perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a transversal</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Line \( AB \) is... ![A pair of parallel lines are drawn with the arrows pointing up to the right.
A straight blue line, AB, is drawn so that it diagonally crosses the pair of parallel lines. The blue line rises from A on the left up to B.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Skew</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the term transversal</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
If we want to write
"\( n \) multiplied by \( n \) multiplied by \( n \)"
using algebra, this would be:
</Question>
<Answer>\( n \times n \times n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
If we want to write
"\( n \) multiplied by \( n \) multiplied by \( n \)"
using algebra, this would be:
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
If we want to write
"\( n \) multiplied by \( n \) multiplied by \( n \)"
using algebra, this would be:
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{nnn} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes repeated letters instead of using index form of a variable</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
3, 5, 1, 8, 2, 4
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you don't need to numerically order the data before calculating the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
5, 9, 12, 18, 2, 7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
3, 1, 8, 6, 5, 2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.5 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
![Think of a number, then add \( 3 \), next multiply by \( 6 \), next subtract 2, and finally divide by \( 4 \).]() Sam says you can write this as:
\[
\left(\frac{(n+3) \times 6}{4}\right) - 2
\]
Alex says you can write this as:
\[
\left((n+3) \times 6 - 2\right) \div 4
\]
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 2x + 5y = 7 \)
What is its gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 2x + 5y = 10 \)
What is its gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that for a line written in the form ax + by = c, a is the gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 2 x+5 y=7 \)
What is it's gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Create a situation to match an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which model does not correctly represent the following expression?
\(3(m+2)\)
</Question>
<Answer>![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( m \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( m \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( m \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Create a situation to match an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which model does not correctly represent the following expression?
\(3(m+2)\)
</Question>
<Answer>![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \( \mathrm{m} \) & \( 2 \) & \( \mathrm{m} \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Create a situation to match an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which model does not correctly represent the following expression?
\(3(x+2)\)
</Question>
<Answer>![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \( \mathrm{x} \) & \( \mathrm{x} \) & \( \mathrm{x} \) & \( 2 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the distributive property</Misconception>

2n + 1 = p
\]

</Question>
<Answer>always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>

\[
2x + 1 = y + 1
\]
Using the diagram on the right, is the expression above... ![A bar model where the same length is represented by either 2 lengths of 'x' or 1 length of 'y']()
</Question>
<Answer>sometimes true</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>

\[
2x + 5 = 4y - 3
\]
Using the diagram on the right, is the expression above... ![A bar model where the same length is represented by either 2 lengths of 'x' or 4 lengths of 'y']()
</Question>
<Answer>Need more information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons. Tom says this is a regular polygon ![A square with 4 equal sides and 4 equal angles]() Katie says this is a regular polygon ![A rectangle with 2 pairs of equal sides marked]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word regular</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons. Tom says this is a regular polygon ![A square with 4 equal sides and 4 equal angles]() Katie says this is a regular polygon ![A rectangle with 2 pairs of parallel sides marked]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons. Tom says this is a regular polygon ![A square with 4 equal sides and 4 equal angles]() Katie says this is a regular polygon ![A rectangle with 2 pairs of parallel sides marked]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Katie is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant height instead of perpendicular height to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the area of this trapezium, what is the value of \( h \) in the formula? Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![Trapezium with the slanted sides labelled 9cm and 8.5cm. The parallel sides labelled 4cm and 9cm. The perpendicular height labelled 8cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant height instead of perpendicular height to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the area of this triangle, what is the value of \( h \) in the formula? Area \( = \frac{1}{2} \times b \times h \) ![Triangle with the base labelled 6cm and the perpendicular height labelled 4cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses base instead of height as h in area of a triangle formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
![A grid of 7 squares across and 7 squares up. A red vertical line goes from the bottom to the top of the grid, it is 4 squares left from the edge of the grid. An orange rectangle (3 squares width and 2 squares height) is drawn to the left of the red line, with its right-hand side on the red line.  The bottom side of the rectangle is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid. The bottom left corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter P, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid and 3 squares to the left of the red line. The bottom right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter Q, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. ]() Tom and Katie are discussing reflections

Tom says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( P \) stays in the same position

Katie says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( Q \) stays in the same position
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

![A grid of 7 squares across and 7 squares up. A red vertical line goes from the bottom to the top of the grid, it is 4 squares left from the edge of the grid. The bottom side of the rectangle is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid. The bottom left corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter P, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid and 3 squares to the left of the red line. The bottom right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter Q, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. ]() Tom and Katie are discussing reflections

Tom says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( P \) stays in the same position

Katie says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( Q \) stays in the same position
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate which two integer values the decimal equivalent of a square root must lie between</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Without using a calculator, which two integers must \( \sqrt{127} \) lie between?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 63 \) and \( 64 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses square rooting and halving the number</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{m}{6}-4=24
\)
Jo says you can write: \( \frac{m}{6}=28 \)
Paul says you can write: \( m-4=144 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation with a fraction, thinks you don't need to multiply every term on both sides when multiplying by the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Carl and Dan are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{x}{5}-3=17
\)
Carl says you can write: \( \frac{x}{5}=20 \)
Dan says you can write: \( x-3=85 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{l|l|l|l}
\( x \) & \( \) & \( 0 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( -4 \) & \( -3 \) &  \( \color{gold}\bigstar\ \) \\
\end{tabular}
 This is a table of values for \( y=2 x+c \)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that a pair of coordinates can be used to find missing parts of an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 90° clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Mary rotates square \( E F G H 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise from the centre \( (5,4) \). What error has she made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two squares drawn on it. The square labelled EFGH has the coordinates: E(3,4) F(4,4) G(4,5) and H(3,5). The other square has the coordinates: (6,4) (7,4) (7,5) and (6,5).]()
</Question>
<Answer>She has translated by the vector \( \left(\begin{array}{l}5 \\ 4\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a shape translated would not change orientation</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
John rotates rectangle \( A B C D 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise from the centre \( (3,2) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two rectangles drawn on it. The rectangle labelled ABCD has the coordinates: A(1,3) B(1,5) C(2,5) and D(2,3). The other rectangle has the coordinates: (4,3) (6,3) (6,2) and (4,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>He has rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) clockwise</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point P? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (1, 1), (3, 1), (2, 2). Point (2, 2) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=1 is shown with a purple dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,0) \)</Answer>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The square is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point Q? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -2 to 6, y-axis from -4 to 5. Four points are plotted and joined to make a square: (1, 3), (1, 5), (3, 5), (3, 3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "Q". The line y=3 is shown with a purple dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is corresponding to angle \( q \) ? ![Image showing two parallel lines cut by a transversal creating two distinct angles around a point. On the left hand side the pink angle is labelled with E, vertically opposite this is the angle labelled q. On the right hand side, angle F is co-interior to q. Then lying on the same straight line as F is the angle labelled G. Vertically opposite angle G is the angle labelled H.]()
</Question>
<Answer>E</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and vertically opposite angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is corresponding to angle \( p \) ? ![Image showing two parallel lines cut by a transversal creating two distinct angles around a point. On the left hand side the pink angle is labelled with A, vertically opposite this is the angle labelled p. On the right hand side, angle B is co-interior to p. Then lying on the same straight line as B is the angle labelled C. Vertically opposite angle C is the angle labelled D.]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses co-interior and corresponding angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is corresponding to angle \( q \) ? ![Image showing two parallel lines cut by a transversal creating two distinct angles around a point. On the left hand side the blue angle is labelled with E, vertically opposite this is the angle labelled q. On the right hand side, angle F is co-interior to q. Then lying on the same straight line as F is the angle labelled G. Vertically opposite angle G is the angle labelled H.]()
</Question>
<Answer>H</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and alternate angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
John rotates hexagon \( \mathrm{ABCDEF}  90^{\degree} \) clockwise from the centre \( (5,4) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two L-shaped hexagons drawn on it. The hexagon labelled ABCDEF has the coordinates: A(2,4) B(2,1) C(4,1) D(4,2) E(3,2) and F (3,4). The other hexagon has the coordinates: (6,7) (3,7) (3,5) (4,5) (4,6) and (6,6)]()
</Question>
<Answer>He has translated by the vector \( \left(\begin{array}{l}5 \\ 4\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mistakes rotations for translations</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 90 degrees clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
John rotates hexagon \( \mathrm{ABCDEF}  90^{\degree} \) clockwise from the centre \( (5,4) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two L-shaped hexagons drawn on it. The hexagon labelled ABCDEF has the coordinates: A(2,4) B(2,1) C(4,1) D(4,2) E(3,2) and F (3,4). The other hexagon has the coordinates: (6,7) (3,7) (3,5) (4,5) (4,6) and (6,6)]()
</Question>
<Answer>He has rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Co-ordinate Geometry with Straight Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Given that \( A C=3 A B \), what are the coordinates of \( C \) ? ![A straight line labelled y=2x-1 is drawn on a set of axes. Points A, B and C are all on the line. Point A is (2,3) and B is (5,9).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (14,27) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a ratio is part to part instead of part to whole</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Co-ordinate Geometry with Straight Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Given that \( A C=2 A B \), what are the coordinates of \( C \) ? ![A straight line labelled y=3x+1 is drawn on a set of axes. Points A, B and C are all on the line. Point A is (1,4) and B is (3,10).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (9,28) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find the length of a line segment from coordinates</Misconception>

\[
5(1+4x)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5+9x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 - 20x \)</Answer>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 20 \) out of \( 50 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you just add a % sign to the numerator to make a fraction into a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\(
0.3, \quad \frac{1}{5}, \quad 1.2, \quad \frac{3}{10}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \) and \( 1.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a percentage by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Given an equation, form or identify related equations</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are talking about statements that can be made about the equation on the right. \( 3x = z \) Jo says this is always true: \( 3x + 2 > z \)
Paul says this is always true: \( -3x < z \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes -a is always smaller than a, ignoring the possibility that a is negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>

<Question>
\( 0.25+40 \%= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 42.5 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals greater than 1 with 2 decimal places to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
\( 1.25+30 \%= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 145 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 1000 instead of 100 when converting a decimal to a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The formula for the volume of a cylinder, \( V \), is
\(V = \pi r^2 h\)

Rearrange this to make the radius, \( r \), the subject. ![An image of a cylinder with the radius labelled r and the height h.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( r = \pi r^2 h \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is
\(A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h)\)

Rearrange this to make the height, \( h \), the subject. ![An image of a triangle with the base labelled b and the perpendicular height h.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( h=\frac{2A}{b} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

Step \( 2 \)
\[
3=x
\]]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only step \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they must expand brackets before solving an equation</Misconception>

\[

\]

<Answer>\( 2y=-6x+10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines with at least one equation written in another form</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>

\[
y=-3x+5 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=10-3x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given the equation of a straight line, believes the first term always gives the gradient, even when the first term is actually c</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{2}{x+5}-\frac{3}{x-3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-1}{x+5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{1}{x+5}-\frac{2}{x-3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x-7}{(x+5)(x-3)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{t}{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1-t}{s-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Reduce a ratio involving two numbers to its simplest form</Construct>

\(
\frac{3}{4}: \frac{1}{8}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2: 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the order is important in a ratio</Misconception>
