\frac{2}{5}: \frac{4}{15}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6: 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not fully simplify ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the lower bound of a number rounded to 2 decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
A number, \( n \), has been rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places to give \( \mathbf{4 . 8 5} \)
What is the smallest \( n \) can be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the lower bound of a number rounded to 2 decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
A number, \( n \), has been rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places to give \( \mathbf{4 . 8 5} \)
What is the smallest \( n \) can be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.84 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand which place value is the one that determines if a number rounds up or down</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the upper bound of a number rounded to 2 decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
A number, \( n \), has been rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places to give \( \mathbf{4 . 8 5} \)
What is the largest \( n \) can be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.854 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand which place value is the one that determines if a number rounds up or down</Misconception>

<Construct>Match linear sequences to other representations, such as tables and graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
![The first three terms of a sequence represented using boxes. The first term is made of 2 boxes arranged side by side. The second term is the same pattern as the first but with two additional boxes added to the right hand side of the shape, side by side. The third pattern is the second pattern with an additional two boxes added to the right hand side of the shape, side by side again.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline Position & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Term & \(  \) & \( \bigstar \) & \(  \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What value should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term</Misconception>

<Construct>Match linear sequences to other representations, such as tables and graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
![The first three terms of a sequence represented using boxes. The first term is made of 1 box. The second term is made of 3 boxes arranged in a row. The third term is made of 5 boxes arranged in a row.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline Position & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Term & \(  \) & \( \bigstar \) & \(  \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What value should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the term in a sequence is double the position value</Misconception>

<Construct>Match linear sequences to other representations, such as tables and graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
![The first three terms of a sequence represented using boxes. The first term is made of 3 boxes arranged with 2 on the base and one box above the furthest left box. The second term is the same pattern as the first but with two additional boxes added to the left hand side of the shape, one on top of the other. The third pattern is the second pattern with an additional two boxes added to the left hand side of the shape, one above the other again.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline Position & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Term & \(  \) & \( \bigstar \) & \(  \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What value should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses left and right</Misconception>

<Construct>Follow simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Doubles side length for similar shape instead of using correct scale factor</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks adding the same value to each side makes shapes similar</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Arrow pointing to the left showing -24  and 4 arrows pointing to the left showing -24 in 4 equal parts]() Sam and Lucy are trying to write different calculations for the diagram shown.
Sam writes: \( 4 \times(-6)=-24 \)
Lucy writes: \( \frac{(-24)}{4}=6 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Sam</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a negative by a positive gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Arrow pointing to the right showing 18 and 3 arrows pointing to the right showing 18 in 3 equal parts]() Tom and Katie are trying to write different calculations for the diagram shown.
Tom writes: \( 3 \times 6 = 18 \)
Katie writes: \( \frac{(-18)}{3} = 6 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Add two equations together to remove a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Eliza is trying to solve the pair of simultaneous equations below.

\( \begin{aligned} -6 g-2 h & = & -2 \\ g-2h & = & 10 \\ \end{aligned} \)

She decides to add them together.
What will she end up with?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 g=8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misreads scale</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( x=5 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 x^{2}=50 \)
\( (2 x)^{2}=50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( x=5 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}4 x^{2}=100 \\ (4 x)^{2}=100\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies before applying a power</Misconception>

<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{c}\xi=\{\text { integers between } 1 \\ \text { and } 10 \text { inclusive }\} \\ P=\{\text { prime numbers }\} \\ Q=\{\text { multiples of } 3\}\end{array} \) ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled P and Q. P without the intersection is labelled A, Q without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]() In which region does \( \mathbf{3} \) belong?
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that the intersection of a Venn diagram represents those belonging to both sets</Misconception>

<Construct>Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{c}\xi=\{\text { integers between } 1 \\ \text { and } 10 \text { inclusive }\} \\ P=\{\text { even numbers }\} \\ Q=\{\text { prime numbers }\}\end{array} \) ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled P and Q. P without the intersection is labelled A, Q without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]() In which region does \( \mathbf{2} \) belong?
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that the intersection of a Venn diagram represents those belonging to both sets</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify fully (if possible):
\(
\frac{15}{90}
\) Simplify fully (if possible): \( \frac{15}{90} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{75} \) \( \frac{1}{75} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify fully (if possible):
\(
\frac{17}{85}
\) Simplify fully (if possible): \( \frac{17}{85} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be simplified Cannot be simplified</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes fractions with prime numerators cannot be simplified</Misconception>

<Construct>Plot two straight lines to find the solution to a pair of simultaneous equations</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows the graphical solution to: \( \begin{array}{c}2 x+3 y=15 \\ y=2-x\end{array} \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A four quadrant plane. Y axis -10 to 20 and x axis -10 to 20. A blue line goes from bottom left to top right sloping upwards. It goes through (-5, -2) and (5, 8). A red line goes from bottom left to top right sloping upwards. It goes through (0, -3) and (5, 7) ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an upward line has a negative gradient</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Plot two straight lines to find the solution to a pair of simultaneous equations</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows the graphical solution to: \( \begin{array}{c}2 x+y=8 \\ y=4-2x\end{array} \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A four quadrant plane. Y axis --3 to 6 and x axis -4 to 7. A blue line goes from bottom left to top right sloping upwards. It goes through (-4, 0) and (0, 4). A red line goes from top left to bottom right sloping downwards. It goes through (0, 6) and (3, 0) ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an upward line has a negative gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing sequences
Emma says \( (\boldsymbol{n}+\mathbf{2})^{2} \) would produce a linear sequence.
Jake says \( 5+\frac{n}{2} \) would produce a linear sequence
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing sequences
Tom says \( (\boldsymbol{n}+\mathbf{1})^{2} \) would produce a linear sequence.
Katie says \( 5-\frac{n}{2} \) would produce a linear sequence
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Lily are discussing sequences
Sam says \( (\boldsymbol{n}+\mathbf{2})^{2} \) would produce a linear sequence.
Lily says \( 5-\frac{n}{2} \) would produce a linear sequence
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes linear sequences cannot include fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
To make purple paint, you mix red paint with blue paint in the ratio \( 2: 3 \).
What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Red & Blue & Total \\
\hline \( \mathrm{800 ml} \) & \( \bigstar \)
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1200 \mathrm{ml} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
To make orange paint, you mix red paint with yellow paint in the ratio \( 4: 2 \).
What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Red & Yellow & Total \\
\hline \( \mathrm{1200 ml} \) & \( \bigstar \)
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1202 \mathrm{ml} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a difference of one part in a ratio means the quantities will differ by one unit</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
To make orange paint, you mix red paint with yellow paint in the ratio \( 2: 3 \).
What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Red & Yellow & Total \\
\hline \( \mathrm{2000 ml} \) & \( \bigstar \)
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3000 \mathrm{ml} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, uses that as one part in ratio without dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation is correct to find the number of degrees representing romance in a pie chart showing the following information? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline Film Genre & Comedy & Romance & Action \\
\hline Number of teachers & \( 9 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 360 \div 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes to find the angle for a pie chart sector you calculate 360 divided by the frequency of that sector</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
![A speed-time graph. At 10 seconds, the car is travelling at a speed of 5 metres per second. After 12 seconds, the car is travelling at a speed of 12 metres per second. ]() Here is a speed-time graph for a car.

Which of the following gives the best estimate for the distance travelled between \( 10 \) and \( 12 \) seconds?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when finding area under graph you can use the upper y value rather than average of upper and lower</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( p \) ? ![A long straight line with two shorter lines joining it, but not crossing it. Where the line on the left joins it forms two angles, p on the left, 138 degrees on the right. Where the line on the right joins it forms two angles, the left is unmarked, 42 degrees on the right.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 42^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks angles which look the same on diagram will be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( q \) ? ![A long straight line with two shorter lines joining it, but not crossing it. Where the line on the left joins it forms two angles, q on the left, 145 degrees on the right. Where the line on the right joins it forms two angles, the left is unmarked, 43 degrees on the right.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 43^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misinterprets the meaning of angles on a straight line angle fact</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( q \) ? ![A long straight line with two shorter lines joining it, but not crossing it. Where the line on the left joins it forms two angles, q on the left, 126 degrees on the right. Where the line on the right joins it forms two angles, the left is unmarked, 37 degrees on the right.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 53^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental subtraction problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
A \( 4 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
\square-6027=1253
\)
What is the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Emma wants to add \( 98 \) to a number.
Which one of the following methods would give her the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( +100 \) then \( +2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Emma wants to add \( 89 \) to a number.
Which one of the following methods would give her the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -100 \) then \( +11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0.8 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Certain</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 1 represents something that is certain</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0.8 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Unlikely</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 1 represents something that is certain</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0.4 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Impossible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

What is the area of this triangle? ![A right angled triangle with base length 8 cm, slant height 10 cm, and perpendicular height 6 cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used slant height and base to find area of a triangle rather than perpendicular height and base</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this triangle? ![A right angled triangle with base length 10 cm, slant length 13cm and perpendicular height 8cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1040 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>
What is the area of this triangle? ![A right angled triangle with base length 10 cm, slant length 13cm and perpendicular height 8cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 80 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a triangle</Misconception>

\hline Joe's Café \\
Sandwich \( £ 3.25 \) \\
Pasty \( £ 2.99 \) \\
Cake \( £ 2.25 \) \\
Soup \( £ 3.19 \) \\
Tea \( £ 1.55 \) \\
Coffee \( £ 1.95 \) \\
Orange \( 89 p \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 14.80 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In a worded problem, does not complete all calculations</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing the sequence \( \mathbf{7 n}+\mathbf{5} \)

Jo says \( \mathbf{1 4 9} \) is a term in the sequence.

Paul says \( \mathbf{1 5 0} \) is a term in the sequence.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Tom says for every one circle there are three squares
\(\bigcirc\bigcirc\bigcirc\)
\(\square\;\square\;\square\;\square\;\square\;\square\;\square\;\square\) Katie says for every one circle there are three squares
\(\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\)
\(\bigcirc\bigcirc\bigcirc\bigcirc\bigcirc\)
\(\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Is not able to spot a proportional relationship pictorially unless they are laid out in groups</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Emma says for every one triangle there are three stars
\(\triangle\)
\(\star\star\star\)
Alex says for every one triangle there are three stars
\(\triangle\triangle\triangle\)
\(\star\star\star\star\star\star\star\star\star\) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not believe you can scale up a proportional statement</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiplication law of indices with positive integer powers and a different base number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Lisa and Mark are discussing \( 2^{3} \times 5^{3} \)
Lisa says \( 2^{3} \times 5^{3}=10^{6} \)
Mark says \( 2^{3} \times 5^{3}=10^{3} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Lisa</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying numbers with different bases, multiplies the powers and multiplies the base numbers.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiplication law of indices with positive integer powers and a different base number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Leo are discussing \( 2^{3} \times 5^{3} \)
Emma says \( 2^{3} \times 5^{3}=10^{6} \)
Leo says \( 2^{3} \times 5^{3}=10^{3} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that multiplication can be broken down into factors</Misconception>

<Answer>Square</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>Cuboid</Answer>

Which of the following could shape \( R \) be? ![A circle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Cube</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of uniform cross section</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{llllll}\frac{8}{10} & \frac{41}{50} & \frac{7}{20} & 0.77 & \frac{4}{5} & \frac{79}{100}\end{array} \) Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{20} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{llllll}\frac{9}{12} & \frac{50}{60} & \frac{3}{4} & 0.75 & \frac{8}{10} & \frac{75}{100}\end{array} \) Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.75 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{llllll}\frac{5}{10} & \frac{21}{50} & \frac{3}{20} & 0.44 & \frac{2}{5} & \frac{49}{100}\end{array} \) Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{49}{100} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is the value in a data set with the biggest denominator, even if this value is close to the mean</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from days to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 3 \) days?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \times 12 \times 60 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 12 hours in 1 day</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from hours to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 3 \) hours?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converted hours to minutes instead of hours to seconds</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following vectors describes how to get from point \( P \) to point \( Q \)? ![The image shows a square grid and 2 points, P and Q. Point P is 4 squares left and 2 squares up from point Q. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{l}-4 \\ -2\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a positive y value in a column vector means to move down rather than up</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following vectors describes how to get from point \( P \) to point \( Q \)? ![The image shows a square grid and 2 points, P and Q. Point P is 4 squares left and 2 squares up from point Q. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}4 \\ -2\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the movement of the top number in a column vector is vertical, and the bottom number is horizontal rather than the other way round</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
q + 2 = \frac{3}{16}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( q = \frac{5}{16} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding an integer to a fraction, thinks you add the integer to the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
q - \frac{1}{6} = \frac{2}{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( q = \frac{1}{18} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, multiplies instead of adding</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a triangle</Misconception>

What is the area of this rectangle? ![Rectangle with length l=4cm and width w=2cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute into simple formulae given in words</Construct>

What is the area of this rectangle? ![Rectangle with length l=4cm and width w=6cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 48 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks halving is the same as multiplying by 2</Misconception>

<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>

What is the value of \( 3^{2} \) ?
</Question>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
The graph shows information about the temperature, \( T \) degrees Celsius, of a heating element \( t \) minutes after it was turned on.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \( t=5 \) ![The image is of a temperature-time graph. There is a straight line, a tangent, drawn so that it is touching the curve at t=5. The tangent goes through (3, 40), (5, 60) and (7, 80). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the difference between a value on a graph and the gradient of a graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
The graph shows information about the temperature, \( T \)°C, of a cup of coffee \( t \) minutes after being poured.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \( t=5 \) ![The image is of a temperature-time graph. There is a straight line, a tangent, drawn so that it is touching the curve at t=5. The tangent goes through (3, 75), (5, 65) and (7, 55). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 13 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient at a point = y coordinate/x coordinate</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise other roots of numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt[3]{27}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has multiplied by the root power</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise other roots of numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt[3]{27}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the root power of 3</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise other roots of numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt[3]{27}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides by the order of the root</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{llll|l|l}
\( x \) & \( -1 \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) &  & \( -1 \) &
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( y=x^{2}-x+1 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that subtracting a negative is the same as adding it's additive inverse</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
What is the gradient of this line?
\(3 x + 2 y = 12\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
What is the gradient of this line?
\(3 x - 2 y = 15\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{3}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 38 \) kilometers</Answer>

<Construct>Read values off a real life graph</Construct>

<Question>

<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify data which is qualitative or quantitative</Construct>
<Subject>Types of Data and Questionnaires</Subject>
<Question>
Leanne has written a questionnaire on the topic of holidays. One of her questions is,

"Describe how you feel when you are about to go on holiday."

What type of data is she collecting by asking this question?
</Question>
<Answer>Quantitative</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up quantitative and qualitative data types</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify data which is qualitative or quantitative</Construct>
<Subject>Types of Data and Questionnaires</Subject>
<Question>
Leanne has written a questionnaire on the topic of holidays. One of her questions is,

"How many times have you been on holiday in the past year?"

What type of data is she collecting by asking this question?
</Question>
<Answer>Attribute data</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of attribute data</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\( x^{2}+8x+4 \equiv(x \bigstar )^{2} \triangle \)
</Question>
<Answer>\(\bigstar =+8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\( n^{2}+8 n+2 \equiv(n \bigstar )^{2} \triangle \)
</Question>
<Answer>\(\bigstar =+16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is double the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer negative number problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation is equal to \( -20 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -5 \times 4 + (-3) - (-2) \times 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that subtracting a negative is the same as adding it's additive inverse</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer negative number problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation is equal to \( -16 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-4)^{2}+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer negative number problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation is equal to \( -10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-30) \div (-3) + 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a negative by a negative gives a negative answer</Misconception>

\( (-3)+(-4)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding two negatives gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving two negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-7)+(-4)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that adding a negative will increase the value of the original number</Misconception>

At what time did he first start travelling at \( 4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \) ? ![The image is of a graph. Its vertical axis labelled Velocity (m/s) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6 marked in even steps. Its horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has the scale 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 marked in even steps.
The graph is in three sections. The first section is a straight slanted line from (0,0) to (1, 4). The second section is a horizontal line from (1, 4) to (3, 4). The third section is a slanted line from (3, 4) to (5, 0).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \) secs</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about the order of rotational symmetry of quadrilaterals.

Tom says some quadrilaterals have an order of rotational symmetry of \( 4 \).
Katie says some quadrilaterals have an order of rotational symmetry of \( 5 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not connect rotational symmetry to number of sides/vertices</Misconception>

Who is correct?

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The top measures 4cm by 2cm, and the height is 7cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2 \times 7)+(4 \times 2)+(4 \times 7) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating surface area, only includes visible faces</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The top measures 5cm by 3cm, and the height is 8cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 5 \times 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds volume when asked for surface area</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star when solving the following problem using the grid method?
\(45 \times 230\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 200 \) & \( 30 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 40 \) &  &  \( \bigstar \) & \\
\hline \( 5 \) &  & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying involving a multiple of 10, just multiplies the digits and ignores the zeros</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star when solving the following problem using the grid method?
\(43 \times 217\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 200 \) & \( 10 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 40 \) &  &  \( \bigstar \) & \\
\hline \( 3 \) &  & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>

<Question>

\(43 \times 218\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 200 \) & \( 10 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 40 \) &  &  \( \bigstar \) & \\
\hline \( 3 \) &  & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying involving a multiple of 10, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be</Misconception>

\(
258+\square=1162
\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental addition problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
A \( 3 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
347+\square=1289
\)
What is the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts the smallest digit from the largest digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(q-3)(q+4) \equiv q^{2} \triangle q \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(p-5)(p+2) \equiv p^{2} \triangle p \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=-10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>

The point is reflected in the line \( x=4 \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-4,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = ? is the y axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
A point, \( P \), has coordinates \( (3,4) \)
The point is reflected in the line \( x=3 \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (4,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = ? or y = ? is y = x</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>

The point is reflected in the line \( x=3 \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( R \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,-4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks y = ? is the x axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( k=3 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}2 k^{2}=18 \\ (2 k)^{2}=18\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( k=4 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}2 k^{3}=128 \\ (2 k)^{3}=128\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies before applying a power</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( x=4 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}2 x^{3}=128 \\ (2 x)^{3}=64\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies before applying a power</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs</Construct>

\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \)</Answer>

\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>

<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying decimals, ignores place value and just multiplies the digits</Misconception>

<Subject>Length Units</Subject>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracted rather than divided by a scale factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Add fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{1}{4}+\frac{2}{4}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you add the number of wholes to the numerator when converting a mixed number to an improper fraction.</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Add fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
1 \frac{3}{4}+\frac{2}{4}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you add the whole to the numerators, ignoring denominators, when adding a mixed number to a proper fraction with the same denominator.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the description of an algebraic term with powers, write the term using algebra</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( x \) multiplied by the square of \( y \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x y)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has not realised that the answer may be changed by the insertion of brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the description of an algebraic term with powers, write the term using algebra</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( p \) multiplied by the cube of \( q \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p q+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cubing a number means adding 3 to that number</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the description of an algebraic term with powers, write the term using algebra</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( p \) multiplied by the cube of \( q \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 p q \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes cubing a number means you multiply it by 3</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would \( x^{2}-5x+6=0 \) belong? ![A Venn diagram made up of two overlapping circles. One is labelled 'Factorises' and the other is labelled 'Has one solution equal to 0'.
A is in the 'Factorises' circle only, B is in the overlap of the two circles, C is in the 'Has one solution equal to 0' circle only, and D is outside the circles.]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes all quadratic equations have a solution of 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a triangle, made of 3 squares in a diagonal line. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 1 more square added below the last square of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 1 more square added below the last square of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 1 more square added below the last square of Pattern 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![This pattern is the same as Pattern 4: it is made up of 4 squares in a diagonal line with no additional squares added.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>![This pattern is a 6x6 square grid.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a square, made of 4 squares in a 2x2 grid. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 1 more square added to the right. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 1 more square added to the right. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 1 more square added to the right.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![This pattern is made up of 8 squares in a 4x2 rectangle.]()</Answer>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "✕ 3" written inside it, the next rectangle has "− 5" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "10" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reverses the order of operations but does not apply the inverse operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "÷ 3" written inside it, the next rectangle has "+ 4" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "10" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "− 3" written inside it, the next rectangle has "✕ 4" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "20" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 17 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}-7 q
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q+7)(q-7) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}-7 q
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q+\sqrt{7})(q-\sqrt{7}) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an arithmetic sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing arithmetic sequences.

Tom says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 3,6,9,12,15, \ldots \)

Katie says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 3,9,27,81,243, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Recognise an arithmetic sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing arithmetic sequences.

Tom says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,8,11,14,17, \ldots \)

Katie says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,15,45,135,405, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Recognise an arithmetic sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing arithmetic sequences.

Tom says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,8,11,14,17, \ldots \)

Katie says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,15,45,135,405, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What fraction is the arrow pointing to? ![An image of a numberline with 5 dashes. On the leftmost dash is the number 1/8. On the rightmost dash is the number 5/8. An arrow points to the 3rd dash from the left]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading a dash on a number line does not take into account the number at the start or the width of each division</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What fraction is the arrow pointing to? ![An image of a numberline with 5 dashes. On the leftmost dash is the number 0/5. On the rightmost dash is the number 5/5. An arrow points to the 3rd dash from the left]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2.5}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the arrow on a number line points to the middle value</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What fraction is the arrow pointing to? ![An image of a numberline with 7 dashes. On the leftmost dash is the number 1/8. On the rightmost dash is the number 4/8. An arrow points to the 6th dash from the left]()
</Question>
<Answer>There is no such fraction</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise you can use equivalent fractions to break fractions up into smaller divisions</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A smoothie is made of fruit and milk in the ratio \( 2: 1 \). What fraction of the smoothie is milk?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A smoothie is made of strawberries and bananas in the ratio \( 2: 1 \). What fraction of the smoothie is bananas?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A fruit salad is made of apples and bananas in the ratio \( 2: 1 \). What fraction of the salad is bananas?
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the relationship between a ratio and fraction</Misconception>

<Question>
How far away from home was Rachel at 11:30? ![A line graph with title "A graph to show the distance Rachel travels from her home on her daily run."
The x-axis is titled "Time" and is labelled with times from 0800 to 1300 in steps of 1 hour, with the axis going half an hour beyond 1300.
The y-axis is titled "Distance from home (Km)" and the scale is from 0 to 8 in steps of 1km. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0800, 0), (0830, 2), (0900, 3.5),(1000, 6), (1030, 7), (1100, 7.5),(1230, 7.5),(1300, 4.5), (1330, 0).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \mathrm{~km} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a horizontal line on a distance time graph means a distance of 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>

<Question>
One of these equations has no real solutions.
Which is it?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^2 = -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a number raised to a power will always give a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these equations has no real solutions.
Which is it?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^2 - 9 = 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes 0 is not a real solution to an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) blue marbles and \( 2 \) green marbles in a bag. ![The image shows the bag with the 5 blue marbles and 2 green marbles.]() Alex picks a green marble out and does not replace it.

He then has a second pick.
What is the probability the second pick is a blue marble?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reduce the denominator when an item is not replaced in a probability question</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What is the solution for this equation? \( 5(2x-3)=3(10x-15) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution to an equation with matching coefficients of variables on both sides will always be 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing parallel lines
Tom says \( y=4 x+3 \) and \( y=4 x-2 \) are parallel
Katie says \( y=4 x+3 \) and \( y=2 x+3 \) are parallel
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Find a negative reciprocal</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( -\frac{2}{5} \times \star=-1 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{5}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Find a negative reciprocal</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( -\frac{3}{4} \times \star=-1 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about the relationship between two parts (e.g. one part is worth 5 more than another), work out the whole</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Alex share their profit in a ratio of \( 7: 3 \) Sam gets \( £ 60 \) more than Alex. How much money did they receive altogether?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 90 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where the difference between the sides is given, uses that as the total for one side instead</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Given information about the relationship between two parts (e.g. one part is worth 5 more than another), work out the whole</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Bill and Mischa share their profit in a ratio of \( 9: 5 \) Bill gets \( £ 72 \) more than Mischa. How much money did they receive altogether?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 432 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where the difference between the sides is given, uses that as one part without dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate a string of multiplications mentally</Construct>

<Question>
\( 4 \times 6 \times 10= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate a string of multiplications mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
\( 4 \times 6 \times 10= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying multiples of ten and the answer requires an extra digit, leaves off that extra digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{3}{5}-\frac{2}{5}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a fraction from a mixed number, assumes they just subtract the numerator from the integer of the mixed number</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{3}{4}-\frac{2}{4}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a fraction from a mixed number, assumes they subtract the numerator from the integer and the numerator of the mixed number</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract integers up to 3 digits using a written method where carrying is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
What is the answer to this subtraction problem? ![\begin{tabular}{r|r|}
\( 627 \) \\
\( -\quad 149 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 488 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract integers up to 3 digits using a written method where carrying is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
What is the answer to this subtraction problem? ![\begin{tabular}{r|r|}
\( 725 \) \\
\( -\quad 167 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 888 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts the smallest digit from the largest digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Combining Operations</Subject>
<Question>
John buys a shirt for £25 and three ties for £15 each.
He pays using a £50 gift card and some cash.

How much cash does he pay?
</Question>
<Answer>£90</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

Lucy says \( y=5-2x \) and \( y=3-2x \) are parallel
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jamie and Lucy</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the place value of each digit in integers</Construct>

<Question>
What is the value of the \( 6 \) in the number below?
\(
56218
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the ten thousands and thousands place value columns</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the place value of each digit in integers</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the \( 5 \) in the number below?
\(
65281
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the value of a digit, just gives the digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the place value of each digit in integers</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the \( 5 \) in the number below?
\(
6582
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not equate the value of a number with the place value column it is in</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise the following expression \( x^{2}+7 x+12 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+3)(x+6) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise the following expression \( x^{2}+8 x+7 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x(x+8)+7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks factorising a quadratic means factorising the variable terms into a single bracket, and leaving out the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>

<Question>
Emma thinks of a number. She triples it and adds \( 9 \). She then divides it by \( 3 \). The answer is \( 10 \). What was her original number? ![A cartoon of a woman, in this question called Emma, wearing a shirt, jeans, and black shoes. She is thinking of a number, we can tell this because she has a thought bubble above her head with a '?' in it.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>

He is thinking of a number, we can tell this because he has a thought bubble above his head with a '?' in it.]()

<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \frac{5}{100} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only reads the percentage symbol as applying to the units digit</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{84} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert two digit integer percentages to fractions</Construct>

What is \( 84 \% \) written as a fraction?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{84}{100} \)</Answer>

\[
(x+3)(x+2)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+x+3x+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 5780 \)</Answer>

<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 5800 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds incorrectly when the nearest 10 is a multiple of 100</Misconception>

<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 7532 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 81250 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 82,250 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 54321 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5,432,100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 72980 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 73080 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the depths below sea level of \( 3 \) creatures:
Starfish: \( -7 m \)
Shark: \( -9 m \)
Dolphin: \( -8.3 \mathrm{~m} \)
Arrange their depths in ascending order, starting with the deepest
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{\text {st }} \) Starfish
\( 2^{\text {nd }} \) Dolphin
\( 3^{\text {rd }} \) Shark</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the more digits a number has the greater it is, regardless of place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the temperatures in a freezer for \( 3 \) items:
Ice cream: \( -5^\circ C \)
Frozen pizza: \( -3^\circ C \)
Ice cubes: \( -4.5^\circ C \)
Arrange their temperatures in ascending order, starting with the coldest
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{\text {st }} \) Ice cream \( 2^{\text {nd }} \) Ice cubes \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) Frozen pizza</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Recognise the vertically opposite angles relationship</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is vertically opposite to angle \( q \) ? ![A diagram with 3 lines. 2 of the lines go from the left to the right of the diagram, getting closer to each other on the right hand side (the lines are not parallel). The 3rd line cuts through these 2 lines from top left to bottom right. Where the lines cross near the top left of the diagram, 4 angles are made. The angle which is nearest the top left corner of the diagram is labelled "A". Clockwise from A, the other angles around this point are labelled "C", "B" and "q". Where the lines cross near the bottom right of the diagram, 4 angles are also made, only one of these is labelled (the angle that is nearest to the top left of the diagram): "D". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles with angles on a straight line</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Recognise the vertically opposite angles relationship</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is vertically opposite to angle \( p \) ? ![A diagram with 3 lines. 2 of the lines go from the left to the right of the diagram, getting closer to each other on the right hand side (the lines are not parallel). The 3rd line cuts through these 2 lines from top left to bottom right. Where the lines cross near the top left of the diagram, 4 angles are made. The angle which is nearest the top left corner of the diagram is labelled "A". Clockwise from A, the other angles around this point are labelled "C", "B" and "p". Where the lines cross near the bottom right of the diagram, 4 angles are also made, only one of these is labelled (the angle that is nearest to the top left of the diagram): "D". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles with angles on a straight line</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 13 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying</Misconception>

\hline\( \ldots \ldots \ldots \) & \( 16^{2} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Halves when asked to find the square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 14^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \ldots \ldots \ldots \) & \( 11^{2} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the sum of 2 numbers, each squared first, is the same as adding the two numbers and then squaring the total</Misconception>

\( 5 \times \frac{1}{3}=5 \div ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>Not possible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know multiplying by a unit fraction is equivalent to: dividing by its denominator value</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a triangle using Side-Side-Side</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack are arguing about constructing triangles.

Emma says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 15 \mathrm{~cm}, 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Jack says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 9 \mathrm{~cm}, 6 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 4 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the sum of the two shorter sides must be greater than the third side for it to be a possible triangle</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Construct a triangle using Side-Side-Side</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about constructing triangles.

Tom says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 15 \mathrm{~cm}, 12 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Katie says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 9 \mathrm{~cm}, 4 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the sum of the two shorter sides must be greater than the third side for it to be a possible triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>

<Question>
![Pictogram showing smiley faces, where each smiley face is worth 10 people. Game 1 has 5 smiley faces. Game 2 has 2 smiley faces. Game 3 has 3 smiley faces. Game 4 has 2 smiley faces.]() The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>

![Pictogram showing smiley faces, where each smiley face is worth 10 people. Game 1 has 5 smiley faces. Game 2 has 2 smiley faces. Game 3 has 3 smiley faces. Game 4 has 2 smiley faces.]() The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know you can find the mean from a pictogram</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
![Pictogram showing smiley faces, where each smiley face is worth 10 people. Game 1 has 5 smiley faces. Game 2 has 2 smiley faces. Game 3 has 3 smiley faces. Game 4 has 2 smiley faces.]() The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the mean from a list of data, adds up the numbers but does not divide</Misconception>

\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Question>

There are \( 40 \) cows.

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes value of symbols in a pictogram without checking the key</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a descending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes this sequence?

\[
10,5,0, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 10 \) and the term-to-term rule is \( +5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Goes the wrong direction in the sequence when identifying term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a descending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes this sequence?

\[
10, 5, 0, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 10 \) and the position-to-term rule is \( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Describes term to term rules using position to term rules</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a descending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes this sequence?

\[
10, 5, 0, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 15 \) and the position-to-term rule is \( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the first term in a sequence is the term before the sequence begins (0th term)</Misconception>
