<Construct>Recognise when it is possible to factorise an expression into a double bracket</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Sam says when he is factorising \( x^{2}-6x \) he tries to think of two numbers that multiply together to give \( -6 \) and add together to give \( 0 \)

Lily says when she is factorising \( x^{2}-\frac{9}{4} \) she tries to think of two numbers that multiply together to give \( -\frac{9}{4} \) and add together to give \( \frac{3}{4} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Sam</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, believes the sum of the two values in the brackets equals bx rather than b</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which step of the balance diagram is incorrect? ![Image of an equation and three lines of working to solve it.
The equation is 3x+7=2x-3
Step A is 3x=2x-10
Step B is x= -10
Step C is x= 10]()
</Question>
<Answer>They are all correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Heads towards zero when subtracting from a negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A quadratic curve with a maximum turning point at (2, 1). The curve crosses the x axis at the points (1,0) and (3,0). It crosses the y axis at (0,-3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+1)(x+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to swap the sign of roots when placing into brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A quadratic curve with a maximum turning point at (2, 1). The curve crosses the x axis at the points (1,0) and (3,0). It crosses the y axis at (0,-2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-1)(x+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A quadratic curve with a maximum turning point at (2, 1). The curve crosses the x axis at the points (1,0) and (3,0). It crosses the y axis at (0,-2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+1)(x-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{5}{9} \) of a group of students are girls.
What would be a possible ratio of girls to boys?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5: 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses the denominator when converting from fractions to ratio, rather than numerator.</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{2}{5} \) of a group of students are girls.
What would be a possible ratio of girls to boys?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2: 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting fractions to ratios, puts the other side of the ratio as the total of the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{5}{9} \) of a group of students are girls.
What would be a possible ratio of girls to boys?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4: 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:

\(
5 q = \frac{1}{6}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( q = \frac{1}{30} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( x, y \) and \( z \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{x}{y+z}=x \div y + z
\)
Is the above relationship...
</Question>
<Answer>always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the numerator and denominator of fractions represent groupings and have the same order of priority as brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( x, y \) and \( z \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{x}{y+z}=x \div(y+z)
\)
Is the above relationship...
</Question>
<Answer>sometimes true</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the numerator and denominator of fractions represent groupings and have the same order of priority as brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( x, y \) and \( z \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{x}{y+z}=x \div y + z
\)
Is the above relationship...
</Question>
<Answer>Need more information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the numerator and denominator of fractions represent groupings and have the same order of priority as brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+17x+16 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \times 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+17 x+72 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \times 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the final stage of Jamie's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?

\[
(x+5)(x-2)=0
\] \( x=\bigstar \) or \( x=-2 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the constants in the factorised form</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the final stage of Beth's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?

\[
(h-4)(h+7)=0
\] \( h=\bigstar \) or \( h=7 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes both solutions of a quadratic will have the same absolute value, even when the graph is not symmetrical about the y axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the final stage of Sam's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?

\[
(x-5)(x+2)=0
\] \( x=\bigstar \) or \( x=-2 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes all quadratic equations have a solution of 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( q \) ? ![A right-angled triangle with the angle labelled 45 degrees, the side adjacent to this is 8cm and the side opposite is q.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \operatorname{Sin} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses sin when tan is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( q \) ? ![A right-angled triangle with the angle labelled 45 degrees, the side adjacent to this is 8cm and the side opposite is q.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Cos</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses cos when tan is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Sine (sin) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( h \) ? ![A right-angled triangle with the angle labelled 45 degrees, the side opposite to this is 8cm and the hypotenuse is h.]()
</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to apply sohcahtoa</Misconception>

<Construct>Add algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{x}{y}+\frac{3 y}{x} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x^{2}+9 y^{2}}{x y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When squaring a variable, believes they also need to square the coefficient</Misconception>

<Construct>Add algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{x}{y}+\frac{3 y}{x} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x+3 y}{x+y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Add algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{x}{y}+\frac{3 y}{x} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 x y}{x+y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding/subtracting fractions, adds/subtracts the denominators and multiplies the numerators</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "÷ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "- 5" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "5 - q/2" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has  "÷ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "- 5"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(5 - q)" written inside it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "x" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 4" written inside the next rectangle, "- 5" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "4(x - 5)" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "x" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "- 5" written inside the next rectangle, "✕ 4"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "4x - 5" written inside it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

```
<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "x" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2x + 3" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "x" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(x + 3)" written inside it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is trying to solve the equation below.

Here are her steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct? ![An equation 12 =  3q - 6 on the first line.
On the second line, Step 1 : 18 = 3q.
On the third line, Step 2: 6 = q]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only step \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tina is trying to solve the equation below.

Here are her steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct? ![An equation 12 =  3q - 6 on the first line.
On the second line, Step 1 : 18 = 3q.
On the third line, Step 2: 6 = q]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only step \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sarah is trying to solve the equation below.

Here are her steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct? ![An equation 20 =  5q + 2 on the first line.
On the second line, Step 1 : 22 = 5q.
On the third line, Step 2: 110 = q]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both steps are correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of an isosceles triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give the area of this triangle? ![A triangle with the base labelled with 30cm, the perpendicular height 12cm and the slant height labelled with 20 cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{30 \times 20}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used slant height and base to find area of a triangle rather than perpendicular height and base</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of an isosceles triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give the area of this triangle? ![A triangle with the base labelled with 30cm, the perpendicular height 10cm and the slant height labelled with 20 cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{30 \times 20 \times 10}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has multiplied base by slant height and perpendicular height to find area of a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of an isosceles triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give the area of this triangle? ![A triangle with the base labelled with 50cm, the perpendicular height 20cm and the slant height labelled with 30 cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{25 \times 20}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Halves base but still divides product by 2 when finding area of a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which vector correctly describes the translation that maps object \( R \) onto object \( S \)? ![The image shows a set of axes and two congruent rectangles R and S. Rectangle R has vertices at (2, 3), (2, 6), (5, 6), (5, 3). Rectangle S has vertices at (6, -1), (6, 2), (9, 2), (9, -1).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}4 \\ 3\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the movement of the top number in a column vector is vertical, and the bottom number is horizontal rather than the other way round</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which vector correctly describes the translation that maps object \( Q \) onto object \(P \)? ![The image shows a set of axes and two congruent triangles P and Q. Triangle P has vertices at (1, 5), (3, 7), (5, 5). Triangle Q has vertices at (4, 1), (6, 3), (8, 1).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}-3 \\ 4\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the equation of a line when given a negative gradient and a point on the line</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
A line has a gradient of \( -3 \) and passes through the point \( (2,2) \)
The equation of this line could be...
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=-3x+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes  c, in y=mx+c, will be the y value of the coordinate given despite the x coordinate not being 0.</Misconception>

<Construct>Add amounts of money together to make a total between £1 and £10</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Money</Subject>
<Question>
Sunita wants to buy a sandwich and a tea.

How much money will she need? Joe's Café
Sandwich £3.25
Pasty £2.99
Cake £2.25
Soup £3.19
Tea £1.55
Coffee £1.95
Orange 89p
</Question>
<Answer>£4.70</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Add amounts of money together to make a total between £1 and £10</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Money</Subject>
<Question>
Raj wants to buy a cake and a coffee.

How much money will he need? Joe's Café
Sandwich £3.25
Pasty £2.99
Cake £2.25
Soup £3.19
Tea £1.55
Coffee £1.95
Orange 89p
</Question>
<Answer>£4.10</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
The dodecagon below is regular. Find angle \( x \). ![A regular dodecagon (12 sided polygon). Each side is marked with a single dash to show that all sides are equal in length. One of the interior angles of the dodecagon is labelled with the letter "x".]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the interior angles of any polygon add up to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
The dodecagon below is regular. Find angle \( x \). ![A regular dodecagon (12 sided polygon). Each side is marked with a single dash to show that all sides are equal in length. One of the interior angles of the dodecagon is labelled with the letter "x".]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the interior angles of any polygon add up to 360</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a common factor involving numeric and algebraic components (e.g. 5a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When this expression is fully factorised, what is left inside the brackets? \( 30 a^2 b - 20 a b c \equiv 10 a b(\square) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 a \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a common factor involving numeric and algebraic components (e.g. 5a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When this expression is fully factorised, what is left inside the brackets? \( 36 a b^2 c - 24 a^2 c \equiv 12 a c (\square) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 b - 2 a \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise multiplying a variable by itself results in a power of that variable</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![\begin{tabular}{|lll|}
\hline\( \bullet \) & \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() How many circles will the next term in this sequence have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![\begin{tabular}{|lll|}
\hline\( \bullet \) & \( 10 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() How many circles will the next term in this sequence have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify square numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![\begin{tabular}{|lll|}
\hline \( \bullet \bullet \) & \( 4 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() How many circles will the next term in this sequence have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from minutes to hours</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3 \) hours \( +200 \) minutes \( = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \) hours</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from minutes to hours</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3 \) hours \( +400 \) minutes \( = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \) hours and \( 40 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

<Construct>Express a linear equation as a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function matches the equation
\[
y = 2(x + 3) ?
\]
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "𝑥" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "✕ 2" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "+ 3" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "y"]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Express a linear equation as a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function matches the equation
\[
y=3(x-2) ?
\]
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "y" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "- 2" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "✕ 3" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "𝑥"]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing a function as a function machine confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( x+y=20 \) Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}x=15 \\ y=10\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Changes the given operation when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( 2x + 3y = 15 \) Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=3 \\ y=2\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>substitutes incorrectly</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( x+y=15 \) Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=5 \\ y=12\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>substitutes incorrectly</Misconception>

</Question>

<Answer>\( \frac{55}{13} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
How many months have an average temperature above 25⁰C ? ![A line graph with title "Monthly Average temperatures for Zakynthos, Greece. (⁰C)".
The x-axis is labelled with the first letter of every month of the year and is titled "months".
The y-axis is titled "Average temperature (⁰C)" and the scale is labelled from 18 to 34 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (J, 18), (F, 20), (M, 21), (A, 22), (M, 23), (J, 25), (J, 29), (A, 32), (S, 27), (O, 22), (N, 20), (D, 18).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to find data points below a certain value, gives the number of data points above this value</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
How many months have an average temperature above 25⁰C ? ![A line graph with title "Monthly Average temperatures for Santorini, Greece. (⁰C)".
The x-axis is labelled with the first letter of every month of the year and is titled "months".
The y-axis is titled "Average temperature (⁰C)" and the scale is labelled from 16 to 30 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (J, 18), (F, 19), (M, 20), (A, 22), (M, 24), (J, 26), (J, 28), (A, 29), (S, 25), (O, 21), (N, 19), (D, 17).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes a data point with the value, when asked to find the number of data points above a value</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of triangle PQR with various lines extending from it. The marked angle is between the lines QR and RS.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( R \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives the vertex instead of the 3-letter angle notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square ABCE with various triangles attached to it.  The marked angle is between the lines CE and EG.]()
</Question>
<Answer>FEC</Answer>
<Misconception>In 3 letter angle notation, gives a wider angle that contains the shaded angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square ABCD with various triangles attached to it.  The marked angle is between the lines CD and DE.]()
</Question>
<Answer>EDC</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives 3-letter angle notation in the wrong order</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+11x+24 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \times 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+12 x+27 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \times 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+11x+24 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \times 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which option shows the fractions in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{llll}\frac{1}{12} & \frac{2}{6} & \frac{1}{2} & \frac{3}{4}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up smallest and largest when ordering fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which option shows the fractions in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{llll}\frac{1}{4} & \frac{2}{8} & \frac{3}{12} & \frac{4}{16}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ordered fractions by comparing denominators rather than using equivalent fractions.</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which option shows the fractions in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{llll}\frac{1}{10} & \frac{1}{5} & \frac{2}{20} & \frac{3}{30}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When comparing unit fractions believes that fractions with larger denominators are greater in size.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an odd numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
2,4,7,7,10
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mean instead of the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an odd numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
2, 4, 7, 11, 15
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median for an odd numbered data set, find the midpoint of two values rather than giving the middle value</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an odd numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
2,4,7,7,9
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mode instead of the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify multiples of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
If you list the multiples of \( 12 \) in ascending order, what is the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) number in the list?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 84 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the first multiple of a is 2a</Misconception>

<Construct>Can calculate missing coordinates in a geometric shape</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Here are \( 3 \) vertices of a rectangle:
\((1,5),(6,2),(3,0),\)

What are the coordinates of the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) vertex?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (1,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of a rectangle must be horizontal and vertical, not diagonal</Misconception>

<Construct>Can calculate missing coordinates in a geometric shape</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Here are \( 3 \) vertices of a rectangle:
\((1,2),(5,6),(3,8),\)

What are the coordinates of the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) vertex?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (7,4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of a rectangle must be horizontal and vertical, not diagonal</Misconception>

<Construct>Can calculate missing coordinates in a geometric shape</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Here are \( 3 \) vertices of a rectangle:
\((1,2),(5,-2),(3,0),\)

What are the coordinates of the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) vertex?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-1,-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of a rectangle must be horizontal and vertical, not diagonal</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{3}{y} \times \frac{4 z}{y^{2}}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 y+12 z}{y^{2}} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to multiply fractions, uses the method for adding instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{3}{x} \times \frac{4 y}{x^{2}}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{12 y}{3 x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes cubing a number means you multiply it by 3</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract two equations together to remove a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is trying to solve the pair of simultaneous equations on the right.

\[
4 x+2 y=10
\]
\[
4 x-5 y=-5
\]

She decides to subtract the bottom equation from the top equation.
What will she end up with?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 y=15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract two equations together to remove a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the pair of simultaneous equations on the right.

\[
5 x + 2 y = 10
\]
\[
5 x - 3 y = 1
\]

He decides to subtract the bottom equation from the top equation.
What will he end up with?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 y = 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract two equations together to remove a variable</Construct>

\[

\]
\[

\]

What will he end up with?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 h=9 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Compare the lengths of diagonal line segments without calculating the exact length</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about distance and coordinates.

Tom says \( (3,-2) \) and \( (2,-3) \) are equidistant from the origin.
Katie says \( (4,1) \) and \( (7,-2) \) are equidistant from the origin.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sum of change in x and change in y gives the distance between points</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare the lengths of diagonal line segments without calculating the exact length</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about distance and coordinates.

Tom says \( (4,-1) \) and \( (1,-4) \) are equidistant from the origin.
Katie says \( (5,2) \) and \( (8,-3) \) are equidistant from the origin.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Tom is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses negative and positive coordinates when working with graphs in four quadrants</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.45 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>

<Question>

What is the perimeter of the compound shape? ![A regular hexagon with a square joined along one edge]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 288 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that square root is found by dividing by 4</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>

What is the perimeter of the compound shape? ![A regular hexagon with a square joined along one edge]()

<Answer>\( 144 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines inside the shape are included when finding perimeter</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given the perimeter of a regular polygon, subtracts instead of divides to find each side length</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the perimeter, work out a missing length requiring knowledge of the geometrical properties of the shape</Construct>

<Misconception>When given the perimeter of a regular polygon, multiplies instead of divides to find each side length</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
![Squared paper with a horizontal line of reflection and a square. The bottom edge of the square is one square above the line of reflection.]() Tom and Katie are arguing about how to reflect the object in the line of reflection. Who reflects it correctly? ![Tom does this: his reflected square is sitting upright the same as the original object. The bottom edge is 2 squares below the line of reflection.]() ![Katie does this: her reflected square is upside down compared to the original object. The top edge of the reflected square is on the line of reflection.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Translates rather than reflects across a line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

![Squared paper with a horizontal line of reflection and a rectangle. The bottom edge of the rectangle is one square above the line of reflection.]() Tom and Katie are arguing about how to reflect the object in the line of reflection. Who reflects it correctly? ![Tom does this: his reflected rectangle is sitting upright the same as the original object. The bottom edge is 2 squares below the line of reflection.]() ![Katie does this: her reflected rectangle is upside down compared to the original object. The bottom edge of the reflected rectangle is on the line of reflection.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify or mark lines of symmetry on a shape</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify a line of symmetry in a simple shape</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Identify or mark lines of symmetry on a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Line Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
![A square divided into 4 equal sections by vertical and horizontal lines. The top left and bottom right sections are red, and the top right and bottom left sections are blue.]() How many lines of symmetry does this shape have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores colours or design on shape when looking for symmetry</Misconception>
```

```
<Construct>Identify or mark lines of symmetry on a shape</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks squares have line symmetry in the diagonals</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
Below is data from a Basketball team's matches over the course of a season, showing the number of points scored. How many matches did the team play? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Points scored & Frequency \\
\hline \( 50 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 60 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 70 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 80 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 90 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes total frequency in a table is found by counting rows</Misconception>

<Question>
Below is data from a Basketball team's matches over the course of a season, showing the number of points scored. How many matches did the team play? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Points scored & Frequency \\
\hline \( 50 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 60 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 70 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 80 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 90 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35 \)</Answer>

<Question>
Below is data from a Basketball team's matches over the course of a season, showing the number of points scored. How many matches did the team play? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Points scored & Frequency \\
\hline \( 50 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 60 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 70 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 80 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 90 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes total frequency in a table is given by the sum of the categories given</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
If
\(
x^{2}+7 x-18 \equiv(x+a)(x+b)
\)
then \( a \times b= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the coefficent of x in an expanded quadratic comes from multiplying the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
If
\(
n^{2}+7 n-18 \equiv(n+c)(n+d)
\)
then \( c \times d= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, believes the product of the constants in the brackets is of the opposite sign to the constant in the expanded equation.</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1250 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing a number as a percentage of another number gets them the wrong way around</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 80 \% \)</Answer>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack are discussing the order of operations
Emma says: \( 5+4-2 \equiv 5-2+4 \)
Jack says: \( 5+4 \times 2 \equiv 4 \times 2+5 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
John and Sarah are discussing the order of operations
John says: \( 4+3-2 \equiv 4-2+3 \)
Sarah says: \( 4+3 \div 2 \equiv 3 \div 2+4 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Only Sarah</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>

<Question>

Emma says it is \( 90^{\circ} \)
Sam says it is \( 210^{\circ} \)
Who is correct? ![Angle with a protractor over it showing 210 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a 180 degree protractor to measure reflex angles gives the value of the acute or obtuse angle that is a complement to 360</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>

Mike says it is \( 270^{\circ} \)
Who is correct? ![Angle with a protractor over it showing 270 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Sara</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not add on 180 degrees when using a protractor to measure a reflex angle</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sophia is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Sophia's book. Sophia always records what operation she has done to both sides of the equation.

What operation should replace the star? ![A diagram showing the change from the equations 7x = to x = represented by a gold star]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( +7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, adds instead of dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.

What operation should replace the star? ![A diagram showing the change from the equations 7x = to x = represented by a gold star]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.

What operation should replace the star? ![A diagram showing the change from the equations 9y = to y = represented by a gold star]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, subtracts instead of dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the number of cups of tea and coffee sold in a café over \( 4 \) days.

How many cups of coffee were sold on Wednesday? ![A dual bar bar chart showing the number of cups of tea and coffee sold Monday to Thursday. The vertical scale showing the number of cups sold has 10 small boxes between 0 and 10. The bar for tea on Wednesday reaches 4 small boxes above 10. The bar for coffee on Wednesday reaches 3 small boxes above 40.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+3x-4}{x-2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly factorises a quadratic</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+3x-10}{x-2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x-5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly factorises a quadratic</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+3x-4}{x-2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Does not simplify</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise factorising a quadratic</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
A regular shape must have...
</Question>
<Answer>Only all sides equal</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know equilateral means the same as regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
A regular polygon must have...
</Question>
<Answer>All angles equal to 90 degrees</Answer>
<Misconception>Does know know equilateral means the same as regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
A regular polygon must have...
</Question>
<Answer>All sides equal</Answer>
<Misconception>Does know know equilateral means the same as regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Ben share some marbles in the ratio \( 2\;: 7 \).
Alex gets \( 10 \) marbles.
How many marbles does Ben get?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a difference of one part in a ratio means the quantities will differ by one unit</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify vertical translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=f(x)\)
to the graph of
\(y=f(x)-2\)
</Question>
<Answer>Translation by vector
\(\left[\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
2
\end{array}\right]\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes f(x) - a translates the function up a units</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify horizontal translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=f(x)\)
to the graph of
\(y=f(x+1)\)
</Question>
<Answer>Translation by vector
\(\left[\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right]\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes f(x) + a translates the function right a units</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify horizontal translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=f(x)\)
to the graph of
\(y=f(x-1)\)
</Question>
<Answer>Translation by vector
\(\left[\begin{array}{l}
-1 \\
0
\end{array}\right]\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes f(x) - a translates the function right a units</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Given an exchange rate x = ny, convert to work out the number of x’s for a given y</Construct>
<Subject>Direct Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|}
\hline Exchange rates \\
\\
\( £ 1=€ 1.17 \) \\
\( £ 1=\$ 1.31 \)
\end{tabular} How much is \( € 5 \) worth in pounds ( \( £ \) )?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5.85 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to calculate with exchange rates</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Given an exchange rate x = ny, convert to work out the number of x’s for a given y</Construct>
<Subject>Direct Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|}
\hline Exchange rates \\
\\
\( £ 1=€ 1.17 \) \\
\( £ 1=\$ 1.31 \)
\end{tabular} How much is \( € 5 \) worth in pounds ( \( £ \) )?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to calculate with exchange rates</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( s \) the subject
\[
q=4 s+7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( s=q-7 \div 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misunderstands order of operations in algebraic expressions</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( r \) the subject
\[
p=3r+2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( r=\frac{p+2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the inverse operations of addition and subtraction when rearranging equations</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( -3(x-4) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3x+12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( -3(x-4) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3x-12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise an integer to a positive non-unit fraction power</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\( (27)^{\frac{3}{2}}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 81 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes they multiply by the numerator of fractional index</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise an integer to a positive non-unit fraction power</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\( (27)^{\frac{4}{3}}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 36 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing rearranging \( p=\sqrt{5-q} \) to make \( q \) the subject. Tom says a correct first line of working could be: \( p^{2}=5-q \). Katie says a correct first line of working could be: \( p+\sqrt{q}=\sqrt{5} \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing rearranging \( y=\sqrt{9-x} \) to make \( x \) the subject. Emma says a correct first line of working could be: \( y^{2}=9-x \) Jake says a correct first line of working could be: \( y+\sqrt{x}=\sqrt{9} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply an integer and an algebraic term</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
James is expanding these two brackets.

What should he get when he multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (x-5)(x-3). The arrows are pointing at the x in the first bracket and the -3 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply an integer and an algebraic term</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Emily is expanding these two brackets.

What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (x-5)(x-3). The arrows are pointing at the x in the first bracket and the -3 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( +3x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 42 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Find missing angles on parallel lines using corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the missing angle: ![Two vertical lines marked with arrows are crossed by one diagonal line. Two angles are marked; they are both on the lower side of the diagonal line and to the left of the vertical lines. One is marked '30', the other '?'. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 150^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks corresponding angles sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles on parallel lines using corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the missing angle: ![Two vertical lines marked with arrows are crossed by one diagonal line. Two angles are marked; they are both on the upper side of the diagonal line and to the right of the vertical lines. One is marked '80', the other '?'. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 280^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks corresponding angles sum to 360 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the prime factor decomposition of a number to calculate the number</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
What number should replace \(\color{gold}\bigstar \) in the Venn diagram? ![A Venn diagram with two circles. The left hand one is labelled 'prime factors of \star\', the right hand circle is labelled 'prime factors of 72'. In the left hand circle, there is a 7, in the overlap there is a 2 and a 3, and in the right hand circle there is a 2 and a heart. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the intersection in a prime factor venn diagram does not contribute to the size of the number represented by a circle</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the prime factor decomposition of a number to calculate the number</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
What number should replace \(\color{gold}\bigstar \) in the Venn diagram? ![A Venn diagram with two circles. The left hand one is labelled 'prime factors of \star\', the right hand circle is labelled 'prime factors of 72'. In the left hand circle, there is a 7, in the overlap there is a 2 and a 3, and in the right hand circle there is a 2 and a heart. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes factors add to give a number</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the prime factor decomposition of a number to calculate the number</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
What number should replace \(\color{gold}\bigstar \) in the Venn diagram? ![A Venn diagram with two circles. The left hand one is labelled 'prime factors of \star\', the right hand circle is labelled 'prime factors of 72'. In the left hand circle, there is a 7, in the overlap there is a 2 and a 3, and in the right hand circle there is a 2 and a heart. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 126 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiply all numbers in a prime factor venn diagram gives the value of one sets number</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest other integer value (e.g. 20, 50 etc)</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 70 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to nearest 50 not 20</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest other integer value (e.g. 20, 50 etc)</Construct>

<Question>
What is \( 73 \) rounded to the nearest \( 50 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand you can round to numbers other than powers of 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest other integer value (e.g. 20, 50 etc)</Construct>

<Question>
What is \( 378 \) rounded to the nearest \( 50 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 400 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 70 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Question>
What is \( 437 \) rounded to the nearest \( 50 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 450 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify rational and irrational numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Recurring Decimals to Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these two numbers are rational?
\(
\sqrt{2} \text{ and } \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the definition of a rational number</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify rational and irrational numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Recurring Decimals to Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these two numbers are rational?
\(
0.333\ldots \text { and } \sqrt{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the definition of a rational number</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify rational and irrational numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Recurring Decimals to Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these two numbers are rational?
\(
\sqrt{2} \text { and } \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Both</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the definition of a rational number</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}+3 q+5
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q+3)(q+2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}+4 q+6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q+6)(q-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}+4 q+5
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q+5)(q-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret the graphical solution to a pair of linear simultaneous equations from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The cost of journeys from two taxi companies is shown on the diagram.

After how many miles is Company P more expensive than Company Q? ![A graph showing Cost (£) on the y axis and Distance (miles) on the x axis. Y axis from 0 to 30, each square goes up by 5,  and x axis from 0 to 6, each square goes up by 1. A blue line slopes upwards from left to right, from (0, 10). It is labelled 'Company Q'. A red line slopes upwards from left to right, from (0,0). It is labelled 'Company P'. Both lines go through (5, 20)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Jake and Lily are discussing ways to calculate \( 49 \times 7 \) mentally
Jake adds \( 1 \) to \( 49 \) and then multiplies by \( 7 \)
Lily does \( 50 \times 7 \) and then subtracts \( 7 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers is valid.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Lily are discussing ways to calculate \( 72 \times 4 \) mentally
Sam doubles \( 72 \) and then doubles the answer
Lily does \( 75 \times 4 \) and then subtracts \( 12 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Lily</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that doubling and then doubling again is not the same as multiplying by 4</Misconception>

1,8,27,64, \ldots
\]

What is the name given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The square numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know what a square number is</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Recognise square numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1,4,9,16, \ldots
\]

What is the name given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The odd numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up odd and even numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1, 8, 27, 64, \ldots
\]

What is the name given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The triangular numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cube numbers are triangular numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Aaron completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\(
3 g^{2}-18 g-7 \equiv 3(g-3)^{2} \triangle
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=-16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying out 2 or more brackets, does not multiply all the combinations of terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Ben completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\(
2 h^{2}-20 h+3 \equiv 2(h-5)^{2} \triangle
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=53 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Emily completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\(
4 h^{2}+24 h-5 \equiv 4(h+3)^{2} \triangle
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=-14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes a coefficient of x^2 does not affect the value of the constant inside the bracket</Misconception>

<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 5 m \) is the same as ___ \( mm \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10000mm in a metre</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by counting squares</Construct>
<Subject>Perimeter</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is measuring the sides of this figure. ![A pentagon with one side, length 2 squares, labelled 4cm. The side labelled with the gold star is 3 squares in length.]() What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not account for scale on diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by counting squares</Construct>
<Subject>Perimeter</Subject>
<Question>
Mary is labelling the lengths of the sides of this shape. ![A rectangle with one side, length 4 squares, labelled 8cm. The side labelled with the gold star is 2 squares in length.]() What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrect use of scale on a diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of one expression</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct solution for the following pair of simultaneous equations:
\[2x+y=5\]
\[3x+2y=8\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=2 \\ y=1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of one expression</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct solution for the following pair of simultaneous equations:
\[5x+2y=12\]
\[2x+y=5\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=2 \\ y=1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of one expression</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct solution for the following pair of simultaneous equations:
\[5x+y=12\]
\[2x+3y=9\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=2 \\ y=-1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a surd in the form √a in a simplified form</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify \( \sqrt{72} \) as much as possible
</Question>
<Answer>\( 36 \sqrt{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not square root the largest square number that goes into the number under the surd before putting it in front of the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a surd in the form √a in a simplified form</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify \( \sqrt{72} \) as much as possible
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \sqrt{18} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not use the largest square number to simplify</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 8 \div 4+2= \)
Problem Q: \( 8 \div 4 \times 2= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 4+2 \)
Problem Q: \( 4 \times 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem A: \( 8 \div 2 + 4 = \)
Problem B: \( 8 \div 2 \times 4 = \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem A: \( 2 + 4 \)
Problem B: \( 8 \div 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before division</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 8 \div 4 + 2 = \)
Problem Q: \( 8 \div 4 \times 2 = \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 8 \div 4 \)
Problem Q: \( 4 \times 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Change decimals of hours into minutes</Construct>

<Question>
\( 0.5 \) hours \( = _______ \) minutes
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

<Construct>Change decimals of hours into minutes</Construct>

<Question>
\( 0.3 \) hours \( = _______ \) minutes
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10 minutes in an hour</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 67.5^{\circ} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation would give you the area of the face of this cuboid labelled \( Q \) ('the top')? ![A cuboid with dimensions 5cm by 4cm by 2 cm. The top face Q is marked. It is a rectangle with dimensions 5cm by 4cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \times 2 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \mathrm{~cm} \times 7 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \times 2 \mathrm{~cm} \times 7 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds volume when asked for surface area</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>

<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The outer scale goes from 0 to 360, clockwise. The angle is a reflex angle that is between the red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale) on the protractor and goes clockwise round to the red line that is halfway between 220 and 230 (outer scale) and halfway between 320 and 310 (inner scale).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 315^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (-2,3) (-2,6) and (0,5). The point P is the coordinate (0,5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-5,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (-2,3) (-2,6) and (0,5). The point P is the coordinate (0,5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-5,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (-2,3) (-2,6) and (0,5). The point P is the coordinate (0,5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,-5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects horizontally or vertically instead of across a diagonal line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Add integers up to 4 digits using a written method where carrying is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Addition</Subject>
<Question>
What number should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \(5\) & \(4\)\\
\hline+ & \( 2 \) & \(\bigstar\)  & \(7\) & \(1\) \\
\hline \(\space\) & \(6\) & \(3\) & \(2\) & \(5\)
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Add integers up to 4 digits using a written method where carrying is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Addition</Subject>
<Question>
What number should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) & \(6\) & \(7\)\\
\hline+ & \( 1 \) & \(\bigstar\)  & \(5\) & \(8\) \\
\hline \(\space\) & \(4\) & \(0\) & \(2\) & \(5\)
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+5x+6}{x^{2}-4x-5} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x+3}{x-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible: \( \frac{x^{2}-x-6}{x^{2}+2x-3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x-3}{2x-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that when you cancel identical terms from the numerator and denominator, they just disappear</Misconception>

\(

\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing fractions, does the reciprocal of the first fraction instead of the second</Misconception>

\(

\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative</Misconception>

\(

\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a numberline</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x \leq 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a numberline</Construct>
