</Question>
<Answer>\( x \leq 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve basic introduction simultaneous equation problems, often involving shapes and symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Chris orders \( 2 \) cups of tea and a cake, and his bill comes to £1.40

Amy orders \( 4 \) cups of tea and a cake, and her bill comes to £2.20.

How much does one cup of tea cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve basic introduction simultaneous equation problems, often involving shapes and symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Maria buys 3 apples and 2 bananas for £2.50.

John buys 1 apple and 4 bananas for £3.00.

How much does one banana cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
Sarah recorded the number of books she read in one month.
How many books did she read altogether? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Genre & Frequency \\
\hline Fiction & \( 4 \) \\
\hline Non-fiction & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Mystery & \( 2 \) \\
\hline Romance & \( 1 \) \\
\hline Other & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes total in a grouped table is found by counting rows</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
Bob recorded the number of cars he sold in one week.
How many cars did he sell altogether? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Colour & Frequency \\
\hline Blue & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Black & \( 2 \) \\
\hline Silver & \( 4 \) \\
\hline Red & \( 1 \) \\
\hline Other & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you do not include an "other" category when finding a total frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply two decimals together with the same number of decimal places</Construct>

<Question>
\( 0.5^{2}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

</Question>

Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Monday and the upper one showing Tuesdays sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Coffees bar lower section is 2 ticks below 50 on the vertical scale, and the whole bar's height is 1 tick above 100 on the vertical scale.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 65 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misreads scale</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the snacks sold in John's Store on Monday and Tuesday last week.

Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Monday and the upper one showing Tuesdays sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Chips bar lower section is 2 ticks below 50 on the vertical scale, and the whole bar's height is 3 ticks above 100 on the vertical scale.

</Question>
<Answer>\( 160 \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 288 \)</Answer>

<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4096 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Squares when asked to find the square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Jake and Emily are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Jake says to find \( 30 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 3 \).
Emily says to find \( 30 \% \) you divide by \( 10 \) and multiply by \( 3 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that dividing by 100 gives 10%</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Sara and Mike are discussing how to calculate percentages mentally.

Sara says to find \( 30 \% \) of an amount, you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 3 \).
Mike says to find \( 30 \% \) of an amount, you divide by \( 10 \) and multiply by \( 3 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Sara and Mike</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that dividing by 100 gives 10%</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing how to find \( 60 \% \) of a number.

Alex says to find \( 60 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 6 \).
Jamie says to find \( 60 \% \) you divide by \( 5 \) and multiply by \( 3 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Unable to equate a division and multiplication to a single division</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing Fibonacci sequences.

Tom says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 1,1,2,3,5,8, \ldots \)

Katie says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 2,3,5,8,13, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a Fibonacci sequence must start with 1, 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing Fibonacci sequences.

Tom says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 1,1,2,3,5,8, \ldots \)

Katie says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 1,2,3,5,8,13, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks it can't be called a sequence with a repeated number at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Lucy are discussing Fibonacci sequences.

Emma says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 2,4,6,10,16, \ldots \)

Lucy says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 3,6,9,15,24, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know what a Fibonacci sequence is</Misconception>

Which is it?

<Question>
One of these equations has no real solutions
Which is it?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+3)^{2}=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes 0 is not a real solution to an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{3}{5} \times 4=4 \div K \times L \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}K=5 \\ L=3\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies the denominator instead of the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{3}{8} \times 4=4 \div M \times N \)
</Question>
<Answer>Not possible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can write a division as a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply two decimals together with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star? \( \bigstar \times 0.3=1.5 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation thinks they divide when in fact they need to multiply</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply two decimals together with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star? \( \bigstar \div 0.2=1.2 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation thinks they add when in fact they need to multiply</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply two decimals together with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star? \( \bigstar \times 0.3=1.5 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation thinks they divide when in fact they need to multiply</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent written scenarios as ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
For every \( 4 \) books Sam reads, Alex reads \( 5 \).
Write the number of books Sam and Alex read as a ratio, with Sam's part first.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5\; : 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent written scenarios as ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
For every \( 4 \) apples Anna has, Ben has \( 5 \).
Write the number of apples Anna and Ben have as a ratio, with Anna's part first.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4\; : 5\; : 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to include the total as well as the individual parts when asked to write a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent written scenarios as ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
For every \( 4 \) apples Alice has, Bob has \( 6 \).
Write the number of apples Alice and Bob have as a ratio, with Alice's part first.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4\; : 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing ratio, writes total as one side</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Use the graph to approximate the solution to \( x^{2}<3 \) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x<-1.7, x>1.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Selects y>a solutions instead of y<a solutions for a quadratic inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out the whole</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
The ratio of cats to dogs in a shelter is \( 4: 2 \)

If there are \( 60 \) cats, how many animals (cats and dogs) are there in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 66 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the number in the ratio is the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>

<Question>

Pattern 1 is a rectangle with a total of 6 circles surrounding it. Pattern 2 is 2 rectangles with a total of 10 circles surrounding it. Pattern 3 is 3 rectangles with a total of 14 circles surrounding it.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>

Pattern 3 is 3 rectangles with a total of 14 circles surrounding it.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term before</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{12}{16} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies both numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that 1 part of a bar model will always have a value of 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
A math teacher wants to divide her class of \( 48 \) students into smaller groups for a project.
To do this she needs to know the _________ of \( 48 \)
Which word best fills in the gap?
</Question>
<Answer>Remainders</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that factors are divisors which split the number into equal groups</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
A math teacher wants to divide his class of \( 48 \) students into equal groups for a project.
To do this he needs to know the _________ of \( 48 \)
Which word best fills in the gap?
</Question>
<Answer>Fractions</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that factors are divisors which split the number into equal groups</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Least Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
A dance instructor wants to combine several classes of \( 12 \) students each into larger groups.
To do this she needs to know the _________ of \( 12 \)
Which word best fills in the gap?
</Question>
<Answer>Factors</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses factors and multiples</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = ? is a horizontal line through ?</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving adding a period of time on to a given start time</Construct>

If the train leaves Paris at 10:15, what time does it arrive in Lyon?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12: 85 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving adding a period of time on to a given start time</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>

If the train leaves Liverpool at 10:30, what time does it arrive in Glasgow?
</Question>
<Answer>03:15</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes times in the afternoon as if they are morning on a 24 hour clock</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{6} \times \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand parts must be equal in a fraction diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation gives the fraction that replaces the question mark? ![A horizontal bar divided into 5 equal sections with vertical lines. The left hand section of these is coloured green and is further divided into 2 equal sections with vertical dotted lines. A curly bracket shows that the width of one of these green sections is denoted by a question mark.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{5} \div \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that dividing by a decimal is the same as dividing by its reciprocal</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand where to place inputs/ operations/ outputs when drawing a function machine</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>

\)

<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>

\(

\)

<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 96 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines inside the shape are included when finding perimeter</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise a positive integer to a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about powers.

Jo says there is no value of \( m \) that means \( 2^{m} \) is odd.

Paul says there is no value of \( n \) that means \( 5^{n} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 90 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
A student wishes to solve the equation below.

Which of the following is a correct next step?
\(
(x-4)^{2}-16=0
\)

Step \( 1 \)
\(
(x-4)^{2}=16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x-4=4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only considers the positive solution when calculating a square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
A student wishes to solve the equation below.

Which of the following is a correct next step?
\(
(x+2)^{2}-16=0
\)

Step \( 1 \)
\(
(x+2)^{2}=16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x+2=8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the inverse of square rooting is halving</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>

\(
(x+4)^{2}-16=0
\)

Step \( 1 \)
\(
(x+4)^{2}=16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}=12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation</Misconception>

Sarah says \( \mathbf{8 2 5 . 9 9} \) rounded to \( 2 \) significant figures is \( \mathbf{8 2 0} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both John and Sarah</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up when next digit is 5</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jamie are discussing factors

Emma says \( 3 \) is a common factor of \( 5 x \) and \( 8 y^{2} \)

Jamie says \( x \) is a common factor of \( 5 x \) and \( 8 y^{2} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to identify common factors from algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing factors

Tom says \( 3 \) is a common factor of \( 5 x \) and \( 7 y \)

Katie says \( x \) is a common factor of \( 5 x \) and \( 7 y \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to identify common factors from algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing factors

Tom says \( 3 \) is a common factor of \( 5 x \) and \( 8 y^{2} \)

Katie says \( x \) is a common factor of \( 5 x \) and \( 8 y^{2} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to identify common factors from algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
When factorised, \( 25 x^{2}-49 \) will become...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 x(x-49) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes only the first term needs to be divided when factorising an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
When factorised, \( 25 x^{2}-49 \) will become...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 x(5 x-49) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes only the first term needs to be divided when factorising an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
When factorised, \( 4 x^{2}-25 \) will become...
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2 x+5)(2 x+5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division problems involving negative non-integers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{(-4) \times (-5)}{(-0.5)} = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a decimal by a whole number, ignores decimal point and just divides the digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division problems involving negative non-integers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{(-4) \times(-5)}{(-0.5)}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(cx + d)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Molly is expanding these two brackets.

What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (3q-2)(4q-5). The arrows are pointing at the -2 in the first bracket and the -5 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(cx + d)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Molly is expanding these two brackets.

What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (3x + 2)(4x - 5). The arrows are pointing at the 2 in the first bracket and the -5 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Find missing angles in an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( w \) ? ![An isosceles triangle with one of the base angles labelled with a w and the angle vertically opposite the vertex angle labelled with 35 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35^{\degree} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly identifies angles as vertically opposite</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( x \) ? ![An isosceles triangle with one of the base angles labelled with a x and the angle vertically opposite the vertex angle labelled with 45 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90^{\degree} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that vertically opposite angles are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{2 4 7 . 6 3 2} \) rounded to two significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{3 4 5 . 6 7} \) rounded to one significant figure?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 345.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply surds by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Operations with Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(5 \times \sqrt{7}\)

Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a surd by an integer, adds the integer to the number under the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply surds by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Operations with Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(4 \times \sqrt{5}\)

Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{20} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a surd by an integer, multiplies the integer with the number under the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply surds by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Operations with Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(7 \times \sqrt{5}\)

Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be simplified</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that an integer multiplied by a surd can be simplified</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand and simplify:
\(
(2 x+3)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 x^{2}+9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand and simplify:
\(
(2x + 5)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4x^{2} + 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand and simplify:
\(
(2x + 5)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2x + 5)(2x + 5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes expanding a squared expression means writing it as a set of double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing multiplying decimals.

Tom says \( 4 \times 2.7=2 \times 4.7 \)

Katie says \( 4 \times 2.7=2.7 \times 4 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the commutative property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing multiplying decimals.

Tom says \( 4 \times 2.8=2 \times 4.8 \)

Katie says \( 4 \times 2.8=2.8 \times 4 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the commutative property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing multiplying decimals.

Alex says \( 4 \times 2.7=2 \times 4.7 \)

Jamie says \( 4 \times 2.7=2.7 \times 4 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplication is not commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
Which description describes an isosceles triangle?
</Question>
<Answer>A triangle with one right angle.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and right angle triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
What are the characteristics of the angles in an isosceles triangle?
</Question>
<Answer>All angles are equal and measure 60 degrees each.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and equilateral triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
Which description describes an isosceles triangle?
</Question>
<Answer>A triangle with all sides of equal length and all equal angles.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and scalene triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are arguing about the result of this Function Machine:
Alex says the output is: \( 2 n-8 \)
Jamie says the output is: \( 2(n-4) \)
Who is correct? ![A function machine with input n and operations subtract 4, multiply by 2]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think a factorised expression is equivalent to its multiplied out form</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are arguing about the result of this Function Machine:
Emma says the output is: \( 2 n-8 \)
Jake says the output is: \( 2(n-4) \)
Who is correct? ![A function machine with input n and operations subtract 4, multiply by 2]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think a factorised expression is equivalent to its multiplied out form</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
5, \quad 11, \quad 31, \quad 91, \quad \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you add \( 6 \) to the previous term</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
3, \quad 9, \quad 27, \quad 81, \quad \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you multiply the previous term by \( 2 \) and add \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 0.0275 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.03 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 0.0245 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts leading zero as a significant figure</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 0.00456 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.005 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}-3 x+2}{x-1} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Does not simplify</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise factorising a quadratic</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out missing number multiplication problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star?

\(
(-4) \times \color{gold}\bigstar \color{black} =-12
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses dividing fractions method for multiplying fractions</Misconception>

What should replace the star?

\(
(-4) \times \color{gold}\bigstar \color{black} =-12
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first cube number greater than \( 60 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 61 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has confused cube numbers with prime numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first cube number greater than \( 64 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 81 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up square numbers and cube numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Order integers with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Ben and Emily are discussing how to order integers

Ben says \( 6000 \) is greater than \( 5999 \)

Emily says \( 2030 \) is greater than \( 2300 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Emily</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not equate the value of a number with the place value column it is in</Misconception>

<Construct>Order integers with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to order integers

Tom says \( 2000 \) is greater than \( 1999 \)

Katie says \( 4010 \) is greater than \( 4100 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not equate the value of a number with the place value column it is in</Misconception>

<Construct>Order integers with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Maria and John are discussing how to order integers

Maria says \( 6000 \) is greater than \( 5999 \)

John says \( 2030 \) is greater than \( 2300 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>John is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the y-intercept of a line from an accurate drawing</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
Use a graphing program (e.g. Desmos) to plot the following pairs of functions.
\[
y=x^{2} - 4 \quad \text { and } \quad y=x-4
\]

Tom says both functions are linear

Katie says both functions cross the \( y \)-axis at the same point

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a linear graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the y-intercept of a line from an accurate drawing</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
Use a graphing program (e.g. Desmos) to plot the following pairs of functions.
\[
y=x^{3} - 3 \quad \text { and } \quad y=x-3
\]

Tom says both functions are linear

Katie says both functions cross the \( y \)-axis at the same point

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Katie is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant only gives the y-intercept for linear graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to calculate the size of each interior angle in a regular \( 20 \) sided shape. Tom says you can do \( \frac{22 \times 180}{20} \) Katie says you can do \( 360-\frac{180}{20} \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an interior angle in a regular polygon can be found using 180(n+2)/n</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack are discussing how to calculate the size of each interior angle in a regular \( 24 \) sided shape. Emma says you can do \( \frac{26 \times 180}{24} \) Jack says you can do \( 360-\frac{180}{24} \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jack</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an interior angle in a regular polygon can be found using 360 subtract (180 over number of sides)</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 4x + 2y = 8 \)
What is its gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the gradient from the equation of a line in the form ax + by = c, believes b/a is the gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 4x + 2y = 8 \)
What is its gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 4x + 2y = 8 \)
What is its gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that for a line written in the form ax + by = c, a is the gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this shape? ![Blue, right angled triangle on square grid with area of 8 square units. Base length 4 and perpendicular height 4]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the area of a triangle is half the area of the containing rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this shape? ![Blue, right angled triangle on square grid with area of 6 square units. Base length 6 and perpendicular height 3]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the area of a triangle is half the area of the containing rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the perimeter, work out a missing length requiring knowledge of the geometrical properties of the shape</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
The perimeter of this rectangle is \( 6.2 \mathrm{~cm} \).

What is the length of the side marked with a star? ![Rectangle with base length labelled 1.05 cm and side length labelled with a gold star]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5.15 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the perimeter, work out a missing length requiring knowledge of the geometrical properties of the shape</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
The perimeter of this rectangle is \( 5.6 \mathrm{~cm} \).

What is the length of the side marked with a star? ![Rectangle with base length labelled 1.02 cm and side length labelled with a gold star]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.6 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When doing operations with decimals, ignores significant zeros after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Teddy calculates the answer to \( 600 \div 25 \) mentally "There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in 100. I then multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 6 \) to get \( 24 \). So \( 600 \) divided by \( 25 \) is \( 24 \)" Teddy uses the same method to calculate \( 800 \div 25 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \)
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \)
So the answer is \( 48 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to two decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Two different numbers are equal to \( 4.37 \) to two decimal places.
The numbers could be....
</Question>
<Answer>\[
4.378
\]
and
\[
4.368
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\[
5.6749
\]
and
\[
5.6651
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the meaning of congruency</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing congruent shapes.
Emma says you can slide a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.

Jake says you can flip a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that shapes are congruent if they have the same size and shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the meaning of congruency</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing congruent shapes.
Tom says you can translate a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.

Katie says you can dilate a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that shapes are congruent if they have the same size and shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the meaning of congruency</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Lisa and Mark are discussing congruent shapes.
Lisa says you can stretch a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.

Mark says you can shrink a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that shapes are congruent if they have the same size and shape</Misconception>

<Question>
\[
67892.3456
\]
What is this number rounded to the nearest \( 100 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 67892 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

\[
26789.4321
\]

<Answer>\( 26700 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Convert decimals greater than 1 to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
How do you write \( 3.8 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 38 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals greater than 1 to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
How do you write \( 6.8 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.068 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides instead of multiplies when converting a decimal to a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals greater than 1 to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
How do you write \( 2.5 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.5 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to just add a % sign to a decimal to convert to a percentage</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\[
1,1,3,3,5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1, 3, \) and \( 5 \)</Answer>

<Question>
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\[
1,1,3,3,5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can only have one mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mode as an average from a list of data when there is a single mode</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\[
1,1,3,3,3,5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the median instead of the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
The diagram shows a regular pentagon and a triangle.
What is the size of angle \( b \) ? ![A regular pentagon and triangle, joined on one side, with the angle between them labelled b. Not to scale]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 190^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes interior angles are outside a shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the change from purchases between £1 and £5</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Money</Subject>
<Question>
A book costs \( £ 3.40 \).

Emma pays for it with a \( £ 5 \) note.

How much change should she receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 3.40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In a worded problem, does not complete all calculations</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the change from purchases between £1 and £5</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Money</Subject>
<Question>
A book costs \( £ 3.40 \).

Emma pays for it with a \( £ 5 \) note.

How much change should she receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 2.60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ends up £1 out when dealing with change in money</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the change from purchases between £1 and £5</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Money</Subject>
<Question>
A book costs \( £ 3.50 \).

Emma pays for it with a \( £ 5 \) note.

How much change should she receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 8.50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle from a description of the properties</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
A triangle has the following angles: \( 90^{\degree}, 30^{\degree}, 60^{\degree} \)
Statement 1. It must be a right-angled triangle
Statement 2. It must be an isosceles triangle
Which is true?
</Question>
<Answer>Statement \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes isosceles triangles cannot have right angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle from a description of the properties</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
A triangle has the following angles: \( 90^{\degree}, 30^{\degree}, 60^{\degree} \)
Statement 1. It must be a right-angled triangle.
Statement 2. It must be an equilateral triangle.
Which is true?
</Question>
<Answer>Statement \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that a right angle is 90 degrees</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 25\degree \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there are 100 degrees in a full turn</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 72\degree \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the unit fraction when asked to find a non-unit fraction of an amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The square is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{Q} \) ? ![A coordinate grid with the reflection line y=x drawn and a square with the coordinates (1,2) (3,2) (3,4) and (1,4). Q is the point (3,4)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (4,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The square is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{Q} \) ? ![A coordinate grid with the reflection line y=x drawn and a square with the coordinates (1,2) (3,2) (3,4) and (1,4). Q is the point (3,4)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the squares rather than the diagonals when reflecting in y=x or y=-x</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

\]

What is the exact value of that remainder?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a remainder can be written as a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Sara and Mike are arguing about factorising.

Sara says \( q^{2}+20 q \equiv(q+10)(q+10) \)

Mike says \( q^{2}+20 q \equiv q(q+10) \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Sara</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are debating the solution to this inequality:
\[
20 \leq 5 n
\]

Alex says \( n \) could be \( 4 \)

Jamie says \( n \) could be \( 5 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about the solution to this inequality:
\[
15 \geq 4 m
\]

Tom says \( m \) could be \( 4 \)

Katie says \( m \) could be \( 3.75 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When using inequality notation, thinks "greater than/less than or equal to" symbols are instead the "greater than/less than" symbols and vice versa</Misconception>

The full width across the top is 28m, the partial width on the left is 12m, the partial width on the right is 9m. The full height on the right is 20m, the partial height on the lower block is 15m. The shaded section is the top rectangle across the full width.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 270 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses an incorrect side length when splitting a composite shape into parts</Misconception>

<Misconception>Lines up the digits incorrectly when doing a subtraction involving two numbers with a different amount of digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{llll|l|l}
\( x \) & \( -1 \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) &  &  \( 3 \)
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( y=x^{2}-x+3 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks tables of values are symmetrical about (0,0)</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{llll|l|l}
\( x \) & \( -1 \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) &  &  \( 3 \)
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( y=x^{2}-x+3 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that subtracting a negative is the same as adding it's additive inverse</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 7433 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{9 2 7 3 . 8} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9270 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 7500 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Answer>They are equal</Answer>
<Misconception>Student thinks that any two angles along a straight line are equal</Misconception>

\[

\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes angles on a straight line add to 360 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when an ascending sequence is linear</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing linear sequences.

Tom says this is a linear sequence: \( 1,3,5,9,13, \ldots \)

Katie says this is a linear sequence: \( 0.5,0.75,1,1.25,1.5, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when an ascending sequence is linear</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Ella and Ben are discussing linear sequences.

Ella says this is a linear sequence: \( 3,6,12,24,48, \ldots \)

Ben says this is a linear sequence: \( 2.5,2.7,2.9,3.1,3.3, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Ella and Ben</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when an ascending sequence is linear</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Emily and Jake are discussing linear sequences.

Emily says this is a linear sequence: \( 2,4,8,16,32, \ldots \)

Jake says this is a linear sequence: \( 0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{3}{x} \times \frac{4}{y}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x+4y}{xy} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to multiply fractions, uses the method for adding instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{3}{x} \times \frac{4}{y}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{x+y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{2}{x} \times \frac{3}{y}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{x y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and multiplies the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 24 \div 3 + 4 \times 3 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before division</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 12 \div 3 + 4 \times 5 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 29 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What improper fraction is shown on the number line? ![Line with 6 dashes spaced equally. No dashes at the start and end of the line. First dash marked with a 1 fifth dash marked with a 2. Blue arrow pointing upwards towards the fourth dash.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify a fraction on a number line</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What improper fraction is shown on the number line? ![Line with 5 dashes spaced equally. No dashes at the start and end of the line. First dash marked with a 1 fourth dash marked with a 2. Blue arrow pointing upwards towards the third dash.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confused mixed numbers with improper fractions</Misconception>

Without using a calculator, what is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
4,4,5,5,4
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>

<Question>
Without using a calculator, what is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
1,2,2,3,4
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is the middle number</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two independent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
![Two spinners shown. The first spinner has the numbers 1-3 and the second spinner has the number 1-4.]() You spin the above fair spinners
What is the probability of getting a \( 2 \) on both spinners?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, multiplies the numerator and adds the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two independent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>

![Two spinners shown. The first spinner has the numbers 1-4 and the second spinner has the number 1-5.]() You spin the above fair spinners
What is the probability of getting a \( 2 \) on both spinners?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two independent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>

<Answer>\( \frac{2}{20} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and multiplies the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Jim and Sarah are discussing the \( 5 \) trees with these heights:
\[
15 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 10 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 25 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 20 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 18 \mathrm{~cm}
\]

Jim says if all the trees doubled in height, the range wouldn't change.

Sarah says if all the trees grew by \( 10 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jim</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Alex are discussing the \( 5 \) trees with these heights:
\[
15 \mathrm{~m}, \quad 20 \mathrm{~m}, \quad 25 \mathrm{~m}, \quad 30 \mathrm{~m}, \quad 35 \mathrm{~m}
\]

Sam says if all the trees doubled in height, the range wouldn't change.

Alex says if all the trees grew by \( 10 \mathrm{~m} \) each, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Sam and Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the \( 5 \) plants with these heights:
\[
23 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 17 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 40 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 25 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 31 \mathrm{~cm}
\]

Tom says if all the plants doubled in height, the range wouldn't change.

Katie says if all the plants grew by \( 12 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you add the same value to all numbers in the dataset the range will change</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}-4}{x-2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}-4}{x-2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Does not simplify</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
If the original sequence looks like this: ![Two patterns made of circles. Pattern 1 consists of a central row of three circles, with an extra circle either side, making a cross. Pattern two consists of two central rows of three circles with one extra circle either side. ]() There are \( 302 \) circles in Pattern \( 100 \). But if the shape changes to this: ![These patterns are the same as those in the first picture except that in each, the second circle from each row of three has been removed. ]() How many circles would there be in Pattern \( 100 \) now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 301 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
If the original sequence looks like this: ![Two patterns made of triangles. Pattern 1 consists of a central column of three triangles, with an extra triangle either side, making a cross. Pattern two consists of two central columns of three triangles with one extra triangle either side. ]() There are \( 298 \) triangles in Pattern \( 99 \). But if the shape changes to this: ![These patterns are the same as those in the first picture except that in each, the second block from each column of three has been removed. ]() How many triangles would there be in Pattern \( 100 \) now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 300 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 75^{\circ} \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 115^{\circ} \)</Answer>

\hline & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() The perimeter of the shape is \( 24 \mathrm{~cm} \). The area of the square is \( 9 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \).
What is the area of the shape?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify alternate interior angles</Construct>

These marked angles are: ![A pair of parallel lines with a transversal line crossing both. The angles formed on the interior but on opposite sides of the transversal are marked.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Corresponding</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and alternate angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
These marked angles are: ![A pair of parallel lines drawn pointing up to the right. A straight line is drawn that crosses both parallel lines. The angles formed below the straight line and to the left of each of the parallel lines is marked.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Co-Interior</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses co-interior and alternate angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
These marked angles are: ![A pair of parallel lines drawn pointing up to the right. A straight line is drawn that crosses both parallel lines. The angles formed below the straight line and to the left of each of the parallel lines is marked.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Parallel</Answer>
<Misconception>Describes lines when asked to describe angles</Misconception>

Kay's company paid her \( £ 64 \)

How many miles did she travel?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Read values off a real life graph</Construct>

![A linear graph showing that 10 miles = £8. ]() The graph can be used to work out how much Kay's company pays her for travel.

Kay's company paid her \( £ 50 \)

How many miles did she travel?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes direct proportion means a 1:1 ratio</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 45 \% \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \% \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts squares instead of the correct scale when plotting coordinates</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Answer>Square</Answer>

<Answer>Parallelogram</Answer>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "×2" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "10" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "+½" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "6" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "+2" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "10" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is division</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
The pie chart shows the favorite sports of students in a school.

If there were \( 720 \) students in the school, which of the following would calculate how many students chose basketball? ![A pie chart split into five parts, labelled with sports. The part for Soccer is 120 degrees, Basketball is 60 degrees, Tennis is 90 degrees, Swimming is 70 degrees, and Other is 20 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{360}{60} \times 720 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a proportion of a whole is whole/part not part/whole</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
The pie chart shows the preferred vacation destinations of survey participants.

If there were \( 400 \) people surveyed, which of the following would calculate how many people chose the beach? ![A pie chart split into four parts, labelled with vacation destinations. The part for Mountains is 120 degrees, Beach is 60 degrees, City is 90 degrees, and Countryside is 90 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>You need more information</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes it is not possible to calculate the frequency for a pie chart sector despite being given enough information to do so</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 523-800= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 277 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs subtraction in wrong order</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out a subtraction problem with positive integers where the answer is less than 0</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
\( 550-800= \)
</Question>
<Answer>This problem cannot be solved</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can not take away a larger number from a smaller one</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Lucy are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{x}{3}-2=15
\)
Sam says you can write: \( \frac{x}{3}=17 \)
Lucy says you can write: \( x-2=45 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Lucy</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{x}{3}-2=15
\)
Emma says you can write: \( \frac{x}{3}=17 \)
Jake says you can write: \( x-2=45 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sara and Mike are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{x}{5}+3=13
\)
Sara says you can write: \( \frac{x}{5}=10 \)
Mike says you can write: \( x+3=65 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions</Misconception>

</Question>

</Question>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Lisa are discussing factors of \( \mathbf{8 x} \)
Sam says \( x \) is a factor of \( 8 x \)
Lisa says \( 4 \) is a factor of \( 8 x \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Sam</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the term factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jordan are discussing factors of \( \mathbf{8 x} \)
Alex says \( x \) is a factor of \( 8 x \)
Jordan says \( 2 \) is a factor of \( 8 x \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jordan</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes factors of algebraic terms/expressions will only be numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving multiples</Construct>
<Subject>Algebraic Proof</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following expressions is always a multiple of \( 7 \) if \( n \) is a positive integer.
</Question>
<Answer>\( n+7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding b to any integer gives a multiple of b</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving multiples</Construct>
<Subject>Algebraic Proof</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following expressions is always a multiple of \( 6 \) if \( n \) is a positive integer.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3n + 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can find the nth term based on the first term only</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving multiples</Construct>
<Subject>Algebraic Proof</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following expressions is always a multiple of \( 7 \) if \( n \) is a positive integer.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7n+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that an + b is still a multiple of a</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{8 7 . 3 4 1} \) rounded to one significant figure?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 87.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{7 8 . 9 1 2} \) rounded to one significant figure?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 70 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sarah and David are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{4x}{2} - 2 = -3\)

Sarah says a correct next line of working could be: \( 4x - 4 = -6 \)

David says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{4x}{2} = -1 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Sarah and David</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{4 x}{2}-2=-3\)

Alex says a correct next line of working could be: \( 4 x-4=-6 \)

Jamie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{4 x}{2}=-1 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph, f(x), write down the solutions to f(x) = a</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
According to the graph, what is the approximate solution to
\(x^{2}+2x-8=3\) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2+2x-8 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the y intercept when asked to read the solution to a quadratic equation from a graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph, f(x), write down the solutions to f(x) = a</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
According to the graph, what is the approximate solution to
\(x^{2}-3x-10=4\) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-3x-10 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=5, \quad x=-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Solves for y=0 instead of given y-value when reading from a quadratic graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The rectangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -2 to 6, y-axis from -4 to 5. Four points are plotted and joined to make a rectangle: (1, 2), (4, 2), (4, 4), (1, 4). Point (2, 3) is labelled with the letter "Q". The line y=3 is shown with a purple dashed line.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=1 is shown with a purple dashed line.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=1 is shown with a purple dashed line.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>

![Image of a function machine. The function is subtract 5 and the output is 10]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![Image of a function machine. The function is add 5 and the output is 12]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 17 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding an input of a function machine thinks you apply the operations given rather than the inverse operation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 154 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Makes an assumption about line segments being equal within a shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this compound shape made with rectangles? ![Compound shape made of three rectangles with the sides labelled 10 cm, 8 cm, 6 cm, and 4 cm. Two sides are unlabelled]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 480 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the area of a rectilinear compound shape, calculates the are of the surrounding rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
If I put the numbers \( 3 \) and \( 7 \) into this function machine, what comes out? ![Flow chart starting with instruction "In" inside a blue rimmed circle, then "+ 3" inside a red rimmed square, then "double" inside a red rimmed square and lastly,  "Out" inside a blue rimmed circle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 36 \) and \( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
If I put the numbers \( 3 \) and \( 8 \) into this function machine, what comes out? ![Flow chart starting with instruction "In" inside a blue rimmed circle, then "× 2" inside a red rimmed square, then "+ 3" inside a red rimmed square and lastly,  "Out" inside a blue rimmed circle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1 \) and \( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

```

</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \div (3 - 4) + 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>
```

</Question>
<Answer>\( 20-(4+8) \div 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>
