</Question>
<Answer>\( 10+(2 \times 3+4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a table of values for \( y=3x+c \) What should replace the star? ![\begin{tabular}{l|l|l|c}
\( x \) & & \( 0 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( -4 \) & \( -1 \) & ఔ
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can find missing values in a given table by treating the row as linear and adding on the difference between the first two values given.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a table of values for \( y=3 x+c \) What should replace the star? ![\begin{tabular}{l|l|l|c}
\( x \) & & \( 0 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( -4 \) & \( -1 \) & ఔ
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that a pair of coordinates can be used to find missing parts of an equation</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumed each part of a fraction diagram is worth 10%</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies when scaling up in direct proportion problems</Misconception>

Which of the following coordinates satisfies the following inequalities?
\[
y<x-1 \text{ and } y>2-x
\] ![A graph showing all 4 quadrants. x axis from -2 to 5 and y axis from -3 to 5. A red line from top left sloping downwards to bottom right, going through -1 on the x axis and -1 on the y axis. A black line going from bottom left sloping upwards to top right. Going through 2 on the x axis and -2 on the y axis]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses inequality symbols with equality</Misconception>

<Question>
\[
4 \times \square = 576
\]

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1728 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

```

4 \times \square=428
\]

</Question>
<Answer>\( 137 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem using written division (bus-stop method), does the calculation from right to left</Misconception>

The full width of the diagram is 25m, the width of the first upper step is 9m, the width of the third bottom step is 7m. The full height of the diagram is 20m, the height of the first upper step is 6m, the height of the third bottom step is 5m. The shaded section is a rectangle which starts in the top left of the second (middle) step and finishes in the bottom right of the diagram.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 150 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Answer>C</Answer>

<Construct>Write a surd in the form √a in a simplified form</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\sqrt{45}=n \sqrt{5}
\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not square root the largest square number that goes into the number under the surd before putting it in front of the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a surd in the form √a in a simplified form</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\sqrt{120}=n \sqrt{3}
\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 123 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, adds the number on the outside of the surd to the number under the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
The blue shape is rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise about \( (-2,2) \). Which shape gives the correct answer? ![A coordinate grid with 5 congruent shapes, one blue and 4 red, which are labelled A, B, C and D. The blue shape has vertices at (-3,5) (-3,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-3,3). Shape A has vertices at (-1,2) (0,2) (1,2) (0,1) (-1,1). Shape B has vertices at (0,-2) (1,-2) (1,-3) (0,-3) (-1,-3). Shape C has vertices at (-4,-2) (-3,-2) (-3,-3) (-4,-3) (-5,-3). Shape D has vertices at (-4,2) (-3,2) (-3,1) (-4,1) (-5,1).]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
The blue shape is rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise about \( (-2,2) \). Which shape gives the correct answer? ![A coordinate grid with 5 congruent shapes, one blue and 4 red, which are labelled A, B, C and D. The blue shape has vertices at (-3,5) (-3,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-3,3). Shape A has vertices at (-1,2) (0,2) (1,2) (0,1) (-1,1). Shape B has vertices at (0,-2) (1,-2) (1,-3) (0,-3) (-1,-3). Shape C has vertices at (-4,-2) (-3,-2) (-3,-3) (-4,-3) (-5,-3). Shape D has vertices at (-4,2) (-3,2) (-3,1) (-4,1) (-5,1).]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses negative and positive coordinates when working with graphs in four quadrants</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
The blue shape is rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) clockwise about \( (3,-1) \). Which shape gives the correct answer? ![A coordinate grid with 5 congruent shapes, one blue and 4 red, which are labelled A, B, C and D. The blue shape has vertices at (2,1) (2,0) (3,0) (3,-1) and (2,-1). Shape A has vertices at (5,1) (6,1) (6,0) (5,0) (4,0). Shape B has vertices at (2,-3) (2,-4) (3,-4) (3,-5) (2,-5). Shape C has vertices at (-1,1) (0,1) (0,0) (-1,0) (-2,0). Shape D has vertices at (2,3) (3,3) (3,2) (2,2) (1,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the centre of rotation is always the origin</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
x \times x \times 2 \times y \times y \times 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(xx2yy3\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can simplify a term that involves powers</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
m \times 2 \times m \times m \times h \times h
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( m 2 m^{2} h^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the commutative property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
h \times 2 \times h \times h \times k \times k
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 k k h^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can simplify a term that involves powers</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts leading zero as a significant figure</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.0 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 0.06 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Answer>Variable</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a variable with an equation</Misconception>

<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>

<Answer>Expression</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses an equation with an expression</Misconception>

<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>

<Answer>Term</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a term with an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first three terms of a sequence \( \begin{array}{llll}67 & 59 & 51 & \ldots\end{array} \) Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8n + 59 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the nth term of a descending sequence will have a positive coefficient of n</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first three terms of a sequence \( \begin{array}{llll}50 & 44 & 38 & \ldots\end{array} \) Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( -6 n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Lily are discussing the output of this \( 2 \)-step function machine input \(x\rightarrow- 5\rightarrow\) multiplied by 4\(\rightarrow\) output Sam says the output is \( \mathbf{4 x}+\mathbf{4(-5)} \)
Lily says the output is \( \mathbf{4}+\mathbf{-5} \boldsymbol{x} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Lily</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Answer>Vertical</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the notation for parallel sides</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given input find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "6" written inside it. The next rectangle has "✕3" written inside it, the next rectangle has "+2" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right is empty and has "output" written above it.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given input find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "6" written inside it. The next rectangle has "✕3" written inside it, the next rectangle has "+2" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right is empty and has "output" written above it.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 6+24 \div(3+1)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 6+18 \div(3+3)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 8+24 \div(3+3)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of division</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the line of symmetry of curves in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would \( y=(x+4)(x-2) \) belong? ![A Venn diagram with two overlapping sets. The set on the left is 'Line of symmetry at x = 3' and the set on the right is 'y intercept is negative'. A is in only  'Line of symmetry at x = 3', B is in the intersection, C is in only 'y intercept is negative' and D is outside both sets.]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the absolute values of the constants in the factorised form</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>![A 3D-shape with 2 identical octagonal faces connected by 8 rectangular faces.]()</Answer>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 100</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{9 8 9 . 9 8 9} \) rounded to the nearest hundred?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{7 4 5 . 6 7 8} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 750 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{1 2 3 . 4 5 6} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible:
\(
\frac{2x + 4}{x^2 - 4x + 20}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2x}{x^2 - 4x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that when you cancel identical terms from the numerator and denominator, they just disappear</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Nothing</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that a pictogram needs a title or question</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>Other needs to say what subject it is</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think 'other' is an acceptable category for data</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a line segment, calculate the gradient where the gradient is a negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
What is the gradient of this line? ![A set of axes with a graph drawn on. The graph passes through the points (2,4) and (0,8).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in x/change in y</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a line segment, calculate the gradient where the gradient is a negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
What is the gradient of this line? ![A set of axes with a graph drawn on. The graph passes through the points (3,5) and (1,9).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a line is given by the x intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Completing the Square Form</Subject>
<Question>
Tom wants to write the equation of the curve in the form \( y=(\boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{p})^{2}+\boldsymbol{q} \).
What is the value of \( \boldsymbol{p} \) ? ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2+4x+3 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in completed square form, the x co-ordinate of the turning point has the same sign as the constant in the brackets.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Completing the Square Form</Subject>
<Question>
Sally wants to write the equation of the curve in the form \( y=(\boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{p})^{2}+\boldsymbol{q} \).
What is the value of \( \boldsymbol{p} \) ? ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-4x+3 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In completed square form, confuses the x and y coordinates of the turning point</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>

\( 85.32 - 0.05 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 85.27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

\( 8.23 - 0.3 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7.93 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting decimals with a different number of decimal places, lines up the digits incorrectly</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "Square root" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "16" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the inverse of square rooting is doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "Square root" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "20" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the inverse of square rooting is halving</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "Square root" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "9" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding an input of a function machine thinks you apply the operations given rather than the inverse operation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles on parallel lines using corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate \( t \). ![Two parallel horizontal lines with a transversal. The lower interior angle to the right of the transversal is marked 't'. The angle to the right of the transversal and lying above the upper parallel line is marked '65'. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( t=25^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes corresponding angles sum to 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles on parallel lines using corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( t=95^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks corresponding angles sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles on parallel lines using corresponding angles</Construct>

<Misconception>Thinks corresponding angles sum to 360 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a rectangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
![A rectangle with one part shaded, labelled with dimensions 15, 7 and 10]() Which of the following calculations would correctly work out the area of the section shaded with a solid colour?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \times 15+7 \times 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts when using an area model for multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a rectangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
![A rectangle with one part shaded, labelled with dimensions 30, 15 and 10]() Which of the following calculations would correctly work out the area of the section shaded with a solid colour?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \times 20 - 15 \times 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding part of the area of a shape, subtracts from the side length before multiplying but still subtracts the unshaded area too.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret and carry out mental division using a bar model</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Sarah are discussing this bar model ![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \multicolumn{5}{|c|}{\( 240 \)} \\
\hline \( 48 \) & \( 48 \) & \( 48 \) & \( 48 \) & \( 48 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() Alex uses the bar model to write:
\[
240 \div 5=48
\] Sarah uses the bar model to write:
\[
240 \div 48=5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Only Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to use a bar model to write division facts</Misconception>

\hline \( 48 \) & \( 48 \) & \( 48 \) & \( 48 \) & \( 48 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() Mark uses the bar model to write:
\[
240 \div 5=48
\] Sarah uses the bar model to write:
\[
240 \div 48=5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Only Mark</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to use a bar model to write division facts</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret and carry out mental division using a bar model</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Jane and Mark are discussing this bar model ![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|}

\hline \( 36 \) & \( 36 \) & \( 36 \) & \( 36 \) & \( 36 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() Jane uses the bar model to write:
\[
180 \div 5=36
\] Mark uses the bar model to write:
\[
180 \div 36=5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to use a bar model to write division facts</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the outcomes of more than one event</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
These are fair spinners

How many possible outcomes are there if they are spun together and both scores are recorded? ![Two spinners. One is a four-sided spinner with 4 equal sections labelled 1, 2, 3 and 4. One is a five-sided spinner with 5 equal sections labelled 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies when using the product rule for counting</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the outcomes of more than one event</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
These are fair dice

How many possible outcomes are there if they are rolled together and both scores are recorded? ![Two dice. One is a six-sided die with sides labelled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6. One is an eight-sided die with sides labelled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses all possible outcomes with options available</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=x^{2}-4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes both solutions of a quadratic will have the same absolute value, even when the graph is not symmetrical about the y axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Frequency tables</Subject>
<Question>
Emma has recorded the number of cars each household owns in the frequency table on the right. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of cars & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} How many households did Emma record the results of?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mistakes the number of rows for the total frequency in a frequency table</Misconception>

<Question>
Sarah has recorded the number of books her classmates have read in the frequency table on the right. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of books & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} How many people did Sarah record the results of?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds up the variable column when asked for total frequency</Misconception>

</Question>

Which of these statements is false?
</Question>
<Answer>"All squares are similar"</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that all regular shapes of a certain type will be similar</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>

<Question>
What number is \( 10,000 \) more than \( 599,999 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 509,999 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 1,000 \) more than \( 7,982 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8,882 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100,000 \) more than \( 799,999 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7,999,990,000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are arguing about the answer to \( \frac{1}{4} \times 8 \)
Alex says \( \frac{1}{4} \times 8=2 \)
Jamie says \( \frac{1}{4} \times 8=\frac{8}{32} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jamie</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies both numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise graphical representations of inverse proportion in the form y = k/x</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>![A straight line from top left to bottom right, starting from above the origin]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that graphs of inverse proportion meet the axes</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise graphical representations of inverse proportion in the form y = k/x</Construct>
<Subject>Indirect (Inverse) Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following graphs is most likely to illustrate the time taken to complete a job \( (t) \) changes depending on the number of people working on it \( (p) \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A straight line from bottom left to top right, starting from the origin]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the graphs of direct and inverse proportion</Misconception>

<Question>

\[
0.05 \times 20
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a decimal less than 1 by an integer, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be</Misconception>

<Question>

\[
0.04 \times 15
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.415 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing decimals, does not realize that the order and position of the digits (relative to each other) has to remain constant.</Misconception>

<Question>
Work out:
\[
0.05 \times 20
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a decimal less than 1 by an integer, gives an answer 10 times bigger than it should be</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between ml and l</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 5000 \mathrm{ml} \) is the same as \(___\) litres
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 100 ml in a litre</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between ml and l</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 5000 \mathrm{ml} \) is the same as \(___\) litres
</Question>
<Answer>\( 500 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10ml in a litre</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between mg and kg</Construct>
<Subject>Mass Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 5000 \mathrm{mg} \) is the same as \(___\) kilograms
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5000000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent the solution to a graphical inequality involving a combination of vertical, horizontal and diagonal lines</Construct>
<Subject>Graphing Linear Inequalities (Shading Regions)</Subject>
<Question>
Which letter describes the region where \( \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{y} \leq \mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y} \geq \mathbf{1} \) ? ![Image is a set of axes with two straight lines drawn. One is x+y=3, which goes through (0,3) and (3,0). The other is y=1 which is a horizontal line going through (0,1). Letter A is in the region that is under x+y=3 and above y=1. Letter B is in the region above both lines. Letter C is in the region that is under y=1 and above x+y=3. Letter D is in the region below both lines.]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "0" above the 1st dash and "3" above the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. A red arrow is pointing to the 7th dash.]() What number is the arrow pointing to?

![A horizontal number-line with 9 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "0" above the 1st dash and "2" above the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. A red arrow is pointing to the 7th dash.]() What number is the arrow pointing to?

<Construct>Construct an angle of 60° using a ruler and a compass</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following best describes how to construct an angle of \( 60^{\circ} \) using a ruler and a pair of compasses?
</Question>
<Answer>- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Place the compass at one end of the line and draw an arc that crosses the line
- Without changing the compass width, place the compass at the point where the arc crosses the line and draw another arc
- Join the intersection of the two arcs with the original end of the line</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes constructing a perpendicular gives an angle of 60 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Liam are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
3(x-2)=15
\)
Emma says you can write: \( 3x=17 \)
Liam says you can write: \( x-2=5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>

\(

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>

<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(3 x + 2 = 5 x - 4\)

Jo says you can write: \( 3 x - 4 = 5 x \)

Paul says you can write: \( 3 x = 5 x + 4 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a reflection in a vertical line by drawing the line of reflection, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
![A grid of 8 squares across and 7 squares up.  A blue isosceles triangle, labelled "P", is drawn on the grid. Its corners are at points: 4 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 2 squares right and 3 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 2 squares right and 5 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid.   Another blue isosceles triangle (identical shape and size to P), labelled "Q", is also drawn on the grid. Its corners are at points: 6 squares right and 3 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 6 squares right and 5 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 8 squares right and 4 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid.
A light blue vertical line, labelled "A" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 2 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. A dark blue vertical line, labelled "B" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 4 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. A green vertical line, labelled "C" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 5 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. ]() Which is the correct line of reflection to map triangle \( \mathrm{P} \) to triangle \( \mathrm{Q} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a line of reflection must be touching the original shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide integers up to 2 digits using long division</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing, confuses the remainder with the quotient</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>

\[
2 x+3 y=12
\] \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

\hline\( y \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (3,-4) \) and \( (-2,5) \) She wants to use a formula.

Which formula should she use?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}, \frac{y_{1}+y_{2}}{2}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses midpoint and distance between two points</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (1,-6) \) and \( (-5,2) \) She wants to use a formula.

Which formula should she use?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the method for finding the gradient and length of a line segment</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
A bag contains some chocolate candies, some vanilla candies, and some caramel candies.

The probability of choosing a chocolate candy is \( 0.7 \).

What is the probability of choosing a vanilla candy?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that probabilities of an event occurring or not occurring must be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
A deck of cards has red cards and black cards.

The probability of drawing a red card is \( 0.6 \).

What is the probability of drawing a black card?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the probability of something not happening is 1 minus the probability of it happening</Misconception>

How many stamps does John have altogether?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 23 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Question>
The frequency table shows the grade achieved by some students in a science exam.
How many more students achieved a grade \( 4 \) than a grade \( 2 \) ? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Grade & Frequency \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores a more than question and just states one of the values</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The frequency table shows the grade achieved by some students in a maths exam.
How many more students achieved a grade \( 4 \) than a grade \( 2 \) ? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Grade & Frequency \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores a more than question and just states one of the values</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
\frac{x+2}{2}=\frac{3}{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-\frac{5}{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies the denominator instead of the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
\frac{x+2}{5}=\frac{7}{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=\frac{5}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The square is reflected in the \( y \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( A \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -3 to 3, y-axis from -3 to 3. Four points are plotted and joined to make a square: (1, 1), (1, -1), (-1, -1), (-1, 1). Point (1, 1) is labelled with the letter "A".]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (1,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( x \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 6, y-axis from -4 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 0), (4, 0), (3, 1). Point (3, 1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( x \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 6, y-axis from -4 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 0), (4, 0), (3, 1). Point (3, 1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve basic introduction simultaneous equation problems, often involving shapes and symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
![\( \begin{array}{l}\triangle \triangle \triangle \star \star=25 \\ \triangle \triangle \star \star=20\end{array} \)]() What is the value of a triangle?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide integers up to 2 digits using long division</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
When using long-division to solve this problem, what digit should replace the triangle to give the correct answer (quotient)? ![Division sum written out in Bus Stop format with dividend = 72, divisor = 9, quotient is represented by a yellow star and a purple triangle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Starts at the wrong end of the dividend when dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the inequality:
\(-\frac{2}{5} x \geq -10\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \geq 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can multiply/divide through by a negative number without changing the direction of the inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the inequality:
\(-\frac{1}{4} x \leq-8\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \geq 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing by a unit fraction is equivalent to dividing by its reciprocal</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is 1</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Vera wants to solve this equation using the quadratic formula.
\(
h^{2}+4=5 h
\)

What should replace the star? \( \frac{ \bigstar\pm \sqrt{?-?}}{?} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using the formula to solve a quadratic equation, believes that a, b and c are always taken from the 1st, 2nd and 3rd terms, respectively, of the quadratic.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is 1</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Vera wants to solve this equation using the quadratic formula.
\(
h^{2}+4=5 h
\)

What should replace the star? \( \frac{ \bigstar\pm \sqrt{?-?}}{?} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to be factorised</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify and distinguish between polygons and non-polygons</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Ben and Sarah are discussing polygons. Ben says this is a polygon: ![Square]() Sarah says this is a polygon: ![Circle]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Ben and Sarah</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a polygon can have curved sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify and distinguish between polygons and non-polygons</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack are looking at shapes. Emma says this is a polygon: ![Quadrilateral]() Jack says this is a polygon: ![Oval]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the term polygons only applies to shapes with more than 3 sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and one step is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Step \( 2 \)

Which is the correct next step rearrangement of the following formula, making \( u \) the subject?
\[
7 t-13=u(5+2 t)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( u=7 t-13-2 t \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, subtracts instead of dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and one step is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Step \( 2 \)

Which is the correct next step rearrangement of the following formula, making \( u \) the subject?
\[
7 t-13=u(5+2 t)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( u=7 t-13 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misunderstands the process of making a variable the subject of an equation</Misconception>

\( 2.3 \) hours \( = _______\) minutes
</Question>
<Answer>\( 23 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule for ascending integer linear sequences to find another term in the sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
If you know the third term of a linear sequence and you multiply it by \( 5 \), you get the \( 15^{\text {th }} \) term of that sequence.
Is this statement...
</Question>
<Answer>always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule for ascending integer linear sequences to find another term in the sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
If you know the first term of a linear sequence and you add twice the common difference to it, you get the \( 3^{\text{rd }} \) term of that sequence.
Is this statement...
</Question>
<Answer>always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the speed, calculate missing values from a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows the first \( 10 \) seconds of Mo's journey.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s.} \)

What distance should replace the star? ![A graph showing Time in seconds on the x axis and Distance in metres on the y axis. A straight line is drawn from the origin to the point (10, \(\bigstar \))]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes distance is the area under the graph on a displacement time graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the speed, calculate missing values from a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows the first \( 10 \) seconds of Mo's journey.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s.} \)

What distance should replace the star? ![A graph showing Time in seconds on the x axis and Distance in metres on the y axis. A straight line is drawn from the origin to the point (10, \(\bigstar \))]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes scales on graphs must match on both axes</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the speed, calculate missing values from a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows the first \( 15 \) seconds of Mo's journey.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s.} \)

What distance should replace the star? ![A graph showing Time in seconds on the x axis and Distance in metres on the y axis. A straight line is drawn from the origin to the point (15, \(\bigstar \))]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes distance = speed + time</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two independent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) blue marbles and \( 2 \) green marbles in a bag. ![The image shows the bag with the 5 blue marbles and 2 green marbles.]() Alex picks a green marble out and then replaces it.

He then has a second pick.
What is the probability the second pick is also a green marble?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes the item has not been replaced in a probability question where it has actually been replaced</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two independent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) green balls and \( 4 \) blue balls in a bag. ![The image shows the bag with the 5 green balls and 4 blue balls.]() Jake picks a blue ball out and then replaces it.

He then has a second pick.
What is the probability the second pick is also a blue ball?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes the item has not been replaced in a probability question where it has actually been replaced</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
![A horizontal number-line with 9 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "0" above the 1st dash and "2" above the 9th dash are the only numbers marked on the line. A red arrow is pointing to the 7th dash.]() What number is the arrow pointing to?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading decimals on a number line, assumes each dash is 0.1</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
![A horizontal number-line with 9 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "0" above the 1st dash and "2" above the 9th dash are the only numbers marked on the line. A red arrow is pointing to the 7th dash.]() What number is the arrow pointing to?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the arrow on a number line points to the middle value</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates a measurement on a diagram rather than working it out</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally ![Image showing a cartoon girl with three thought bubbles above her head. The first bubble states 'I added the whole part first 12+4=16'. The second states 'I then added the decimal part 0.3+0.5=0.8'. The third bubble states 'I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8.So 12.3+4.5=16.8']() Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 5.7+14.9 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}5+14=19 \\ 0.7+0.9=1.6 \\ 19+1.6=20.6\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding decimals, just adds the digits and ignores place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally ![Image showing a cartoon girl with three thought bubbles above her head. The first bubble states 'I added the whole part first 12+4=16'. The second states 'I then added the decimal part 0.3+0.5=0.8'. The third bubble states 'I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8.So 12.3+4.5=16.8']() Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 3.5+21.8 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}3+21=24 \\ 0.5+0.8=1.3 \\ 24+1.3=25.3\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not interpret the correct order of operations from a worded problem</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally ![Image showing a cartoon girl with three thought bubbles above her head. The first bubble states 'I added the whole part first 12+4=16'. The second states 'I then added the decimal part 0.3+0.5=0.8'. The third bubble states 'I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8.So 12.3+4.5=16.8']() Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 5.7+13.2 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}5+13=18 \\ 0.7+0.2=0.9 \\ 18+0.9=18.9\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores place value when adding a whole number and a decimal</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>

The area of this trapezium is \( 72 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \).

What is the value of \( a \) ? ![A trapezium with the parallel sides labelled with 4cm and a and the height labelled with 8cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.15 \)</Answer>

\( \frac{1}{15} \) of \( 9=? \times 9 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the denominator instead of dividing when finding a fraction of an amount</Misconception>

\( 7-(-5)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative thinks the answer must be negative</Misconception>

<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( 7-(-9)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that subtracting a negative is the same as adding it's additive inverse</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
A distance has been rounded to the nearest \( \mathrm{km} \), giving \( 106 \) \( \mathrm{km} \).
Which of these values could the distance \( \underline{not} \) be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 105220 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 1000</Construct>

A distance has been rounded to the nearest \( \mathrm{km} \), giving \( 106 \) \( \mathrm{km} \).
Which of these values could the distance \( \underline{not} \) be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 105500 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

Which of these values could the distance \( \underline{not} \) be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 105700 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible
\(
\frac{3}{m^{2}-5 m+6} \times \frac{m-2}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 m-6}{5 m^{2}-25 m+30} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise an exponential graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of an exponential function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with two curves, in the top right and bottom left quadrants. The top right curve starts up and right of the origin and travels steeply down and right, it then levels off to travel alongside the x-axis without touching it. The bottom left curve starts down and left of the origin, travels steeply up and left, it then levels off just below the x-axis without touching it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses reciprocal and exponential graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an exponential graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of an exponential function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph that starts from the bottom left, rises up to a peak, then drops down to the right.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses cubic and exponential graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an exponential graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of an exponential function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A curved graph, a symmetrical U shape. It starts in the bottom left, travels steeply up and right, turns at a point on the y-axis above the origin and travels steeply right and down.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses quadratic and exponential graphs</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 75 \) people were surveyed about the pets they own.
The results are shown in the Venn Diagram.

How many people own a dog? ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled Owns a Cat and Owns a Dog. The number 30 is in the Owns a Cat only region, 12 is in the intersection, and 18 is in the Owns a Dog only region.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the intersection on a Venn diagram represents the total of one set</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 75 \) people completed a survey about the pets they own.
The results are shown in the Venn Diagram.

How many people own a dog? ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled Owns a Cat and Owns a Dog. The number 20 is in the Owns a Cat only region, 25 is in the intersection, and 10 is in the Owns a Dog only region.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to include the intersection value when asked for total value of a set in a Venn diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Count backwards in steps of something other than one</Construct>
<Subject>Counting</Subject>
<Question>
Oliver is counting backwards in steps of \( 3 \).
He starts at the number \( 18,762 \)
what is the next number he will say?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18,761 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts on by 1, when asked to count forward/backwards in a step other than 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Count backwards in steps of of something other than one</Construct>
<Subject>Counting</Subject>

Emma is counting backwards in steps of \( 5 \).
She starts at the number \( 37,889 \)
what is the next number she will say?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 37,885 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the starting number when counting backwards</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between different factors of a number</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \) and \( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes numbers are divisible by numbers which sum to their factors</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about simplifying fractions.

Jo says you can never simplify a fraction if either the numerator or denominator is a prime number.

Paul says you will always be able to simplify a fraction if neither the numerator or denominator is prime.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes fractions with prime numerators cannot be simplified</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>

<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about simplifying fractions.

Jo says you can never simplify a fraction if either the numerator or denominator is a prime number.

Paul says you will always be able to simplify a fraction if neither the numerator or denominator is prime.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets:
\[
(x-4)(x-5)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+9x+20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding two negatives gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets:
\[
(n-4)(n-1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( n^{2}-5 n-4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
3x + 2y = 9
\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a factor of: \( 8 x^{2}+14 x \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for factors of an algebraic expression, thinks any part of a term will be a factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a factor of: \( 8 x^{2}+12 x \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for factors of an algebraic expression, thinks any part of a term will be a factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a factor of: \( 8 x^{3}+20 x^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for factors of an algebraic expression, thinks any part of a term will be a factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a cube</Construct>

<Question>
What is the volume of this cube? ![A cube with one edge labelled 6cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating volume instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a cube</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
What is the volume of this cube? ![A cube with one edge labelled 7cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 49 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds area of one face when asked for volume</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a cube</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
What is the volume of this cube? ![A cube with one edge labelled 7cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that all lengths on a cube are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The rectangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a rectangle. The rectangle has coordinates: (-1,1) (-1,-1) (1,-1) and (1,1). The point Q is the coordinate (-1,-1)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-1,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (3,3) (2,1) and (4,1). The point P is the coordinate (2,1)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (3,3) (2,1) and (4,1). The point P is the coordinate (4,1)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (4,-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects horizontally or vertically instead of across a diagonal line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When \( x^{2}+14 x+45 \) is factorised, what will appear in the box below? ![\( (x+5) \square \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+40) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, finds the sum of two values which give the non variable term in the expression rather than the product</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When \( x^{2}+10 x+24 \) is factorised, what will appear in the box below? ![\( (x+4) \square \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x-6) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from kilometers to miles</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 1 \mathrm{~km} \approx 0.6 \) miles \( 5 \mathrm{~km} \approx \square \) miles
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Added rather than multiplied by a scale factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from kilometers to miles</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 1 \mathrm{~km} \approx 0.6 \) miles \( 5 \mathrm{~km} \approx \square \) miles
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying decimals, ignores place value and just multiplies the digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
\( 30 \) people attended a local basketball game.
The pie chart shows the colors of their shirts.
How many people wore blue? ![Pie chart divided into 10 equal sections. 5 sections are blue, 3 sections are green, and 2 sections are red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes fraction rather than fraction of amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
\( 32 \) people attended a school function.
The pie chart shows the types of drinks they chose.
How many people chose soda? ![Pie chart divided into 8 equal sections. 3 sections are water, 2 sections are soda, 2 sections are juice, and 1 section is tea.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the unit fraction when asked to find a non-unit fraction of an amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
\( 32 \) people attended a local basketball game.
The pie chart shows the types of drinks they bought.
How many people bought soda? ![Pie chart divided into 8 equal sections. 3 sections are soda, 3 sections are water, 1 section is juice, and 1 section is coffee.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives number of sections of pie chart rather than the amount it represents</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\[
\text { When } k=15 \text { and } m=3
\]

Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}k(m+2)=63 \\ k(2+m)=-63\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise addition is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\[
\text { When } m=8 \text { and } n=3
\]

Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}m(n+1)=35 \\ m(1+n)=27\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise addition is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\[
\text { When } p=6 \text { and } q=3
\]

Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}p(q+1)=15 \\ p(1+q)=21\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise addition is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A compound shape making an upside down T shape where there is a rectangle across the bottom and a rectangle attached above this, slightly to the left of the centre. The full width across the bottom is 16m, the partial width on the left is 2m, the partial width on the top block is 7m. The full height on the right is 9m, the partial height on the left is 3m. The shaded section is the right hand rectangle from the right edge up to where the top rectangle begins.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 56 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses an incorrect side length when splitting a composite shape into parts</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>

The full width across the bottom is 14m, the partial width on the left is 4m, the partial width on the top block is 6m. The full height on the right is 10m, the partial height on the left is 5m. The shaded section is the right hand rectangle from the right edge up to where the top rectangle begins.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A compound shape making an upside down T shape where there is a rectangle across the bottom and a rectangle attached above this, slightly to the left of the centre. The full width across the bottom is 16m, the partial width on the left is 2m, the partial width on the top block is 7m. The full height on the right is 9m, the partial height on the left is 3m. The shaded section is the right hand rectangle from the right edge up to where the top rectangle begins.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the area of a rectangle is calculated by length add width</Misconception>

\( 85372 \)\[ {\color{blue}\square} \]\( 85327 \)\[ {\color{orange}\square} \]\( 83527 \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A blue box containing a "greater than" symbol  and an orange box containing a "less than" symbol]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>
