<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{6 x}{3}=18
\)

Emma says a correct next line of working could be: \( 6 x=6 \)
Jake says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{3}=3 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{7 x}{3}=21
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 7 x=7 \)
Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{3}=3 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides both the numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete a sample space diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
These spinners are spun and the two scores are added together.

Bob records the results in a sample space diagram.
How many cells would contain a score of \( 4 \) ? ![Two 6-sided spinners. Both spinners are split into 6 equal sections with the numbers 1, 3, 3, 5, 5, and 5 in them.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline & \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \)  \\
\hline \( 3 \)  \\
\hline \( 5 \)\\
\hline \( 5 \)  \\
\hline \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to consider all possible outcomes</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Convert \( \frac{3}{10} \) into a decimal
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.33 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a fraction means dividing the denominator by the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Convert \( \frac{3}{50} \) into a decimal
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Convert \( \frac{3}{10} \) into a decimal
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify congruence in shapes other than triangles</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Alex are discussing congruent shapes. Who is correct? Emma says these two shapes are congruent ![An image of two squares. The squares are the same shape and size but have different orientations.]() Alex says these two shapes are congruent ![An image of two squares. A big one and a small one.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify congruence in shapes other than triangles</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Mike and Sarah are discussing congruent shapes. Who is correct? Mike says these two shapes are congruent ![An image of two squares. The squares are the same shape and size but have different orientations.]() Sarah says these two shapes are congruent ![An image of two squares. A big one and a small one.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Mike and Sarah</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify congruence in shapes other than triangles</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
John and Mary are discussing congruent shapes. Who is correct? John says these two shapes are congruent ![An image of two squares. The squares are the same shape but have different sizes.]() Mary says these two shapes are congruent ![An image of two squares. One is rotated 90 degrees from the other, but they are the same size and shape.]()
</Question>
<Answer>John is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that shapes are congruent if they have the same size and shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the properties of an isosceles triangle to find missing lengths</Construct>
<Subject>Perimeter</Subject>
<Question>
What is the difference between the perimeters of these two shapes? ![Blue rectangle with base length 10cm and side length 6cm]() ![Green, isosceles triangle with base length 7cm and side length 12cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the properties of an isosceles triangle to find missing lengths</Construct>
<Subject>Perimeter</Subject>
<Question>
What is the difference between the perimeters of these two shapes? ![Green rectangle with base length 10cm and side length 7cm]() ![Blue, isosceles triangle with base length 6cm and side length 15cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 42 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the properties of an isosceles triangle to find missing lengths</Construct>
<Subject>Perimeter</Subject>
<Question>
What is the difference between the perimeters of these two shapes? ![Green square with side length 8cm]() ![Blue, isosceles triangle with base length 10cm and side length 12cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 64 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts when asked to find the difference</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle from a description of the properties</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
A triangle has the following angles: \( 90\degree, 50\degree, 40\degree \)
Tom says the triangle is right-angled
Katie says the triangle is isosceles
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that base angles in an isosceles are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle from a description of the properties</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
A triangle has the following angles: \( 95\degree, 45\degree, 40\degree \)
Tom says the triangle is right-angled
Katie says the triangle is isosceles
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Tom is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that a right angle is 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Jack and Jill are trying to calculate the answer to \( 22 \times 9 \)
Jack does this: \( 20 \times 9 + 2 \times 9 \)
Jill does this: \( 10 \times 9 + 12 \times 9 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}+5 q
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q-5)(q+1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}+6 q
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q+3)(q+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Use prime factor decomposition to find the Lowest Common Multiple of two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Here is the completed Venn diagram from earlier in the quiz.
What calculation works out the lowest common multiple of \( 48 \) and \( 72 \) ? ![A Venn diagram showing the Prime factors of 48 set and the Prime factors of 72 set. There is a 2 in the prime factors of 48 set, there is 2, 2, 3, 3 in the intersection and there is a 2 in the prime factors of 72 set.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the calculations for HCF and LCM</Misconception>

<Construct>Use prime factor decomposition to find the Lowest Common Multiple of two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Here is the completed Venn diagram from earlier in the quiz.
What calculation works out the lowest common multiple of \( 45 \) and \( 60 \) ? ![A Venn diagram showing the Prime factors of 45 set and the Prime factors of 60 set. There is a 3, 3 in the prime factors of 45 set, there is a 2 in the intersection and there is a 2, 5 in the prime factors of 60 set.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>forgets to include the common factors when calculating the lowest common multiple</Misconception>

<Construct>Can read Roman numerals between 100 and 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is this CCXXIV?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 326 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the value of a number given in roman numerals, adds the value of all letters together without considering the position of the letter.</Misconception>

<Question>
What number is this CCXLIX?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 269 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the value of a number given in roman numerals, adds the value of all letters together without considering the position of the letter.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square root of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing the table of values for \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{x}^{2} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Jo says the star could be \( 81 \).
Paul says the star could be \( -3 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Squares when asked to find the square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>

<Question>
Write \( 0.15 \) as a percentage.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 150 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders</Misconception>

<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
Write \( 0.25 \) as a percentage.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.25 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to just add a % sign to a decimal to convert to a percentage</Misconception>

\[
y=2 x
\] ![A table with two rows and two columns. The top left box has 'x', top right has a star, the bottom left box has 'y', bottom right has '4'. ]() What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up the value of two terms when substituting</Misconception>

\[

\] ![A table with two rows and two columns. The top left box has 'x', top right has a star, the bottom left box has 'y', bottom right has '3'. ]() What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds too early in calculation</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>

<Question>
What is the first cube number greater than \( 200 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 207 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know what a cube number is</Misconception>

<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first cube number greater than \( 500 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 529 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up square numbers and cube numbers</Misconception>

<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first cube number greater than \( 120 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 126 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes cube numbers are just multiples of 3</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators involve linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible: \( \frac{3}{x+1} \times \frac{x+2}{4} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{12}{(x+1)(x+2)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>when multiplying fractions multiplies by the reciprocal of the 2nd fraction instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators involve linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible: \( \frac{3}{x-2} \times \frac{x^{2}}{4 y} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 x^{2}}{x-8 y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators involve linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible: \( \frac{3}{x-2} \times \frac{x^{2}}{4 y} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 x^{2}}{4 x y-2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify and count the faces, vertices and edges of a 3D shape</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the terms faces and edges</Misconception>

<Construct>Write the next term of an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the next term of this linear sequence?
\[
4,12,20,28, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 29 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the next term in the sequence adds one to the last term given, despite the sequence not going up in ones.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( (6+3)^{2}= \)
Problem Q: \( 6+3^{2}= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 6+3 \)
Problem Q: \( 6+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( (7+3)^{2}= \)
Problem Q: \( 7+3^{2}= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 3^{2} \)
Problem Q: \( 3^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(8x - 5 = 3x + 5\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(x = 0\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a number divided by itself equals 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(8x + 5 = 3x + 10\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x = 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x = 3 \)</Answer>

\hline Pets & Frequency & Pets \( \times \) Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} The table shows the numbers of pets in the households of students in a class.

What does the "10" represent?

\begin{Answer}The total number of pets in the \( 2 \) households</Answer>

\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 10 \) \\

\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) \\

</Question>
<Answer>The mean number of cars in the \( 5 \) households</Answer>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a negative quadratic, work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of the curve? ![A negative quadratic graph that crosses the x-axis at (-5,0) and (1,0).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+5)(x+1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a positive x squared coefficient in a quadratic equation results in an n shaped graph</Misconception>

His car is parked in the basement on level \( -3 \).

How many floors does Jamie need to go down to get from the office to his car?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the starting number when counting backwards</Misconception>

<Construct>Count backwards through zero starting from a positive integer</Construct>

![A number line going from -8 up to 7]() Raj's apartment is on level \( 5 \).
His package is delivered to the basement on level \( -3 \).

How many floors does Raj need to go down to get from the apartment to the package?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the difference between a positive number and a negative number is equal to the positive number</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally "\( 46+20 \) is equal to \( 66 \). Then I am going to add on the \( 8\). \(66+8=74 \)" Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 37+56 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}37+60=97 \\ 97+6=103\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally "\( 46+20 \) is equal to \( 66 \). Then I am going to add on the \( 8\). \(66+8=74 \)" Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 37+56 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}30+50=80 \\ 7+6=13 \\ 80+13=93\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally "\( 46+20 \) is equal to \( 66 \). Then I am going to add on the \( 8\). \(66+8=74 \)" Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 29+47 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}9+40=49 \\ 20+49=69 \\ 69+7=76\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean shoe size? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Shoe Size \( (\mathrm{s}) \) & Frequency \( (f) \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>B \( \quad 4.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is total divided by sum of categories given</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>

\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>C \( \quad \mathbf{1 . 5 0} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is total frequency divided by sum of categories given</Misconception>

\hline
\end{tabular}

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
Paige, Kaci and David want to find the area of the school playground. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape making an L shape. The full width across the bottom is 9m, the partial width on the top is 5m. The full height on the left is 10m, the partial height on the right is 6m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Paige: \( 10 \times 9 + 5 \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
Sam, Lily and Max want to find the area of the park. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape making an L shape. The full width across the bottom is 12m, the partial width on the top is 7m. The full height on the left is 15m, the partial height on the right is 8m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Lily: \( 15 \times 7 + 12 \times 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Sophie is organising a charity hot dog sale.
There are \( 18 \) bread rolls in each packet.
There are \( 15 \) hot dogs in each packet.
Sophie buys exactly the same number of bread rolls as hot dogs.
What is the smallest number of each packet that Sophie can buy?

To solve this problem you need to work out the \( ___ \) of \( 18 \) and \( 15 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Product</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word "product"</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Highest Common Factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
John is planning a school trip.
There are \( 24 \) students in each bus.
There are \( 30 \) students in each class.
John wants to fill the buses completely with students from whole classes.
What is the largest number of students that can be in each bus?

To solve this problem you need to work out the \( ___ \) of \( 24 \) and \( 30 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Sum</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word "sum"</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Alex is planning a sports event.
There are \( 12 \) bottles of water in each case.
There are \( 20 \) energy bars in each box.
Alex wants to buy an equal number of bottles of water and energy bars.
What is the smallest number of each case and box that Alex can buy?

To solve this problem you need to work out the \( ___ \) of \( 12 \) and \( 20 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Highest Common Factor</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the use of LCM and HCF in real life examples</Misconception>

Katie</Answer>

<Construct>Solve problems involving subtracting a period of time from a given end time</Construct>

<Question>

<Answer>\( 11: 15 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Solve problems involving subtracting a period of time from a given end time</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
What time is \( 15 \) minutes before midnight?
</Question>
<Answer>11:45 am</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that times just before midnight are "am" times</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first five terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llllll}2 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 10 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first five terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llllll}2 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 10 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>Double the term number</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes nth term rule can be given in words</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Number line with -10 and -2 marked on it. From the -10 there is an arrow to the right labelled +6. Then there is an arrow pointing to the left labelled c and ending at -2.]() What is the value of \( c \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the starting number when counting backwards</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving negative decimals</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{4 x}{2}-2=-3.6\)

Emma says a correct next line of working could be: \( 4 x-2=-7.2 \)

Jake says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{4 x}{2}=-1.6 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate: \( \frac{1}{4} \times \frac{1}{5} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate: \( \frac{1}{4} \times \frac{1}{5} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate: \( \frac{1}{5} \times \frac{1}{4} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, multiplies the numerator and adds the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>

<Question>
Which shape has rotational symmetry order \( 4 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Rectangle]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks rectangles have rotational symmetry or order 4</Misconception>

<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
Which shape has rotational symmetry order \( 3 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Rectangle]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
Which shape has rotational symmetry order \( 3 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Square]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not connect rotational symmetry to number of sides/vertices</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.06 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Upper and Lower Bounds</Subject>
<Question>
Round \( 0.0348 \) to \( 1 \) significant figure
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.03 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Upper and Lower Bounds</Subject>
<Question>
Round \( 0.842 \) to \( 1 \) significant figure
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Change an integer base number to another integer base number with a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing powers.
Emma says \( 3^{4}=9^{2} \)
Jake says \( 3^{4}=27^{1} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Change an integer base number to another integer base number with a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
James and Emily are debating about powers.
James says \( 3^{4}=9^{2} \)
Emily says \( 3^{4}=27^{1} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks powers with different bases cannot be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>

<Question>
Multiply out the brackets:
\[
(x-3)(x-4)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+7x+12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding two negatives gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>

Multiply out the brackets:
\[
(x-3)(x-4)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-7x-12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Lucas are arguing about the solution to this inequality:
\[
15 \leq 5n
\]

Emma says \( n \) could be \( 4 \)

Lucas says \( n \) could be \( 2 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Lucas</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Liam are arguing about the solution to this inequality:
\[
15 \leq 5 n
\]

Emma says \( n \) could be \( 3 \)

Liam says \( n \) could be \( 4 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When using inequality notation, thinks "greater than/less than or equal to" symbols are instead the "greater than/less than" symbols and vice versa</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( x(x+3) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3x+3x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise multiplying a variable by itself results in a power of that variable</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( x(x-3) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the following triangles have the same area as this square? ![A square with side of 6]()
</Question>
<Answer>![A right-angled triangle with base of 6 and height of 6]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a scalene triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following triangles have the same area as this rectangle? ![A rectangle with height of 5 and width of 10]()
</Question>
<Answer>![A right angled triangle with base of 5, perpendicular height of 10 and hypotenuse of root 125]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following triangles have the same area as this square? ![A square with side length of 6]()
</Question>
<Answer>All the triangles with a base of 6 and a height of 6</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a triangle</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 16 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
12-4+3
\]
Emma and Lucas are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 5 \).
Emma says you can write it like this: \( 12-(4+3) \)
Lucas says you can leave it like this: \( 12-4+3 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
7-4+3
\]
Alice and Bob are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 6 \).
Alice says you can write it like this: \( 7-(4+3) \)
Bob says you can leave it like this: \( 7-4+3 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Alice and Bob</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
12 \div 3 \times 4
\]
Emma and Jack are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 16 \).
Emma says you can write it like this: \( 12 \div (3 \times 4) \)
Jack says you can leave it like this: \( 12 \div 3 \times 4 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Emma is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Given an equation, form or identify related equations</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing this equation:
\[
a+b=8
\] Emma uses the equation to write:
\[
2a+2b=16
\] Jake uses the equation to write:
\[
a+3b=24
\] Who has written a related linear equation?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Given an equation, form or identify related equations</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Lucas are discussing this equation:
\[
a+b=8
\] Emma uses the equation to write:
\[
2a+2b=16
\] Lucas uses the equation to write:
\[
a+3b=24
\] Who has written a related linear equation?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Lucas</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Given an equation, form or identify related equations</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Maria and John are discussing this equation:
\[
a+b=10
\] Maria uses the equation to write:
\[
2a+2b=20
\] John uses the equation to write:
\[
a+3b=30
\] Who has written a related linear equation?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to create a multiple of an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(
y=x^{2}
\) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -10 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(
y=x^{2}
\) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Perform calculations with temperature when given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement about the temperatures \( -3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and \( 1^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
hotter than
\[
-3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Perform calculations with temperature when given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement about the temperatures \( -3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and \( 4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) colder than
\[
-3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up colder and hotter when comparing temperatures</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
15-3 \times 4+2=
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
12 + 4 \div 2 - 3 \times 5 =
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 + 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
15 + 3 \times 4 - 2 =
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>It doesn't matter: you get the same answer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between cm³ and l</Construct>

<Question>
\( 300000 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \) is the same as ______ litres
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks 1l = 10 000 cubic centimetres</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between cm³ and l</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 300000 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \) is the same as ______ litres
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks 1l = 100 cubic centimetres</Misconception>

2 x - 5
\)

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
3x + 7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3x7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
x + 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes addition of terms and powers of terms are equivalent e.g. a + c = a^c</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines of symmetry must be vertical or horizontal</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 270° and 360°</Construct>

<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The inner scale goes from 0 to 360 anti-clockwise. The angle is a reflex angle that is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the protractor, anti-clockwise to the red line that is half way between 290 and 300 (inner scale) and halfway between 270 and 260 (outer scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 265^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The inner scale goes from 0 to 360 anti-clockwise. The angle is a reflex angle that is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the protractor, anti-clockwise to the red line that is half way between 280 and 290 (inner scale) and halfway between 260 and 250 (outer scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 285^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Correct scale but wrong value on protractor reading.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify acute angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
This angle is... ![An image of an angle that is larger than 90 degrees but smaller than 180 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Acute</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify obtuse angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
This angle is... ![An image of an angle that is larger than 90 degrees but smaller than 180 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>A right angle</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (0,1) (0,3) and (-3,2). The point P is the coordinate (0,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (0,1) (0,3) and (-3,2). The point P is the coordinate (0,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects horizontally or vertically instead of across a diagonal line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (0,1) (0,3) and (-3,2). The point P is the coordinate (0,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects horizontally or vertically instead of across a diagonal line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "-2" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "9" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative</Misconception>

```
<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "-3" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "7" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is multiplication</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = 0</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is a graph of
\(y=2-0.5 x\) ![A set of axes with y=2-0.5x drawn on.]() Use the graph to solve
\(2-0.5 x=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution of mx + c = 0 is x =0</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = 0</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is a graph of
\(y=2-0.5 x\) ![A set of axes with y=2-0.5x drawn on.]() Use the graph to solve
\(2-0.5 x=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they solve mx + c = 0 by substituting in x = 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = 0</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is a graph of
\(y=2-0.5 x\) ![A set of axes with y=2-0.5x drawn on.]() Use the graph to solve
\(2-0.5 x=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution of mx + c = 0 is x = m</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which number line represents \( -2 < x \leq 4 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Number line with numbers from -5 to 5. Above the -2 is an open, unfilled circle with an arrow to the right. Above the 4 is a blue, filled circle with an arrow to the left.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which number line represents \( -2 < x \leq 4 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Number line with numbers from -5 to 5. Above the -2 is a green, filled circle and above the 4 is an open, unfilled circle. The two circles are joined by a horizontal line.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

```

<Question>
Expand:
\[
4(x-2)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4x-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
4(x-2)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x-8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
4(x-2)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4x - 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When expanding brackets, multiplies out the first term correctly but adds together the number outside the bracket with the second term inside the bracket.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "2n - 4" written inside it. The middle rectangle has "✕ 3" written inside it and the final rectangle is empty and has "output" written above it.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2n - 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "2n + 3" written inside it. The middle rectangle has "✕ 3" written inside it and the final rectangle is empty and has "output" written above it.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\(6n + 3\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "4n + 2" written inside it. The middle rectangle has "✕ 3" written inside it and the final rectangle is empty and has "output" written above it.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12n+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Emily wants to subtract \( 299 \) from a number.
Which one of the following methods would give her the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( +300 \) then \( +1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Answer>\( -300 \) then \( -1 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Dogs & Frequency & Dogs \( \times \) Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 10 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 7 \) & \( 14 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} The table shows the numbers of dogs in the households of students in a class.

What does the "14" represent?
</Question>
<Answer>The mean number of dogs in the \( 7 \) households</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the interpretation of the fx column in a frequency table</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Pets & Frequency & Pets \( \times \) Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 10 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 7 \) & \( 14 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} The table shows the numbers of pets in the households of students in a class.

What does the "14" represent?
</Question>
<Answer>The total number of pets in the \( 2 \) households</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the variable and frequency columns in a frequency table</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Radius</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses diameter and radius</Misconception>

The straight line shown in this diagram is a ....? ![A circle with a line across from edge to edge, passing through the centre]()
</Question>
<Answer>Arc</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses arc and diameter</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a chord</Construct>

<Question>
The straight line shown in this diagram is a ....? ![A circle with a line across from edge to edge, passing through the centre]()

<Answer>Circumference</Answer>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
What is the ratio of cats to dogs? ![cats dogs]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2: 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing ratio from diagram, writes total as one side</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
What is the ratio of apples to oranges? ![apples oranges]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing fraction from diagram, writes total as denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Bar Graph</Subject>

<Answer>\( \frac{40}{50} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing fraction from diagram, writes total as denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about rounding.

Jo says \( \mathbf{9 8 . 7 6} \) rounded to \( 1 \) significant figure is \( \mathbf{1 0 0} \)

Paul says \( \mathbf{9 8 . 7 6} \) rounded to \( 1 \) decimal place is \( \mathbf{1 0 0} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>When rounding to decimal places and the only digits after the decimal point will be zeros, just gives the integer as the answer.</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing rearranging \( t=\sqrt{u+9} \) to make \( u \) the subject
Tom says a correct first line of working could be: \( t=\sqrt{u}+3 \)
Katie says a correct first line of working could be: \( t^{2}=u+9 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing rearranging \( y=\sqrt{x+4} \) to make \( x \) the subject
Alex says a correct first line of working could be: \( y=\sqrt{x}+2 \)
Jamie says a correct first line of working could be: \( y^{2}=x+4 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Alex and Jamie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.6 \div 3= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.6 \div 3 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.02 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a decimal by an integer, divides by the wrong power of 10 when reinserting the decimal.</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.7 \div 3 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[y=2 x^{2}\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0.5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[y=2 x^{2}\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0.4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>

\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying decimals, divides by the wrong power of 10 when reinserting the decimal</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>

\( 98765 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When rounding up from a 9, does not add one on to the digit to the left</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 86420 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 80000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to three or more decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 17.84923 \) rounded to \( 3 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 17.84 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to three or more decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 15.67842 \) rounded to \( 3 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15.679 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to three or more decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 15.67892 \) rounded to \( 3 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15.779 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values</Misconception>

\(
3 h^{2}-10 h+4=0
\)

What should replace the circle? \( \frac{? \pm \sqrt{?-?}}{\bigcirc} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1</Construct>

\(
3 h^{2}-10 h+4=0
\)

What should replace the circle? \( \frac{? \pm \sqrt{?-?}}{\bigcirc} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a variable next to a number means addition rather than multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Sam has \( 36 \) apples to distribute evenly among his classmates.
To determine the possible numbers of classmates Sam could distribute the apples to without any leftovers, Sam needs to know the ___ of \( 36 \)
</Question>
<Answer>digits</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise when to find a factor from a worded question</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Jacob has \( 36 \) books to distribute equally among his classmates.
To determine the possible numbers of classmates Jacob could give books to without any books left over, Jacob needs to know the ___ of \( 36 \)
</Question>
<Answer>multiples</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses factors and multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Jack has \( 36 \) apples to distribute equally among his friends.
To determine the possible numbers of friends Jack could give the apples to without any apples left over, Jack needs to know the ___ of \( 36 \)
</Question>
<Answer>reciprocal</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise when to find a factor from a worded question</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 25 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

Number of Spots & Frequency \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.16(1 \mathrm{dp}) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is total frequency divided by sum of categories given</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 20 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
Number of Spots & Frequency \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes mean is total divided by number of groups</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 20 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

Number of Spots & Frequency \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.4(1 \mathrm{dp}) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![Positive coordinate grid from 0 to 5 in the x and y directions with a gold star at (1,4) and a purple triangle at (4,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \) squares right,
\( 2 \) squares down</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![Positive coordinate grid from 0 to 5 in the x and y directions with a gold star at (1,4) and a purple triangle at (4,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \) square down,
\( 3 \) squares right</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, identifies the correct number of jumps but mixes up the directions.</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When factorising \( x^{2}+5 x+6 \) we need two numbers that:
</Question>
<Answer>Add to give \( 5 x \) and multiply to give \( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, believes the sum of the two values in the brackets equals bx rather than b</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When factorising \( x^{2}+5 x+6 \) we need two numbers that:
</Question>
<Answer>Add to give \( 6 \) and multiply to give \( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify and represent sets using set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
Emily and Ben are discussing the probability spinner

Emily says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{1,2\} \)

Ben says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{1,1,1,2,2\} \)

Who do you agree with? ![Circle divided into 5 equal sections. 3 sections labelled with a blue number 1. 2 sections labelled with a red number 2.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Ben</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a sample space should show repeated outcomes, not just unique possible outcomes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( C=\pi d \) ![A circle with diameter labelled d.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Equation</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a formula with an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( C=\pi d \) ![A circle with diameter labelled d.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Variable</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a variable with a formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( C=2\pi r \) ![A circle with radius labelled r.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Expression</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a formula with an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 100</Construct>

<Answer>\( 900 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Determine if a given point lies on a line</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about points on the line
\[
y=3x+2
\]

Tom says \( (4,14) \) lies on the line \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{2} \)

Katie says \( (-4,-10) \) lies on the line \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{2} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtracting a positive number from a negative number makes the answer less negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) &
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( 3 x+ y = 12 \)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 36 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) &   
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( 5 x+3 y=15 \)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes 0 multiplied by a number gives the number</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) &   
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( 3 x+4 y=18 \)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up the value of two terms when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute a solution back into the remaining equation and find the second solution</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is halfway through solving a pair of simultaneous equations, one of which is below.

\(
3j - 2k = -6
\)

Isaac found that \( k = 4 \)
What does \( j \) equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( j = 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a negative by a positive gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute a solution back into the remaining equation and find the second solution</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is halfway through solving a pair of simultaneous equations, one of which is below.

\(
3x - 2y = 14
\)

Emma found that \( y = -5 \)
What does \( x \) equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x = 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative signs when adding positive and negative numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute a solution back into the remaining equation and find the second solution</Construct>

<Question>

\(

\)

Isaac found that \( y = 5 \)
What does \( x \) equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x = 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are arguing about factorising. Emma says \( x^{2}-4x-5 \equiv(x-5)(x+1) \)
Jake says \( x^{2}+4x+5 \equiv(x+5)(x+1) \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this sequence. ![The first 3 patterns in a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a blue rectangle with 6 yellow circles attached to its perimeter: 2 circles on each of the longer sides and 1 circle on each of the shorter sides.
Pattern 2 is made up of 2 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 10 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to the other rectangle).
Pattern 3 is made up of 3 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 14 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to another rectangle).]() Tom says the number of circles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be
double the number of circles in the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term.

Katie says the number of rectangles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be
double the number of rectangles in the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term.

Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is a multiplicative relationship between values of terms in a linear sequence e.g. 10th term is double 5th term</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Liam and Sarah are discussing the data below.

Liam says there are \( 8 \) times as many children as adults.

Sarah says one in nine people are adults.
Who is correct? At a community event, the ratio of adults to children is:
adults : children
\(
1: 8
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Only Liam</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Lily are arguing about the information on the right.

Sam says there are \( 7 \) times as many cats as dogs.

Lily says one in eight animals are dogs.
Who is correct? In a pet adoption center, the ratio of dogs to cats is:
dogs : cats
\(
1: 7
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Only Lily</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in a ratio 1:n that one part of the ratio would be n times bigger than the one part</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are arguing about the information on the right.

Emma says there are \( 7 \) times as many cats as dogs.

Jake says one in eight animals are dogs.
Who is correct? At the animal shelter, the ratio of dogs to cats is:
dogs : cats
\(
1: 7
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n</Misconception>

<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=4 \), what is the value of \( x_{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9.9756 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+3)^{2}-4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can square root a negative number</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Completing the Square Form</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+3)^{2}+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in completed square form, the x co-ordinate of the turning point has the same sign as the constant in the brackets.</Misconception>

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=3 x-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of parallel and perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify perpendicular lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>

\[
y=3 x+2 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=3 y+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes switching the x and y variables in a linear equation gives a perpendicular line</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify perpendicular lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is perpendicular to
\[
y=3 x+2 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=\frac{1}{3} x+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradients of perpendicular lines are reciprocals of the same sign</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Only Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes rounding numbers down would give an overestimate</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when a square root is a surd and when it is not</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{50} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a surd will simplify to a whole number and not longer be a surd if the number under the surd is a square number</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 705 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the next term</Misconception>

\begin{tabular}{lclclclc|c|} \hline \(\bigstar\) & \( \;\) & 850 & \( \;\) &  \( \;\)\end{tabular} A descending linear sequence has a constant difference of \( 15 \) and the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term is \( 850 \).
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 835 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you subtract rather than add when finding the previous term in a descending linear sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how much a block of ice melted over time. ![A line graph with the x-axis titled "Time (minutes)". The x-axis scale is labelled from 0 to 5 in steps of 1 minute.
The y-axis is titled "Water depth (cm)" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 12 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0, 0),(1,1),(2, 3),(3, 6),(4, 9),(5, 10).
]() What was the difference between the first minute and third minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include units in answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>

The y-axis is titled "Temperature (°C)" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 30 in steps of 5. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0, 10),(1, 15),(2, 20),(3, 25),(4, 28),(5, 30).
]() What was the difference between the first hour and third hour?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \mathrm{°C} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the command word 'difference'</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>

The y-axis is titled "Water depth (cm)" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 12 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0, 0),(1,1),(2, 3),(3, 6),(4, 9),(5, 10).
]() What was the difference between the first minute and third minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>
