<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving non-linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following by collecting like terms. \( \frac{3}{4} x^{2}+\frac{1}{8} x^{2}-\frac{1}{4} x^{2}+\frac{3}{8} x^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{4} x^{2}+x^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think that a variable with no coefficient has a coefficient of 1.</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
4, \quad 1, \quad 3, \quad 2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>

<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
5, \quad 1, \quad 3, \quad 7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Question>
This table shows the heights of players on a basketball team.

What is the modal height? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Height & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 6'0" \) & \( 6 \) & \\
\hline \( 6'2" \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline \( 6'4" \) & \( 4 \) & \\
\hline \( 6'6" \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6'2" \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the median instead of the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the number of books each student read over the summer.

What is the modal number of books read? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Number of Books & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 5 \) & \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) & \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mode is the frequency rather than the value/group</Misconception>

<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.

What is the modal age? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 5 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 4 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when identifying the mode you look at all values, not just frequencies, for the highest number</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{r}\quad46 \\ \times 33 \\ \hline\end{array} \) What number will be in the ones/units column of the final answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has treated this like an addition problem and added the ones column.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{r}\quad45 \\ \times 33 \\ \hline\end{array} \) What number will be in the ones/units column of the final answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has written the value of the 'ones' column as the answer, without using the numbers in the question.</Misconception>

</Question>

<Construct>Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence given by this rule:
\[
5 n+2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the nth term of a linear sequence, thinks the the first term is the coefficient in front of n.</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence given by this rule:
\[
5n + 2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the first term in a sequence is the term before the sequence begins (0th term)</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{4 x+2}{4} \div \frac{16 x^{2}-4}{16} \\
= & \frac{4 x+2}{4} \times \frac{16}{16 x^{2}-4} \\
= & \frac{4 x+2}{4} \times \frac{16}{(4 x-1)(4 x+2)}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{16}{16 x-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only applies a division to one of multiple terms in a numerator when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Question>
STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{2 x+3}{4} \div \frac{4 x^{2}-9}{8} \\
= & \frac{2 x+3}{4} \times \frac{8}{4 x^{2}-9} \\
= & \frac{2 x+3}{4} \times \frac{8}{(2 x-3)(2 x+3)}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2(2 x+3)}{(2 x-3)(2 x+3)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying an algebraic fraction, only looks for number factors</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{4 x+2}{4} \div \frac{16 x^{2}-4}{16} \\
= & \frac{4 x+2}{4} \times \frac{16}{16 x^{2}-4} \\
= & \frac{4 x+2}{4} \times \frac{16}{(4 x-1)(4 x+1)}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{4 x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom wants to estimate the answer to this calculation by rounding each number to \( 1 \) significant figure.

\[
62.9 \times 0.483
\]

What number should replace \( \mathbf{6 2 . 9} \) in his estimation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 62 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounded to wrong degree of accuracy (2sf not 1sf)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Julie wants to estimate the answer to this calculation by rounding each number to \( 1 \) significant figure.

\[
45.6 \times 0.285
\]

What number should replace \( \mathbf{4 5 . 6} \) in her estimation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 46 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation</Construct>

\[

\]

What number should replace \( \mathbf{9 2 . 6} \) in her estimation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}+7q+12
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q+4)(q+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
x^{2}+7x+10
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+5)(x+2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Emily share some money in the ratio \( 4: 9 \)

Tom receives \( £ 100 \).

How much money does Emily receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 75 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, treats that as the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack share some money in the ratio \( 4: 9 \)

Emma receives \( £ 64 \).

How much money does Jack receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds one part of a ratio but doesn't multiply that by the number of parts needed</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack share some money in the ratio \( 2: 5 \)

Emma receives \( £ 60 \).

How much money does Jack receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the depths below sea level of \( 3 \) creatures:
Clam: \( -3.1 m \)
Octopus: \( -2.7 m \)
Oyster: \( -1.9 m \)
Arrange their depths in ascending order, starting with the deepest
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{\text {st }} \) Octopus
\( 2^{\text {nd }} \) Clam
\( 3^{\text {rd }} \) Oyster</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the more digits a number has the greater it is, regardless of place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the depths below sea level of \( 3 \) creatures:
Shark: \( -3.2 m \)
Squid: \( -8 m \)
Eel: \( -2.1 \mathrm{~m} \)
Arrange their depths in ascending order, starting with the deepest
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}1^{\text {st }} \text { Eel } \\ 2^{\text {nd }} \text { Shark } \\ 3^{\text {rd }} \text { Squid }\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (2,-5) \) and \( (-7,1) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (2, & -5) & (-7, & 1)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the first bracket equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-7)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number from a positive number, uses a method which assumes one of the negative signs can be ignored</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (2,-5) \) and \( (-7,1) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (2, & -5) & (-7, & 1)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the first bracket equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-5)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean of this set of data?
\[
7, \quad 4, \quad 4, \quad 6, \quad 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the mode</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the mean of this set of data?
\[
4, \quad 1, \quad 0, \quad 1, \quad 2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\(a \Rightarrow +3  \Rightarrow \times2\Rightarrow 2a+3\)

\(a \Rightarrow +3  \Rightarrow \times2\Rightarrow 2(a+3)\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\(a \Rightarrow +3  \Rightarrow \times4\Rightarrow 4a+3\)

\(a \Rightarrow +3  \Rightarrow \times4\Rightarrow 4(a+3)\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>

\(a \Rightarrow \times4  \Rightarrow +3\Rightarrow 4(a+3)\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

\)

What should replace the star?

<Answer>\( \tan (\theta) \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Lucas are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}4 x+3 y=12 \\ 2 x-3 y=6\end{array} \) Emma says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Lucas says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts simultaneous equations when addition is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}4 x+3 y=23 \\ 2 x-3 y=5\end{array} \) Emma says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Jake says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations thinks that identical terms in given equations can be eliminated by either adding or subtracting.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the whole amount, given a fraction of the amount</Construct>

What is \( \frac{1}{10} \) of \( B \) ? ![A pink rounded rectangle with a capital B typed inside]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the part and the whole in fraction of an amount problems</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the part and the whole in fraction of an amount problems</Misconception>

Here is a number card
\( \frac{1}{5} \) of \( B \) is \( 20 \)
What is \( \frac{1}{10} \) of \( B \) ? ![A pink rounded rectangle with a capital B typed inside]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In a worded problem, does not complete all calculations</Misconception>

<Construct>Count a number of objects</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1,4,9,16, \ldots \text { ? }
\]

Which pattern matches the sequence above?
</Question>
<Answer>![A sequence represented using red circles arranged in a pattern so that the first term has one red dot and then an additional three dots are added underneath this one red dot for the second term. For the third term another three red dots are added underneath and for the fourth term, three more added underneath the previous pattern.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise a positive integer to a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about powers.
\( m \) and \( n \) are integers

Tom says there is no value of \( m \) that means \( 3^{m} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Katie says there is no value of \( n \) that means \( 7^{n} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise a positive integer to a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about powers.
\( m \) and \( n \) are integers

Tom says there is no value of \( m \) that means \( 3^{m} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Katie says there is no value of \( n \) that means \( 7^{n} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise a positive integer to a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about powers.
\( m \) and \( n \) are integers

Tom says there is no value of \( m \) that means \( 3^{m} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Katie says there is no value of \( n \) that means \( 7^{n} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Tom is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Use direct proportion to solve unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)</Construct>
<Subject>Direct Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Five apples cost \( £ 2.50 \).

How much does one apple cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 12.50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies up without finding unit price in proportion question</Misconception>

<Construct>Use direct proportion to solve unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)</Construct>
<Subject>Direct Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Eight apples cost \( £ 4.80 \).

How much does one apple cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 4.72 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts rather than dividing to find unit price</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is greater than 100</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 150 \% \) of \( 30 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Found the percentage but forgot to add to 100%</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is greater than 100</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 150 \% \) of \( 40 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 190 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Added the values together instead of finding the percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is greater than 100</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 150 \% \) of \( 75 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>You cannot have percentages greater than \( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that you can have percentages greater than 100%</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division problems involving two negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-4) \div(-2)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a negative by a negative gives a negative answer</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Calculate a positive fractional gradient between two coordinates where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Max is working out the gradient between these two points. He has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the gradient? ![A coordinate grid with a right angled triangle drawn on it. The hypotenuse of the triangle is between the coordinates (2,3) and (5,6). The base of the triangle is labelled with 3 and the perpendicular height of the triangle is labelled with 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient is the difference between the change in x and the change in y</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Calculate a positive fractional gradient between two coordinates where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Max is working out the gradient between these two points. He has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the gradient? ![A coordinate grid with a right angled triangle drawn on it. The hypotenuse of the triangle is between the coordinates (2,3) and (8,6). The base of the triangle is labelled with 6 and the perpendicular height of the triangle is labelled with 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in x/change in y</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate a positive fractional gradient between two coordinates where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is working out the gradient between these two points. She has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the gradient? ![A coordinate grid with a right angled triangle drawn on it. The hypotenuse of the triangle is between the coordinates (2,3) and (8,6). The base of the triangle is labelled with 6 and the perpendicular height of the triangle is labelled with 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in y multiplied by change in x</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these quadratic equations will give no real solutions.
Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-8 \pm \sqrt{24}}{-4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the discriminant must be a perfect square for an equation to have real solutions</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these quadratic equations will give no real solutions.
Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-6 \pm \sqrt{1200}}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the discriminant must be a perfect square for an equation to have real solutions</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these quadratic equations will give no real solutions.
Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-8 \pm \sqrt{0}}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a discriminant of 0 means there are no real solutions</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 3" written inside the next rectangle, "−4" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3q − 4" written inside it.
The first function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 3" written inside the next rectangle, "−4" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3(q − 4)" written inside it.
]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 3" written inside the next rectangle, "−2" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3q − 2" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "−2" written inside the next rectangle, "✕ 3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3(q − 2)" written inside it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "−4" written inside the next rectangle, "÷ 2" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(q − 4)" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has  "−4" written inside the next rectangle, "÷ 2"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "(q − 4) ÷ 2" written inside it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the whole amount given a percentage of the amount mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star? ![A number line from 0% to 100% with 30% labelled with 60 and a star above the 100%]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the wrong part of a fraction model as the whole</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify whether two shapes are similar or not</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
John and Sarah are discussing similarity. Who is correct? John says these two squares are similar ![Two squares of different sizes. One square has side 3cm. The other square has side 9cm. ]() Sarah says these two squares are similar ![Two squares of different sizes. One square has side 4cm. The other square has side 8cm. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only John</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that similar shapes sides must all have the same scale factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify whether two shapes are similar or not</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
James and Lily are discussing similarity. Who is correct? James says these two squares are similar ![Two squares of different sizes. One square has a side length of 3cm. The other square has a side length of 6cm. ]() Lily says these two squares are similar ![Two squares of different sizes. One square has a side length of 4cm. The other square has a side length of 7cm. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Lily</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks adding the same value to each side makes shapes similar</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify whether two shapes are similar or not</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing similarity. Who is correct? Tom says these two triangles are similar ![Two triangles of different sizes. One triangle has sides 3cm, 4cm, and 5cm. The other triangle has sides 6cm, 8cm, and 12cm. ]() Katie says these two triangles are similar ![Two triangles of different sizes. One triangle has sides 5cm, 6cm, and 7cm. The other triangle has sides 10cm, 12cm, and 16cm. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that similar shapes sides must all have the same scale factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between cm and m</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
How should you write \( 3 \) kilometres and \( 9 \) centimetres in metres?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3009 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly converted cm to m</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between km and m</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
How should you write \( 8 \) kilometres and \( 3 \) centimetres in metres?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8003 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has forgotten to convert cm to m</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between mm and km</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
How should you write \( 3 \) kilometres and \( 4 \) millimetres in metres?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3004 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly converted mm to m</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( x(3x-5) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4x-5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( x(3x - 5) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3x^2 - 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( x(3x - 5) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4x - 5x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you add the terms together when multiplying like terms.</Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.5 + 0.3 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding decimals, just adds the digits and ignores place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals with the same number of decimals places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.7+0.4= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding, just writes the digit to the right of the number without considering place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals with the same number of decimals places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.5 + 0.7 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during addition of decimals, does not carry across decimal point to preceding digit.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify and count the faces, vertices and edges of a 3D shape</Construct>
<Subject>Names and Properties of 3D Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
How many faces does this shape have? ![\( \theta \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the terms faces and edges</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 40 \) and \( 30 \)</Answer>

<Construct>For a given input find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine Input \( \longrightarrow \times 3 \longrightarrow+2 \quad \longrightarrow \) Output What is the output when the input is \( 7 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given input find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine Input \( \longrightarrow +3 \longrightarrow \times 4 \quad \longrightarrow \) Output What is the output when the input is \( 7 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given input find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine Input \( \longrightarrow \times 3 \longrightarrow-2 \quad \longrightarrow \) Output What is the output when the input is \( 8 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In a function machine, confuses the first operation and the input</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct way to set up this problem to solve it using long multiplication?
\[
345 \times 12
\]
</Question>
<Answer>![345 multiplied by 12 set out to perform long multiplication. 12 is written under 345. The 1 of 12 is under the 3 of 345 and the 2 of 12 is under the 4 of 345.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Hasn't lined up the place value columns when writing out the calculation</Misconception>
```

```
<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct way to set up this problem to solve it using long multiplication?
\[
157 \times 34
\]
</Question>
<Answer>![157 multiplied by 34 set out to perform long multiplication. 157 is written in 3 columns with 100 in the first column, 50 in the second column and 7 in the third column. 34 is written underneath this, with 30 under 50 and 4 under 7.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Has partitioned the digits when doing long multiplication</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Find missing angles on parallel lines using more than one angle fact</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Jane is trying to find the angles \( x \) and \( y \). Here are her workings. Which step is incorrect? ![A diagram showing parallel lines and two transversals. Some angles are given and one is labelled x]()
</Question>
<Answer>\[
x=103\degree\]
as alternate angles</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of alternate</Misconception>

John is trying to find the angles \( a \) and \( b \). Here are his workings. Which step is incorrect? ![A diagram showing parallel lines and two transversals. Some angles are given and one is labelled a]()
</Question>
<Answer>\[
b=70\degree
\]
as alternate angles</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of alternate</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles on parallel lines using more than one angle fact</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
John is trying to find the angles \( x \) and \( y \). Here are his workings. Which step is incorrect? ![A diagram showing parallel lines and two transversals. Some angles are given and one is labelled x]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both steps are incorrect</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of alternate</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as a single fraction, giving your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{6 x^{2}-6 x-60}{12} \times \frac{3}{x-5} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x^{2}-x-10}{x-5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying an algebraic fraction, only looks for number factors</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify where negative non-integers lie on a number line</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a number line: ![A horizontal number-line with 13 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. The 1st dash is labelled with "-6", the 3rd dash is labelled "-4", the 5th dash is labelled "-2", the 7th dash is labelled "0", the 9th dash is labelled "2", the 11th dash is labelled "4" and the 13th dash is labelled "6"    A red arrow, labelled with a question mark is pointing halfway between the 5th and 6th dashes. ]() Which of the following numbers could be indicated by the arrow?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts on in the wrong direction on a number line</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify where negative non-integers lie on a number line</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a number line: ![A horizontal number-line with 13 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. The 1st dash is labelled with "-6", the 3rd dash is labelled "-4", the 5th dash is labelled "-2", the 7th dash is labelled "0", the 9th dash is labelled "2", the 11th dash is labelled "4" and the 13th dash is labelled "6"    A red arrow, labelled with a question mark is pointing halfway between the 5th and 6th dashes. ]() Which of the following numbers could be indicated by the arrow?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a quarter of 2 is 0.25</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +7 going from -4 up to 3]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4+3=7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative number can be replaced with its positive equivalent when answering an addition problem from a numberline</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +4 going from -2 up to 2]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2+4=-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes we move down a number line when we add</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +8 going from -2 up to 6]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2+6=8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the number of jumps between two numbers on a numberline represents the sum of those 2 numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Use facts about interior angles in triangles with algebra to solve equations</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Find the value of \( x \). ![A triangle with the angles labelled: 3x, x + 10 and 5x - 20]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=80^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes angles in a triangle sum to 360 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Use facts about interior angles in triangles with algebra to solve equations</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Find the value of \( x \). ![A triangle with the angles labelled: 3x, 2x + 15 and x + 30]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=45^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Kai says the following:

"It doesn't matter if you do \( \mathbf{5} \div \mathbf{2 0} \) or \( \mathbf{2 0} \div \mathbf{5} \), you get the same answer"

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Kai is correct because division is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Miran says the following:

"It doesn't matter if you do \( \mathbf{7} \div \mathbf{140} \) or \( \mathbf{140} \div \mathbf{7} \), you get the same answer"

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is incorrect because division is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Miran says the following:

"It doesn't matter if you do \( \mathbf{7} \div \mathbf{1 4 0} \) or \( \mathbf{1 4 0} \div \mathbf{7} \), you get the same answer"

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is correct because division is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of area</Construct>
<Subject>Area Units</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and John are discussing units of area
Emma says inches is a unit of area
John says \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) is a unit of area
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know units of area should be squared</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of area</Construct>
<Subject>Area Units</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Ben are discussing units of area
Emma says inches is a unit of area
Ben says \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) is a unit of area
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Ben</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know units of area should be squared</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of area</Construct>
<Subject>Area Units</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing units of area
Emma says inches is a unit of area
Jake says \( \mathrm{km}^{2} \) is a unit of area
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know units of area should be squared</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve comparison, sum and difference problems using information presented in pictograms</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
This pictogram shows the different types of books Jane has in her library.

How many more Mystery books does Jane have than Science Fiction books? ![A pictogram showing the number of books Jane has in her library. Mystery has 4 and a half symbols, Science Fiction has 3 symbols, Fantasy has 2 and a quarter symbols, Romance has 4 symbols, and History has 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 5 books.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When counting partial symbols on pictogram, uses the fraction rather than the amount it represents</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve comparison, sum and difference problems using information presented in pictograms</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
This pictogram shows the different types of music Bob has in his music collection.

How many more Pop CDs does Bob have than Rock CDs? ![A pictogram showing the number of CDs Bob has in his musical collection. Pop has 3 and a half symbols, rock has 2 symbols, blues has 2 and a quarter symbols, jazz has 3 and a quarter symbols and classical has 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 4 CDs.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

\(
(-9)+5=
\square\)

\(
(-8)+5=
\square\)

<Construct>Given a positive y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form y = c - x</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
y=4-x
\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate unit fractions of an amount</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{5} \) th of an hour \( = _______ \) minutes
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square ABCE with various triangles attached to it.  The marked angle is between the lines AC and BC.]()
</Question>
<Answer>BAC</Answer>
<Misconception>Chooses the wrong 3 letters to describe an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square PQRS with various triangles attached to it. The marked angle is between the lines RS and QR.]()
</Question>
<Answer>SQR</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives 3-letter angle notation in the wrong order</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of triangle DEF with various angles. The marked angle is between the lines DE and DF.]()
</Question>
<Answer>None of these options</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks 3-letter angle notation has to use the nearest vertex on each side of the angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following: \( \frac{12 x^{3}}{8 x^{2}+4 x} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{12 x^{2}}{8 x+4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not fully simplify fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following: \( \frac{12 x^{2}}{4 x + 8} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 x}{1 + 2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following: \( \frac{12 x^{4}}{8 x^{3}+4 x^{2}} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 x^{4}}{2 x^{3}+4 x^{2}} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of rectilinear shapes by counting squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What can you say about the areas of the two rectangles? ![Two rectangles drawn on a grid. The blue rectangle is four grid squares wide and two grid squares long. The red rectangle is drawn diagonally, so that each side goes through three grid squares from corner to corner.]()
</Question>
<Answer>The red rectangle has a larger area</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts half-squares as full squares when calculating area on a square grid</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of rectilinear shapes by counting squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What can you say about the areas of the two squares? ![Two squares drawn on a grid. The green square is four grid squares wide, and four grid squares long. The yellow square is drawn diagonally, so that each side goes through three grid squares from corner to corner.]()
</Question>
<Answer>The areas are the same</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the diagonal of a square is the same length as the side of the square</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of rectilinear shapes by counting squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What can you say about the areas of the two rectangles? ![Two rectangles drawn on a grid. The green rectangle is four grid squares wide and two grid squares long. The yellow rectangle is drawn diagonally, so that each side goes through three grid squares from corner to corner.]()
</Question>
<Answer>It is impossible to say without measuring</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find area by counting squares on a grid</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 13 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Convert percentages containing 1 decimal place to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
How do you write \( 0.25 \% \) as a fraction?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes that converting a decimal percentage to a fraction, they can just convert the decimal to a fraction, instead of writing the decimal over 100.</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert percentages containing 1 decimal place to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
How do you write \( 0.2 \% \) as a fraction?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{50} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes decimal point can be ignored when given a decimal percentage to convert to a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Emily completes the square, what should replace the star? \( q^{2}+6q+2 \equiv(q \bigstar )^{2} \triangle \)
</Question>
<Answer>\(\bigstar =3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is double the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Beth completes the square, what should replace the star? \( q^{2}+q-2 \equiv(q \bigstar )^{2} \triangle \)
</Question>
<Answer>\(\bigstar =1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>A pentagon</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses octagon and pentagon</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the number of sides of a polygon identify the name</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>A pentagon</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses pentagon and hexagon</Misconception>

<Answer>A triangle</Answer>

<Construct>Use area to write algebraic expressions</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{3}+5=12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (2,-5) \) and \( (-7,1) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (2, & -5) & (-7, & 1)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) \( \sqrt{(-9)^{2}+(6)^{2}} \) What is the distance between the points?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\sqrt{45} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( A=\pi r^{2} \) ![A circle, with the dimension labelled r]()
</Question>
<Answer>Equation</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a formula with an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( A=\pi r^{2} \) ![A circle with the radius labelled r]()
</Question>
<Answer>Variable</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a variable with a formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( A=\pi r^{2} \) ![A circle with the dimension labelled r]()
</Question>
<Answer>Expression</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a formula with an expression</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( v \) the subject
\(F=\frac{v^{2}}{r}\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( v=r F^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( x \) the subject
\(y = \frac{x^2}{z}\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(x = \frac{y}{z}\)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( v \) the subject
\(F=\frac{v^{2}}{r}\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( v=r \sqrt{F} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between m and km</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
How many kilometres are there in \( 1 \) metre?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.001 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 1000 metres in 1 km.</Misconception>

<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
How many metres are there in \( 1 \) kilometre?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 100m in a kilometre</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between km and m</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
How many metres are there in \( 1 \) kilometre?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1000000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 1000mm in a centimetre</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Jason and Emily are discussing the order of operations
Jason says: \( 8+6-4 \equiv 6-4+8 \)
Emily says: \( 8+6 \times 4 \equiv 8 \times 6+4 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the measure of an interior angle in a triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
James and Lily are discussing triangles.
James says a triangle can have two obtuse angles.
Lily says only an isosceles triangle can have an obtuse angle.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only James</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not consider that all three angles in a triangle sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in a right-angled triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about triangles.
Sam says a triangle can have two right angles.
Lily says only a scalene triangle can have a right angle.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Lily</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of an isosceles triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing calculations involving brackets
Tom says \( 3(x+y) \equiv (x+y) \times 3 \)
Katie says \( 3(x+y) \equiv 3x+y \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack are discussing calculations involving brackets
Emma says \( 3(x+y) \equiv (x+y) \times 3 \)
Jack says \( 3(x+y) \equiv 3x+y \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the identity symbol</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of B? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-5" below the 1st dash and "4" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "B" is pointing halfway between the 4th and 5th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -6.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When placing a negative number on a number line student assumes numbers with a greater absolute value are placed to the right.</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 2</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 10 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they double the numerator to turn a fraction into a percentage</Misconception>

<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6,8,10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given a term to term sequence with multiple steps, applies one step per term</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -1, 1, 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given a term to term sequence with multiple steps, applies one step per term</Misconception>

<Question>
![Square and then add \( 2 \)]() The first three terms of which sequence below is produced by this term-to-term rule?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2,4,6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Describes term to term rules using position to term rules</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 6 \) blue balls and \( 3 \) green balls in a bag ![A bag with 6 blue and 3 green balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Sam picks out two balls at the same time.

What is the probability that at least one ball is blue?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{18}{36} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not work out all possibilites when given an 'at least' question in probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 6 \) green balls and \( 3 \) blue balls in a bag ![A bag with 6 green and 3 blue balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Mark picks out two balls at the same time.

What is the probability at least one ball is green?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{36}{63} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they can just give the probability of the first event for a combined probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Emma thinks: When dividing two distinct numbers, \( A \) and \( B \), the result is the same regardless of the order. \( A \div B = B \div A \) Is Emma's thought...
</Question>
<Answer>Always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Sophia makes a conjecture: If you have two different numbers, \( A \) and \( B \), the order you divide does not matter. \( A \div B=B \div A \) Is Sophia's conjecture...
</Question>
<Answer>Sometimes true</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is sometimes commutative</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations? Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
-4 p+3 q=10 \\
2 p-3 q=6
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
-4 p-3 q=10 \\
2 p+3 q=6
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are different, we subtract the equations.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how much a block of ice melted over time. ![Chart of water depth (cm) against time (minutes)]() What was the difference between the third minute and fifth minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include units in answer.</Misconception>

<Question>
This graph shows the temperature change over time. ![Temperature (°C) vs Time (hours)]() What was the difference between the third hour and fifth hour?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the command word 'difference'</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how much a block of ice melted over time. ![Chart of water depth (cm) against time (minutes)]() What was the difference between the third minute and fifth minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used the wrong data point on the graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out multiplication problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
James is expanding these two brackets.

What should he get when he multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (x-5)(x-3). The arrows are pointing at the -5 in the first bracket and the -3 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out multiplication problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
James is expanding these two brackets.

What should he get when he multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (x-8)(x-2). The arrows are pointing at the -8 in the first bracket and the -2 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to one decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
\( 236.4928 \) to \( 1 \) decimal place is.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 236.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to one decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
\( 237.684 \) to \( 1 \) decimal place is.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 238.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values</Misconception>

\( 237.843 \) to \( 1 \) decimal place is.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 238.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between m and km</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 5000 m \) is the same as ____ \(km\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 500 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10m in a km</Misconception>

<Subject>Weight Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 500 g \) is the same as ____ \(kg\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between cm and m</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 400 cm \) is the same as ____ \(m\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 100 cm in a m</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with point A marked at (3,3) and point B marked at (-2,-2)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{A} \) to point \( \mathrm{B} \).
</Question>
<Answer>Left \( 6 \) squares, down \( 6 \) squares</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, miscounts when crossing an axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with point X marked at (1,3) and point Y marked at (4,1)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{X} \) to point \( \mathrm{Y} \).
</Question>
<Answer>Down \( 2 \) squares, left \( 3 \) squares</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with point P marked at (1,3) and point Q marked at (-2,0)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{P} \) to point \( \mathrm{Q} \).
</Question>
<Answer>Left \( 3 \) squares, down \( 3 \) squares</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, identifies the correct number of jumps but mixes up the directions.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 54321 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5,432,100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 35721 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35,821 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 37903 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 37,003 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall the correct formula to calculate the length of a non-hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle in a 2D Pythagoras questions</Construct>
<Subject>2D Pythagoras</Subject>
<Question>
A right-angled triangle has sides a, b, and \( c \) as shown.

Choose the formula for finding side a. ![Right-angled triangle with height a, base b and hypotenuse c.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( a = \sqrt{c^2 - b^2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write \( \textbf{twenty thirds} \) as a mixed number fraction.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting from an improper fraction to a mixed number, adds on the part left to make the whole, rather than subtracting it</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write \( \textbf{twenty thirds} \) as a mixed number fraction.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes the numerator of an improper fraction as the number of wholes when converting to a mixed number</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>

<Question>
Write \( \textbf{twenty thirds} \) as a mixed number fraction.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{20}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confused mixed numbers with improper fractions</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.31 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing all values of the fraction after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these statements show that \( \mathrm{x} \) is greater than \( 5 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses inequality symbols with equality</Misconception>

\)

<Answer>\( 5.2 \% \)</Answer>

<Question>
Emma's trip to the park is \( 2 \) hours and \( 45 \) minutes.
Sophia's trip to the park is \( 186 \) minutes.
What is the difference in their trips in minutes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 42 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from hours to minutes</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Hannah's journey to camp is \( 3 \) hours and \( 26 \) minutes.
Tori's journey to camp is \( 204 \) minutes.
What is the difference in their journeys in minutes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 410 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find the length of a line segment from coordinates</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|c|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 4 \) &  \( \ \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\)
\end{tabular}

This is a table of values for \( x+2 y=8 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
x^{2}+7x+10
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+4)(x+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
q^{2}+7 q+6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (q+2)(q+5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the coefficent of x in an expanded quadratic comes from multiplying the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

Katie says a vertex of the square could be \( (1,5) \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a coordinate cannot be placed beyond the bounds of the grid shown</Misconception>

<Construct>Can calculate missing coordinates in a geometric shape</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with a line segment from (1,3) to (4,0)]() The line segment is one side of a square.

Alice says a vertex of the square could be \( (5,-3) \).

Bob says a vertex of the square could be \( (0,6) \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that if the horizontal and vertical measurements of a diagonal line segment switch it remains the same size</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
The graph shows information about the temperature, \( T \)°C, of a heating cup of coffee \( t \) minutes after being poured.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \[t=5\]? ![A graph showing time in minutes on the x axis and temperature in degrees Celsius on the y axis. A curve is shown with a tangent to the curve drawn in at (5,70). The tangent also passes through the point (0,80)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 70 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the difference between a value on a graph and the gradient of a graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
The graph shows information about the temperature, \( T \mathrm{~^\circ C} \), of a cup of coffee \( t \) minutes after being poured.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \[t=5\]? ![A graph showing time in minutes on the x axis and temperature in degrees Celsius on the y axis. A curve is shown with a tangent to the curve drawn in at (5,70). The tangent also passes through the point (0,80)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in x/change in y</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
The graph shows information about the velocity, \( v \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), of a parachutist \( t \) seconds after leaving a plane.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \[t=8\]? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and velocity in metres per second on the y axis. A curve is shown with a tangent to the curve drawn in at (8,51). The tangent also passes through the point (0,40)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.375 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise visual representations of division times table facts</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
![Five groups of four dots]() Jo says the diagram above represents
\[
4 \div 20=5
\]
Paul says the diagram represents \( 5 \times 4=20 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\(y= x^{2}+6x+3 \)

Write in the form
\( (x+a)^{2}+b \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+3)^{2}+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b = the original constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\(y= x^{2}+6x+3 \)

Write in the form
\( (x+a)^{2}+b \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+6)^{2}+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\(y= x^{2}+6x+3 \)

Write in the form
\( (x+a)^{2}+b \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+3)^{2}-9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b = -a^2 regardless of the original constant</Misconception>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.7419 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving negative integers</Construct>

<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
-8=q+3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( q=-11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>

<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(15x - 7 = 3x + 8\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a number divided by itself equals 0</Misconception>

Solve the equation:
\(15x - 7 = 8x + 14\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x = 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

\(15x + 3 = 3x + 12\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=\frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>

What is the ratio for how much they have read to how much they have yet to read? ![An image of a book]()
</Question>
<Answer>1:7</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Emily and Sarah are reading a book. They stop with one fourth left to read.

What is the ratio for how much they have read to how much they have yet to read? ![An image of a book]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4: 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses the denominator when converting from fractions to ratio, rather than numerator.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
The sum of angle \( a \) and \( b \) would be... ![A straight line split into two angles, a and b.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes angles on a straight line add to 100 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
