<Construct>Convert from days to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 1 \) day?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converted hours to minutes instead of hours to seconds</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from days to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 1 \) day?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \times 60 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 12 hours in 1 day</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to three or more significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{3 . 0 0 6 7 1 0} \) rounded to three significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.007 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to three or more significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{3.6942} \) rounded to three significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.69 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to three or more significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{3 . 7 4 9 2 0} \) rounded to three significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.00 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A surveyor wants to make a pie chart of their findings. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & Frequency & Degrees \\
\hline Trees & \( 20 \) & \( 200 \) \\
\hline Shrubs & \( 8 \) & \( 80 \) \\
\hline Flowers & \( 15 \) & \( \mathrm{~F} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which one of these is a correct method for finding F?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 360-200+80 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include brackets when required</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A baker wants to make a pie chart of cake sales. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & Frequency & Degrees \\
\hline Chocolate & \( 20 \) & \( 216 \) \\
\hline Vanilla & \( 8 \) & \( 86 \) \\
\hline Strawberry & \( 15 \) & \( \mathrm{~F} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which one of these is a correct method for finding F?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{15}{28} \times 360 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes to find the proportion of a pie chart sector you do frequency/sum of other frequencies rather than frequency/overall total</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A baker wants to make a pie chart of his sales. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & Frequency & Degrees \\
\hline Cupcakes & \( 20 \) & \( 200 \) \\
\hline Cookies & \( 5 \) & \( 50 \) \\
\hline Muffins & \( 15 \) & \( \mathrm{~F} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which one of these is a correct method for finding F?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{360}{40} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the degrees for 1 person rather than the required number of people for a pie chart sector</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
An isosceles triangle must have ...
</Question>
<Answer>all different side lengths.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and scalene triangles</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
An isosceles triangle must have ...
</Question>
<Answer>one pair of parallel sides.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word parallel</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
An isosceles triangle must have ...
</Question>
<Answer>three equal sides.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and equilateral triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 7, y-axis from -2 to 8. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 4), (4, 4), (2, 7). Point (4, 4) is labelled with the letter "Q". The line y=4 is shown with a blue dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (4,5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The square is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 7, y-axis from -2 to 8. Four points are plotted and joined to make a square: (1, 3), (1, 5), (3, 5), (3, 3). Point (1, 5) is labelled with the letter "Q". The line y=5 is shown with a blue dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (1,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 7, y-axis from -2 to 8. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 4), (4, 4), (2, 7). Point (2, 4) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=4 is shown with a blue dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,-4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects in an axis, instead of the given mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
y=4 x
\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
y=4 x
\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>There is no possible solution</Answer>
<Misconception>Doesn't believe that when you divide by 0 the answer will always be 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where at least one value is negative and at least one is a non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two points and their midpoint.
What should replace the triangle? ![The image is a set of axes with three points marked. One point is (2,5). The midpoint is (-1, 0.5). The third point is given as (star, triangle), so the triangle is the y value of the point.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \Delta=-5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Given a line segment with a midpoint that is not the origin, assumes that the two end points will still have the same absolute value</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where at least one value is negative and at least one is a non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two points and their midpoint.
What should replace the triangle? ![The image is a set of axes with three points marked. One point is (2,-3). The midpoint is (0, 1.5). The third point is given as (star, triangle), so the triangle is the y value of the point.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \Delta=-4.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes midpoint calculation is just half of the difference</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand products of three binomials in the form (x + a)(x + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Triple Brackets and more</Subject>
<Question>
Ori is expanding these three brackets:
\(
(x+2)(x-4)(x-7)
\)

He finds it helpful to split the first bracket and view the problem as follows:
\(
x(x-4)(x-7)+2(x-4)(x-7)
\)

He expands the brackets further. Before he simplifies, what are the terms than contain an \( x^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}+7 x^{2} \\ +4 x^{2} \\ +2 x^{2}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Emma is keeping track of her savings. She saves \( 5 \) dollars every day for \( 20 \) days.
How much money did Emma save in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \div 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Sara is tracking her reading progress. She read \( 5 \) pages every day for \( 28 \) days.
How many pages did she read in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 28-5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts rather than multiplies when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Sarah is counting the number of pages she read. She read \( 4 \) pages every day for \( 20 \) days.
How many pages did she read in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4+20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies when asked for a total</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What fraction replaces the question mark? ![A bar split into 3 equal parts, with one shaded. The shaded part is labelled with a question mark.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the wrong part of a fraction model as the whole</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation should you do first?
\(
((0.8 \div(0.3+0.5)-0.4) \times 0.7)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.8 \div 0.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation should you do first?
\(
((0.8 \div(0.1+0.3)-0.2) \times 0.5)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.2 \times 0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
8 \times 4-3+5
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 28 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \times 4-(3+5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs subtraction in wrong order</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
8 \times 4-2+3
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 21 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \times(4-2+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
8 \div 2 + 4 \times 3
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 16 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Does not need brackets</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) blue balls and \( 2 \) green balls in a bag ![A bag with 5 blue and 2 green balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() John picks out three balls at the same time.

He wants to work out the probability all the balls are blue.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies for combined probabilities</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) blue marbles and \( 2 \) green marbles in a bag ![A bag with 5 blue and 2 green marbles in it. All of the marbles are the same size.]() John picks out three marbles at the same time.

He wants to work out the probability all the marbles are blue.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 125 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that choosing 2 items at once means the first item does not get replaced in a probability question</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) blue balls and \( 2 \) green balls in a bowl ![A bowl with 5 blue and 2 green balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Mark picks out three balls at the same time.

He wants to work out the probability all the balls are blue.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies for combined probabilities</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}b\rightarrow\times 2\rightarrow-5\rightarrow5-2 b \\ b\rightarrow \times 2\rightarrow-5\rightarrow2(5-b)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}b\rightarrow+2 \rightarrow\times 5\rightarrow2+5 b \\ b \rightarrow\times 5\rightarrow+2\rightarrow-5(2+b)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}b\rightarrow+2 \rightarrow\times 5\rightarrow5(2+b) \\ b\rightarrow\times 5\rightarrow+2\rightarrow2(5b)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify common multiples of three or more numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following numbers is a common multiple of \( 5, 10 \) and \( 15 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses factors and multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify common multiples of three or more numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following numbers is a common multiple of \( 3,4 \) and \( 6 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies a common multiple of two numbers when asked to consider a common multiple of three numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify common multiples of three or more numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following numbers is a common multiple of \( 3,5 \) and \( 15 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies a multiple of a number but not a common multiple of a group of numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( \fbox{-5} \) x\( \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{4} = \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{-12} - \hspace{0.2cm}\fbox{ ? } \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( \fbox{-3} \) x\( \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{7} = \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{-15} - \hspace{0.2cm}\fbox{ ? } \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiplication, division and power law of indices with positive integer powers</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\(\frac{\left(3^{4}\right)^{3}}{3^{2}} \equiv 3^{n}\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a power raised to a power leads to addition of the powers</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiplication, division and power law of indices with positive integer powers</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\(\frac{\left(3^{4}\right)^{2}}{3^{3}} \equiv 3^{n}\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when dividing numbers with the same base you divide the powers, rather than subtracting</Misconception>

<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=4 \), what is the solution to \( x=10-\frac{1}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9.90 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=4 \), what is the solution to \( x=10-\frac{1}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9.75 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes substituting the starting value into an iteration formula immediately gives the solution</Misconception>

<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=4 \), what is the solution to \( x=10-\frac{1}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9.9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (significant figures rather than decimal places)</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
      & Multiple of \( 5 \) & Not a multiple of \( 5 \) \\
\hline Factor of \( 40 \) & A & B \\
\hline Not a factor of \( 40 \) & C & D \\
\hline
\end{tabular} In which box should you place \( \mathbf{2 5} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>D</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the term factor</Misconception>

Which of these always produces consecutive numbers if \( n \) is a positive integer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( n, n+2, n+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of consecutive</Misconception>

</Question>

<Misconception>Mixes up square rooting and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
The pie chart shows the favourite subjects of children at a school.

If \( 15 \) students chose Mathematics, how many chose English? ![A pie chart split into four parts, labelled with school subjects. The part for Mathematics is 144 degrees, Science is 36 degrees, English is 72 degrees and French is 108 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 72 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the angle in a pie chart sector is equal to the frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
3, \quad 6, \quad 18, \quad 54 \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you add \( 3 \) to the previous term</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
3, \quad 8, \quad 23, \quad 68 \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you double the previous term and add \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
3, \quad 10, \quad 31, \quad 100 \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you square the previous term and add \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Lisa shares some money with her sister in the ratio \( 3: 2 \). If Lisa gets \( £150 \), how much does her sister get?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, treats that as the total</Misconception>

```

</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, treats that as the total</Misconception>
```

</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 240 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, uses that as one part in ratio without dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 3 \) blue balls and \( 2 \) green balls in a bag ![A bag with 3 blue and 2 green balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Alex picks a green ball out and does not replace it.

He then has a second pick.

What is the probability the second pick is a blue ball?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reduce the denominator when an item is not replaced in a probability question</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand products of three binomials in the form (x + a)(x + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Triple Brackets and more</Subject>
<Question>

\(
(p+8)(p+2)(p+1)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a cubic expression should have three terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Without using a calculator, what is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
5,6,5,6,6
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is the middle number</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Without using a calculator, what is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
2,5,5,8,8,8
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>

\(
\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{9}=\frac{\bigstar}{36}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions</Misconception>

\[
2,2,3,5,5,8
\]

<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>

```
<Construct>Calculate the mode as an average from a list of data when there are two or more modes</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\[
2,2,5,8,9,9
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When there are two modes, finds the mean of these values and gives that as the mode</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Calculate the mode as an average from a list of data when there are two or more modes</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\[
2,2,5,5,8,9
\]
</Question>
<Answer>There is no mode</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if there are two numbers with the same frequency, there isn't a mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 128^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 90^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that all angles anywhere along a straight line add to 180</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 275^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes angles on a straight line add to 360 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence? \( 3, \quad 12, \quad 16, \quad 27, \quad \ldots \)
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you add \( 9 \) to the previous term</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence? \( 3, \quad 14, \quad 17, \quad 32, \quad \ldots \)
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you square the previous term and add \( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence? \( 3, \quad 12, \quad 15, \quad 24, \quad \ldots \)
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you multiply the previous term by \( 4 \) and subtract \( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Manipulate both equations so that they are in a form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Mark and Emily are discussing how to get this pair of simultaneous equations in a form where they can eliminate \( y \) \(( 1)\)  \(3x - 4y = 10 \)
\( (2)\)  \(2x + 5y = 15 \) Mark says you need to multiply equation \( (2) \) by \( 4 \).

Emily says you need to multiply equation \( (1) \) by \( 5 \) and multiply equation \( (2) \) by \( 4 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Emily</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, thinks they can't multiply each equation by a different number</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 35 \times 12 \) mentally. Tom does \( 35 \times 6 \) and then multiplies his answer by \( 2 \). Katie does \( 17.5 \times 12 \) and then doubles her answer. Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Tom is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that multiplication can be broken down into factors</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that fractions with larger denominators are greater in size</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( g^{2}-30=360 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks index notation represents repeated addition rather than repeated multiplication</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( g+30=g \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles and angles around a point</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
A point, \( P \), has coordinates \( (3,-3) \)

The point is reflected in the line \( y=-x \)

What are the new coordinates of point P?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

The point is reflected in the line \( y=x \)

What are the new coordinates of point P?

<Answer>\( (3,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>

The point is reflected in the line \( y=-x \)

What are the new coordinates of point P?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-3,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes reflection in y = -x switches x and y coordinates</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 8 \div 4 + 3 \times 2 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before division</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 8 \div 4 + 3 \times 2 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>

<Construct>Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Liam and Emma are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
52.6381 \div 6.8943
\]

Liam says \( 53 \div 6.8943 \) would give an overestimate.

Emma says \( 52.6381 \div 7 \) would give an overestimate.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the larger the divisor, the larger the answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
42.5678 \div 8.1234
\]

Emma says \( 43 \div 8.1234 \) would give an overestimate.

Jack says \( 42.5678 \div 9 \) would give an overestimate.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jack</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the larger the divisor, the larger the answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Lisa and Mark are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
52.347 \div 9.851
\]

Lisa says \( 55 \div 9.851 \) would give an underestimate.

Mark says \( 52.347 \div 10 \) would give an underestimate.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Lisa is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the larger the dividend, the smaller the answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.
To calculate the mean age, what is the most sensible heading for the third column? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 7 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Age + Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.
To calculate the mean age, what is the most sensible heading for the third column? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 7 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Age - Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the total sales from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Total Sales from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the sales of different products in a store.
To calculate the total sales, what is the most sensible heading for the third column? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Product & Frequency & \\
\hline \( A \) & \( 5 \) & \\
\hline \( B \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( C \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline \( D \) & \( 4 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Product \( \div \)
Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies</Misconception>

<Answer>The cube numbers</Answer>

<Construct>Manipulate both equations so that they are in a form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sandeep wants to eliminate \( l \) from these simultaneous equations.
\(\begin{array}{l}
2 l+3 m=13 \\
3 l+4 m=17
\end{array}\)

First he will transform both of them to get them in an appropriate form.
Which of the following is a correct transformation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}6 l+9 m=13 \\ 6 l+8 m=17\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, thinks you only transform the algebraic terms, rather than the whole equation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Manipulate both equations so that they are in a form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sandeep wants to eliminate \( l \) from these simultaneous equations.
\(\begin{array}{l}
2 l+3 m=13 \\
3 l+4 m=17
\end{array}\)

First he will transform both of them to get them in an appropriate form.
Which of the following is a correct transformation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}6 l+3 m=13 \\ 6 l+4 m=17\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, thinks you only transform the term that is being eliminated, rather than the whole equation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>

<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 36 \times 54 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 30 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 50 \) & \(\space\) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\)\\
\hline \( 4 \) & \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 56 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 35 \times 12 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 30 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 10 \) & \(\space\) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\)\\
\hline \( 2 \) & \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying involving a multiple of 10, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>

\hline \( 3 \) & \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying by a multiple of 10, gives an answer 10 times bigger than it should be</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\[
-8 = q - 4
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( q = -12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you write the carried value in the number rather than adding it to the next place value column</Misconception>

<Construct>Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify (if possible):
\(
7^{8} \div 7^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7^{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when dividing numbers with the same base you divide the powers, rather than subtracting</Misconception>

<Construct>Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify (if possible):
\(
7^{5} \div 7^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing numbers with the same base divides the base numbers and the powers</Misconception>

<Construct>Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify (if possible):
\(
7^{8} \div 7^{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing numbers with the same base correctly subtracts the powers but divides the base numbers.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a non-linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine will solve the equation \( x^{3}-3=24 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine showing x as the input then -3 then cubing to give 24 as the output. Then a reverse function machine underneath showing 24 (the output) now as the input cube root and then +3]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a non-linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine will solve the equation \( x^{3}-7=20 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine showing 20 as the input then cubing and -7 to give the output]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a non-linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine will solve the equation \( x^{2}+2=18 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine showing x as the input then x2 then +2 to give 18 as the output. Then a reverse function machine underneath showing 18 (the output) now as the input  -2 and then divide by 2]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about rounding.

Tom says \( \mathbf{0 . 0 4 7 8 9} \) rounded to \( 2 \) significant figures is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \)

Katie says \( 0.04789 \) rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing rounding.

Emma says \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5 6 7 8} \) rounded to \( 2 \) significant figures is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \)

Jake says \( 0.05678 \) rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (significant figures rather than decimal places)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to other non-integer values (e.g. 0.02)</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{2 . 7 8 3} \) rounded to the nearest \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.80 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to other non-integer values (e.g. 0.05)</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{2 . 3 7 4} \) rounded to the nearest \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.35 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)

Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\begin{array}{c}
\frac{7}{x+5}-\frac{3}{x-3} \\
=\frac{7(x-3)}{(x+5)(x-3)}-\frac{3(x+5)}{(x+5)(x-3)}
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{5}-\frac{3(5)}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly cancels what they believe is a factor in algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)

Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\begin{array}{c}
\frac{7}{x+5}-\frac{3}{x-3} \\
=\frac{7(x-3)}{(x+5)(x-3)}-\frac{3(x+5)}{(x+5)(x-3)}
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{x+5}-\frac{3}{x-3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to subtract algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)

Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\begin{array}{c}
\frac{9}{x+5}-\frac{2}{x-3} \\
=\frac{9(x-3)}{(x+5)(x-3)}-\frac{2(x+5)}{(x+5)(x-3)}
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9(x-3)-2(x+5)}{(x+5)(x-3)-(x+5)(x-3)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A smoothie is made of fruit and milk in the ratio 3:2. What fraction of the smoothie is milk?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A smoothie is made of fruit and milk in the ratio 3:2. What fraction of the smoothie is milk?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A fruit punch is made of juice and soda in the ratio 3:2. What fraction of the punch is soda?
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the relationship between a ratio and fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the diameter</Construct>
<Subject>Parts of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following diagrams shows the diameter of a circle?
</Question>
<Answer>![Circle with a line from the centre to the edge]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses circumference and radius</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the circumference</Construct>
<Subject>Parts of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following diagrams shows the circumference of a circle?
</Question>
<Answer>![Circle with a line below it, touching the circle in one place]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses tangent and circumference</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the circumference</Construct>
<Subject>Parts of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following diagrams shows the circumference of a circle?
</Question>
<Answer>![Circle with a line across from edge to edge, not passing through the centre]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses chord and circumference</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Equivalent Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following fractions is equivalent to \( \frac{6}{8} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when simplifying a fraction you can divide the numerator and denominator by different values</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Equivalent Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following fractions is equivalent to \( \frac{3}{4} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes equivalent fractions are formed with addition not multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Alex says the following:

“It doesn't matter if you do \( 67-42 \) or \( 42-67 \), you get the same answer."

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Alex is correct because subtraction is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Miran says the following:

“It doesn't matter if you do \( 72-45 \) or \( 45-72 \), you get the same answer."

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is incorrect because subtraction is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Lila says the following:

“It doesn't matter if you do \( 16 \div 4 \) or \( 4 \div 16 \), you get the same answer."

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Lila is correct because division is not commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which inequality is represented by the diagram? ![A number line with a filled circle above 3 with an arrow coming out of it over the numbers 2, 1, 0, -1, etc]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x > 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which inequality is represented by the diagram? ![A number line with a hollow circle above 3 with an arrow coming out of it over the numbers 4, 5, 6, 7 etc]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x<3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Find the volume scale factor of similar shapes given the length scale factor</Construct>
<Subject>Length, Area and Volume Scale Factors</Subject>
<Question>
![Two cuboids. Cuboid A has width 4cm, and cuboid B has width 12cm.]() Shape A and Shape B are similar.

What is the volume scale factor to get from Shape \( A \) to Shape \( B \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the volume of an enlarged shape is the volume of the original multiplied by the cube of the scale factor of the lengths.</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Find the volume scale factor of similar shapes given the length scale factor</Construct>
<Subject>Length, Area and Volume Scale Factors</Subject>
<Question>
![Two spheres. Sphere A has a radius of 3cm, and sphere B has a radius of 9cm.]() Sphere A and Sphere B are similar.

What is the volume scale factor to get from Sphere \( A \) to Sphere \( B \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the volume of an enlarged shape is the volume of the original multiplied by the cube of the scale factor of the lengths.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the volume scale factor of similar shapes given the length scale factor</Construct>
<Subject>Length, Area and Volume Scale Factors</Subject>
<Question>
![Two spheres. Sphere A has a diameter of 4cm, and sphere B has a diameter of 8cm.]() Sphere A and Sphere B are similar.

What is the volume scale factor to get from Sphere \( A \) to Sphere \( B \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the volume of an enlarged shape is the volume of the original multiplied by the cube of the scale factor of the lengths.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of a rhombus</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
\( P Q R S \) is a rhombus.
Which lines must be perpendicular? ![Parallelogram with the vertices labelled P, Q, R and S]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( P Q \) and \( Q R \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adjacent sides of a rhombus are always perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of a rectangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
\( A B C D \) is a rectangle.
Which lines must be perpendicular? ![Rectangle with the vertices labelled A, B, C and D]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( A B \) and \( D C \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of parallel and perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of a rectangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
\( A B C D \) is a rectangle.
Which lines must be perpendicular? ![Parallelogram with the vertices labelled A, B, C and D]()
</Question>
<Answer>None of them</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a rhombus</Misconception>

a percentage
greater than \( 100 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
How many squares will the next term in this sequence have? ![A diagram showing the first 3 patterns in a sequence. Pattern 1 contains 10 squares, pattern 2 contains 8 squares, and pattern 3 contains 6 squares.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the term-to-term rule rather than the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
How many triangles will the next term in this sequence have? ![A diagram showing the first 3 patterns in a sequences. Pattern 1 contains 4 triangles, pattern 2 contains 3 triangles and pattern 3 contains 2 triangles.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise integers expressed visually</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is represented below? ![An image showing two rods, each cut into ten squares, five individual squares and two large squares cut into ten rows and ten columns. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 252 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes digits in the order of the pictorial representation rather than using place value columns</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise integers expressed visually</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is represented below? ![An image showing five rods, each cut into ten squares, two individual squares and one large square cut into ten rows and ten columns. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 251 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes digits in the order of the pictorial representation rather than using place value columns</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a y value, find the corresponding x value from a non-linear graph</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of \( x \) when \( y=4 \) ?

Give your answer(s) to \( 1 \) decimal place ![A curved U shaped graph. There are 5 boxes between 0 and 1 on both axes. The graph goes through (-2, 1), (0,0), (2,1) and (4,4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only gives 1 value of x for a given value of y, when reading from a parabolic graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Assign probabilities to single events using fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) blue marbles and \( 2 \) green marbles in a bag. ![The image shows the bag with the 5 blue marbles and 2 green marbles.]() What is the probability of picking a blue marble?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives the probability out of the number of non-successes rather than the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Assign probabilities to single events using fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) blue marbles and \( 2 \) green marbles in a bag. ![The image shows the bag with the 5 blue marbles and 2 green marbles.]() What is the probability of picking a blue marble?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes the numerator and the denominator the wrong way round in a probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a linear graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Straight Line Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a linear function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph showing a wavy line that oscillates up and down as it moves from left to right.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes linear graphs can be curved</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a linear graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Straight Line Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a linear function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph that starts in the bottom left, rises steeply up as you move right, briefly levels off, then steeply down back to the same level as the starting point, forming a symmetrical inverted U shape.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes linear graphs can be curved</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a linear graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Straight Line Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a linear function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with a single curve that starts high on the left side of the y-axis, drops sharply towards the x-axis, then levels off to become nearly horizontal as it approaches the right side of the graph.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses linear and reciprocal graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with a different number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing negative numbers.

Tom says \( -12>-9 \)

Katie says \( -0.401>-0.41 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 50 \% \) of \( 400 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 450 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Added the values together instead of finding the percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 50 \% \) of \( 250 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage can be applied to something not out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 50 \% \) of \( 400 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that dividing by 100 gives 10%</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( -4(x-5) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4x+20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( -4(x-1) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4x+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\[
x^{2}-3 x+7 \equiv(x-b)^{2}+2.25
\]
What is the value of \( b \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\[
x^{2}-7 x+12 \equiv(x-b)^{2}+2.25
\]
What is the value of \( b \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b is the difference between a and the constant of the original quadratic</Misconception>

<Construct>Round decimals to the nearest whole number</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
John measures the length and width of his rectangular garden as \( 8.2 \mathrm{~m} \) and \( 12.8 \mathrm{~m} \).
Which calculation will give the best estimate of the area?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \times 13 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds every number up when estimating</Misconception>

<Construct>Round decimals to the nearest whole number</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
John measures the length and width of his rectangular garden as \( 12.6 \mathrm{~m} \) and \( 14.8 \mathrm{~m} \).
Which calculation will give the best estimate of the area?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \times 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 60 \% \)</Answer>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>

<Question>
What is the ratio of squares to triangles? ![A diagram showing 3 yellow squares and 2 green triangles]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3: 2: 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to include the total as well as the individual parts when asked to write a ratio</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 6: 3 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 3: 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing ratio from diagram, writes total as one side</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( k=3 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( \mathrm{k}>3 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the distance \( (d) \) traveled by a particle with acceleration \( (a)=3.2 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2} \), initial velocity \( (u)=1.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), and time \( (t)=2.7 \mathrm{~s} \) using the formula \( d=ut+\frac{1}{2}at^2 \).
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}d=1.5 + 2.7 + \frac{1}{2} + 3.2 + 2.7^2 \\ d=19.225\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a variable next to a number means addition rather than multiplication</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the time taken \( (t) \) for a particle to travel with acceleration \( (a)=4.1 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2} \), initial velocity \( (u)=2.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) and final velocity \( (v)=8.7 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) \( t=\frac{1}{a}(v-u) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}t=4.1 \times(8.7-2.8) \\ t=24.19\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, multiplies the denominator</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. AB is a vertical line measuring 4 units. CD is a diagonal line, with a positive gradient of 1.5. EF is a vertical line measuring 3 units. GH is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -4/6. IJ is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -3. KL is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 1/3. MN is a vertical line measuring 6 units. OP is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 6/4.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to IJ?
</Question>
<Answer>MN</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and vertical</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. AB is a vertical line measuring 4 units. CD is a diagonal line, with a positive gradient of 1.5. EF is a vertical line measuring 3 units. GH is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -4/6. IJ is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -3. KL is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 1/3. MN is a vertical line measuring 6 units. OP is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 6/4.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to GH?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{AB} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and vertical</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute numbers into a SUVAT equation to work out distance</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \) What is the value of \( S \) when
\[\begin{array}{l} a=2 \\ u=4 \\ t=3\end{array}\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When a variable in an expression has a power, thinks the power applies to the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Work out: \( \frac{3}{5}-\frac{2}{9} \) Give your answer in the simplest form.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{31}{45} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Work out: \( \frac{3}{5}-\frac{2}{3} \) Give your answer in the simplest form.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Work out: \( \frac{3}{5}-\frac{2}{3} \) Give your answer in the simplest form.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to change the numerators when finding equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\(
T=k^{2}
\)

What is the value of \( T \) when \( k=-4 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\(
T=k^{3}
\)

What is the value of \( T \) when \( k=-2 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has multiplied the base number and the power</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( x^{2}-16 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x(x-16) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( x^{2}-25 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x-5)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the factorised form of repeated roots and the difference of 2 squares</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be factorised</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Correctly finds the reciprocal of a number, but believes it should be opposite in sign to the original number.</Misconception>

\)

<Answer>\( m=5 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>

The pie chart shows the favourite subjects of children at a school.

</Question>
<Answer>\( 72 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the angle in a pie chart sector is equal to the frequency</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 1 \times 10^{-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating with numbers in standard form, just applies the operation to the number and the power separately</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![An image of six connected rectangles. The six rectangles are 3 lots of identical rectangle pairs. There is a central rectangle with identical rectangles attached to the left and right of it. It then has identical rectangles attached to its top and bottom sides. Below the rectangle attached to the bottom side is another attached rectangle which is identical to the central rectangle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Cube</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up cubes and cuboids</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![An image of five connected rectangles. There is a central rectangle with identical rectangles attached to the left and right of it. Additionally, identical rectangles are attached to the top and bottom sides of the central rectangle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Rectangle-based pyramid</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses pyramid with prism</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing parallel lines.
Alex says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{1} \) are parallel.
Jamie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) are parallel.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jamie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines are parallel if they have the same y intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about parallel lines.
Tom says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{4 x + 5} \) are parallel.
Katie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) are parallel.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient</Misconception>

<Answer>They are parallel</Answer>

<Answer>They add together to make \[180\degree\]</Answer>

\)

</Question>
<Answer>never true</Answer>

\frac{x+y}{z}=(x+y) \div z
\)

\(

\)

<Answer>"Add \( \mathrm{x} \) and \( \mathrm{y} \) then add five."</Answer>

\)

<Answer>"Add seven to x and then multiply by y."</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

\(
2+x y
\)
</Question>
<Answer>"Add two to \( \mathrm{y} \) and then multiply by x."</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( h=5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the base and perpendicular height when calculating the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( h=5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in a ratio 1:n that one part of the ratio would be n times bigger than the one part</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in a ratio 1:n that one part of the ratio would be n times bigger than the one part</Misconception>

\end{array}

<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>

The vertical height of the top rectangle is 7cm. The top rectangle is shaded red.]()

<Answer>\( 12 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>

The vertical height of the top rectangle is 6cm. The top rectangle is shaded red.]()

<Answer>\( 180 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape made from two rectangles that form an "L" shape. The base of the shape is horizontal and is 13cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 14cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 6cm. The vertical height of the top rectangle is 8cm. The top rectangle is shaded red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 62 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Calculates perimeter when asked for area</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons.
Tom says if all the angles are equal then the polygon must be regular.
Katie says if all the sides are equal in length then the polygon must be regular.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that only the angles need to be the same for a polygon to be regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons.
Tom says if all the angles are equal then the polygon must be regular. Katie says if all the sides are equal then the polygon must be regular.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that only the sides need to be equal for a polygon to be regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons.
Tom says if all the angles are equal then the polygon must be regular.
Katie says if all the sides are equal in length then the polygon must be regular.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that all angles and sides must be equal for regular shapes</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to percentages containing 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \frac{23}{50} \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 23 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a fraction out of a number other than 100 represents a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to percentages containing 1 decimal place</Construct>

<Question>
What is \( \frac{23}{50} \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 23 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a fraction out of a number other than 100 represents a percentage</Misconception>

What is \( \frac{23}{50} \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>23%</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a fraction out of a number other than 100 represents a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
This pictogram shows the different types of fruits Sarah has in her basket.
Sarah has \( 3 \) bananas.

How would she display this on the pictogram? ![A pictogram showing the number of fruits Sarah has in her basket. Apples have 2 symbols, oranges have 3 symbols, bananas have 1 and a half symbols, grapes have 2 and a quarter symbols, and pears have 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 4 fruits.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![\( 3 \)]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Raj accelerates gradually, then maintains a constant speed, before decelerating to a stop. Which of the following velocity \( (v) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate Raj's journey?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with time on the horizontal axis and velocity on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels right and up in a curved line, travels horizontally right, then travels right and down in a more steep straight line than the start, until it reaches the horizontal axis.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What mixed number fraction is represented below? ![Five bars, each split into eight equal parts. In four of the shapes, all eight parts are shaded. In the fifth shape, seven out of eight parts are shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \frac{7}{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting from an improper fraction to a mixed number, just writes the tens digit as the number of wholes</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape</Construct>
