What mixed number fraction is represented below? ![Five bars, each split into seven equal parts. In four of the shapes, all seven parts are shaded. In the fifth shape, six out of seven parts are shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{34}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confused mixed numbers with improper fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the 7th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is 1 orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 2 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![9 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 5 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence just gives the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the 6th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is 1 orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 2 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![11 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 6 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives a different term, which is not the next</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the 8th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is 1 orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 2 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![13 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 7 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives a different term, which is not the next</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100,000 \) more than \( 452,789 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 552,789 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 1,000 \) more than \( 75,432 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 754,320 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100,000 \) more than \( 345,789 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 355,789 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in a scalene triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( q \) ? ![A triangle with angles labelled 40 degrees, 60 degrees and q [not to scale]]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks angles which look the same on diagram will be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in a scalene triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( q \) ? ![A triangle with angles labelled 30 degrees, 60 degrees and q [not to scale]]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that angles in a triangle sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{9}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{1}{2} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{27}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{1}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{27} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up square rooting and cube rooting</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{9}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{1}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides by the index</Misconception>

\[
0.0000205
\]

<Answer>\( 2.1 \times 10^{-5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When changing a number to standard form omits zero's of significance</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from mixed number fractions to improper fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into an improper fraction:
\(
5 \frac{3}{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{53}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the number of wholes in a mixed number represents the tens from the numerator of an improper fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from mixed number fractions to improper fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into an improper fraction:
\(
5 \frac{3}{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{19}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you multiply by the numerator and add the denominator when converting a mixed number to an improper fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from mixed number fractions to improper fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into an improper fraction:
\(
5 \frac{3}{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{20}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to add the numerator when converting from a mixed number to an improper fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![A set of axes with a horizontal line going through 4 on the y axis]() What is the equation of this line?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=4x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses lines of the form y = a and y= ax</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of length</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
George has answered a question on perimeter and worked out an answer of \( 310 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 310 \color{yellow} \bigstar\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( cm^3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise metres as a unit of length</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of length</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
George has answered a question on perimeter and worked out an answer of \( 310 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 310 \color{yellow} \bigstar\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(cm^3\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise millimetres as a unit of length</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of length</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
George has answered a question on perimeter and worked out an answer of \( 310 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 310 \color{yellow} \bigstar\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( ft \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise feet (ft) as a unit of length</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Emma's book. Emma always records what operation she has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x - 5 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Emma's book. Emma always records what operation she has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 5 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 5 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \div 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is division</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A graph of a quadratic curve that crosses the x axis at (-2,0) and (4,0) and crosses the y axis at (0,-8).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-2)(x-4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to swap the sign of roots when placing into brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A graph of a quadratic curve that crosses the x axis at (2,0) and (-4,0) and crosses the y axis at (0,-8).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-2)(x+4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A graph of a quadratic curve that crosses the x axis at (2,0) and (4,0) and crosses the y axis at (0,8).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-2)(x-4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a bar model to express a ratio problem</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie share \( £ 30 \) in the ratio \( 3\;: 2 \).
Which of the following diagrams best represents this situation?
</Question>
<Answer>![A bar split into 3 pink blocks and 2 blue blocks. All the blocks are the same size and each block is labelled £30.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio where total is given, treats that as one part without dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a bar model to express a ratio problem</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Jane and Sam share \( £ 40 \) in the ratio \( 4\;: 1 \).
Which of the following diagrams best represents this situation?
</Question>
<Answer>![A red bar split into 4 blocks, and below it a shorter green bar split into 1 block. All the blocks are the same size. The difference in length between the red bar and the green bar is labelled £40.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When drawing bar diagram for ratio, shows the total as the difference between parts</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a bar model to express a ratio problem</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie share \( £ 30 \) in the ratio \( 3\;: 2 \).
Which of the following diagrams best represents this situation?
</Question>
<Answer>![A pink bar split into 3 blocks, and below it a shorter blue bar split into 2 blocks. All the blocks are the same size. The length of the pink bar is labelled £30.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When drawing bar diagram for ratio, shows the total amount as the total of one side</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{9}+\frac{2}{9}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies the numerators when adding fractions with a common denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{5}+\frac{2}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{25} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to add fractions, multiplies instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{8}+\frac{2}{8}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{16} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square root of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 12^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \square^{2} \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the sum of 2 numbers, each squared first, is the same as adding the two numbers and then squaring the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square root of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 20^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \square^{2} \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Halves when asked to find the square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental subtraction problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
A \( 4 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
\square -8529=2341
\)
What is the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental subtraction problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
A \( 4 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
\square -2398=2014
\)
What is the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>does not know the meaning of the word digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental subtraction problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
A \( 4 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
\square -5678=2345
\)
What is the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>Not possible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that addition is the inverse operation of subtraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving two negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-7)+(-3)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that adding a negative will increase the value of the original number</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving two negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-7)+(-5)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding two negatives gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing sequences. Emma says \( (3n-2)^{2} \) would produce a linear sequence. Jake says \( 4-n \) would produce a linear sequence. Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing sequences. Emma says \( (3n+2)^2 \) would produce a linear sequence. Jake says \( 5 - \frac{n}{3} \) would produce a linear sequence. Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing sequences. Alex says \( 5 - 2n \) would produce a linear sequence. Jamie says \( 3 - \frac{3n}{4} \) would produce a linear sequence. Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes linear sequences cannot include fractions</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 4.76+3.87= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8.53 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

\( 4.23+1.87= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding decimals, just adds the digits and ignores place value</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 5.07 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Know the equation of the axes</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks y = 1 at the y axis</Misconception>

<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of the \( y \) axis?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the equation of the axes</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of the \( y \) axis?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = y is an axis</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the range of this set of data?
\[
10 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 3 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 15 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 8 \mathrm{~cm}
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the biggest value for the range</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the range of this set of data?
\[
12 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 3 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 8 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 5 \mathrm{~cm}
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>

\[
4 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 22 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 5 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 7 \mathrm{~cm}
\]

<Construct>Describe an ascending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most accurate way to describe this sequence?

\[
3,8,13,18,23, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 5 \) and the common difference is positive \( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the definition of term or term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an ascending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most accurate way to describe this sequence?

\[
3,9,15,21,27, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 5 \) and the common difference is negative \( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the definition of term or term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete mental addition problems up to 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
\( 45+123= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 568 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Lines up the digits incorrectly when doing an addition involving two numbers with a different amount of digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete mental addition problems up to 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
\( 45+98= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 133 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.4=\frac{2}{5}=? \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a percentage by writing the numerator followed by the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.5=\frac{1}{2}=? \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a linear expression by taking out a single numeric common factor (e.g. 6)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star and triangle when this expression is fully factorised? \( 6x - 9 \equiv {\bigstar}(\triangle x-\bigcirc) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=6 \\ \Delta=1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising, finds a factor that goes into only the first term of the expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a linear expression by taking out a single numeric common factor (e.g. 6)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star and triangle when this expression is fully factorised? \( 12 n - 18 \equiv {\bigstar}(\triangle n-\bigcirc) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=9 \\ \Delta=4\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes factors add to give a number</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The rectangle is reflected in the \( x \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -3 to 6, y-axis from -4 to 5. Four points are plotted and joined to make a rectangle: (1, 0), (4, 0), (4, 3), (1, 3). Point (1, 3) is labelled with the letter "Q". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (1,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when a shape touches the mirror line, all of its vertices will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( x \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 8, y-axis from -5 to 6. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 0), (4, 0), (2, 3). Point (2, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that reflection always switches the x and y coordinates</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of vertical lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A graph showing a vertical line going through 3 on the x axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=3 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the equation of a vertical line is in the form y = ax, where a is the x intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A graph showing a horizontal line going through 3 on the y axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=3x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A graph showing a horizontal line going through 5 on the y axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 90° and 180°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 150^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise, to the red line that is halfway between 140 and 150 (inner scale) and halfway between 40 and 30 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Chooses the correct scale when measuring angles on a protractor but starts from the wrong number when the angle is in between two labelled dashes</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 90° and 180°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 120^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise, to the red line that is halfway between 60 and 70 (inner scale) and halfway between 120 and 110 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles</Misconception>

\(
\begin{array}{llllll}
a & 7 & 12 & b & 21 & 28
\end{array}
\)

<Answer>\( a-28 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
The data is in ascending order.
\(
\begin{array}{llllll}
a & 7 & 12 & b & 20 & 30
\end{array}
\)
Write an expression for the range.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7+12+b+20+30+a}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mean instead of the range</Misconception>

\[

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( b=\frac{2}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds when using inverse operations to solve an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret linear sections of real life graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>

The gradient of the negative sloping section would tell us... ![A graph with time (mins) on the horizontal axis and temperature (°C) on the vertical axis. The graph starts high on the vertical axis and travels in a straight line down and right towards the x-axis.]
</Question>
<Answer>The temperature of the coffee</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that gradient represents rate of change</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise that a sequence is linear sequences when expressed as a pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing linear sequences. Alex says this is a linear sequence: ![Three shapes made of triangles. The first is a single triangle. The second shape has 3 triangles, one on top and two below. The third shape has 6 triangles, one on top, two in the middle, and three below.]() Jamie says this is a linear sequence: ![Three shapes made of triangles. The first is a single triangle. The second shape has 4 triangles, two on top and two below. The third shape has 9 triangles, three on top, three in the middle, and three below.]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise that a sequence is linear sequences when expressed as a pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing linear sequences. Alex says this is a linear sequence: ![Three shapes made of squares. The first is a T-shape made of 4 squares. The second shape is a T made of 7 squares, three on the top row and four on the bottom row. The third shape is a T made of 10 squares, four on the top row and six on the bottom. ]() Jamie says this is a linear sequence: ![Three shapes made of squares. The first is a T-shape made of 4 squares. The second shape is a T made of 8 squares, four on the top row and four on the bottom row. The third shape is a T made of 12 squares, four on the top row and eight on the bottom. ]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise that a sequence is linear sequences when expressed as a pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing linear sequences. Alex says this is a linear sequence: ![Three shapes made of squares. The first is a T-shape made of 4 squares. The second shape is a T made of 6 squares, one extra on each side. The third shape is a T made of 8 squares, two extra on each side. ]() Jamie says this is a linear sequence: ![Three shapes made of squares. The first is a T-shape made of 4 squares. The second shape is a T made of 7 squares, one extra on each side and one at the bottom. The third shape is a T made of 10 squares, two extra on each side and one at the bottom. ]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both are correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\frac{\mathbf{1}}{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a number divided by itself equals 0</Misconception>

\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a reciprocal equation is defined when the denominator is 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
What is the midpoint of these two coordinates? ![A set of axes with two points (-3,7) and (5,-1) plotted.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (4,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes midpoint calculation is just half of the difference</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
What is the midpoint of these two coordinates? ![A set of axes with two points (-3,7) and (5,-1) plotted.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,6) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of both expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
If two pizzas and three sodas cost \( £ 15.50 \), and one pizza and four sodas cost £12.00, what is the cost of a pizza and a soda?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Pizza }= £4.50, \\ \text { Soda }= £1.50\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
I think of a number. I multiply it by three and then subtract two. The answer I get is \( 7 \).
Which of the following equations represents this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( n \times 3 - 2 = 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
I think of a number. I subtract three and then multiply the result by two. The answer I get is \( 11 \).
Which of the following equations represents this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 n-3=11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include brackets when attempting to multiply an expression</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 60 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Jane and Mark are discussing ways to calculate \( 24 \times 15 \) mentally. Jane does \( 15 \times 8 \) and then multiplies her answer by \( 3 \). Mark does \( 24 \times 5 \) and then triples his answer. Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jane</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Jake and Sarah are discussing ways to calculate \( 15 \times 14 \) mentally. Jake does \( 14 \times 5 \) and then multiplies his answer by \( 3 \). Sarah does \( 15 \times 7 \) and then doubles her answer. Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Sarah</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Sara and Mike are discussing ways to calculate \( 15 \times 14 \) mentally. Sara does \( 14 \times 5 \) and then multiplies her answer by \( 3 \). Mike does \( 15 \times 7 \) and then doubles his answer. Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by dividing by a single letter</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Jake and Emma are discussing how to simplify a fraction. Jake says \( \frac{4q + 2}{q} \equiv 4 \) while Emma says \( \frac{4q + 2}{q} \equiv 4 + \frac{2}{q} \). Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Only applies a division to one of multiple terms in a numerator when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}d=-3 \\ h=2\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

\(
5 h^{2}-3 h-2=0
\)

What should replace the triangle? \( ?\pm \sqrt{\triangle-?} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -9 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Emma decides to go for a bike ride starting from her house.
The graph on the right shows Emma's distance in metres \( (d) \) over time in seconds
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the negative sloping section of the graph is \( 0.75 \).

Which of the following does that \( 0.75 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with d on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Emma is travelling away from home at a speed of \( 0.75 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a downward slope on a distance-time graph means travelling away</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Aaliyah goes on a bike ride starting from her house.
The graph on the right shows Aaliyah's distance in metres \( (d) \) over time in seconds
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the positive sloping section of the graph is \( 2 \).

Which of the following does that \( 2 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with d on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Aaliyah is accelerating at a rate of \( 2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a distance-time graph is the acceleration</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
What does the following equal?
\[
6 + 8 \div 2 - 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
What does the following equal?
\[
7-2+3 \times 5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of subtraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
What does the following equal?
\[
2-3+6 \times 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( -15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a ruler to measure the length of a line segment</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Lengths</Subject>
<Question>
When measuring the length of a line segment, which step will you complete last?
</Question>
<Answer>Align the ruler along the line segment.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recall the steps required to draw an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to draw angles between 90° and 180°</Construct>

<Question>
When drawing an angle, which step will you complete first?
</Question>
<Answer>Measure the angle using the protractor.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recall the steps required to draw an angle</Misconception>

<Question>
When drawing an angle, which step will you complete last?
</Question>
<Answer>Place the protractor on the paper</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recall the steps required to draw an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to draw angles between 0° and 90°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 35^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise to the red line that is halfway between 145 and 155 (inner scale) and halfway between 35 and 25 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles</Misconception>

The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise to the red line that is halfway between 30 and 40 (inner scale) and halfway between 150 and 140 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Chooses the correct scale when measuring angles on a protractor but starts from the wrong number when the angle is in between two labelled dashes</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-4 x+3 x-7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Points \( A, B \) and \( C \) are equally spaced along the line segment, as shown in the sketch.

The coordinates of \( \mathrm{A} \) and \( \mathrm{C} \) are marked on the diagram.

What are the coordinates of \( B \) ? ![A graph with 4 quadrants showing a line joining points A(1, 6), B (unknown coordinate in 2nd quadrant) and C (-3, -4)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-1,-4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The frequency table shows the number of pets owned by some families.
What was the modal number of pets? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mode is the most common frequency rather than the highest frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The frequency table shows the number of books read by students in a month.
What was the modal number of books read? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of Books & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mode is the frequency rather than the value/group</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \triangle \triangle \triangle \square \triangle \triangle \triangle \square \triangle \triangle \triangle \square \) For every \( 3 \) squares there are \(___\) triangles
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds one part of a ratio but doesn't multiply that by the number of parts needed</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition or subtraction with multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 6 \) shelves of plates. Three of the shelves hold \( 12 \) plates each. One of the shelves holds \( 20 \) plates. The other two shelves hold \( 18 \) plates each.
How many plates are there in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 62 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores numbers written as words in worded questions, and just calculates using those written in digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition or subtraction with multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 7 \) shelves of plates. Three of the shelves hold \( 12 \) plates each. Two of the shelves hold \( 25 \) plates each. The other shelves hold \( 18 \) plates each.
How many plates are there in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 57 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores numbers written as words in worded questions, and just calculates using those written in digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a quantity into two parts for a given ratio, where each part is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
For every \( 2 \) blue circles there is \( 1 \) yellow circle.

How many circles should be coloured blue in the grid on the right? \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not believe you can scale up a proportional statement</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a quantity into two parts for a given a ratio, where each part is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>

\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\

\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
8/2\times4
\]
Sara and Mike are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 1 \).
Sara says you can write it like this: \( (8/2)\times4 \)
Mike says you can leave it like this: \( 8/2\times4 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Sara</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>

<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\( 2, \quad 4, \quad 6, \quad 8 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\( 2, \quad 4, \quad 6, \quad 8 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence expressed as a pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the best way to describe this sequence: ![A pattern with 6 terms made of green and red dots. The first term is a green dot, the second a red dot, the third is one red and one green dot. The fourth term is made of one green and two red dots. The fifth term is made from two green dots and three red dots. The sixth term is made of five red dots and three green dots. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Linear</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence expressed as a pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the best way to describe this sequence: ![A pattern with 6 terms made of green and red dots. The first term is a green dot, the second a red dot, the third is one red and one green dot. The fourth term is made of one green and two red dots. The fifth term is made from two green dots and three red dots. The sixth term is made of five red dots and three green dots. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Quadratic</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the term quadratic</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence expressed as a pattern</Construct>

<Question>

The first term is a green dot, the second a red dot, the third is one red and one green dot. The fourth term is made of one green and two red dots. The fifth term is made from two green dots and three red dots. The sixth term is made of five red dots and three green dots. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Arithmetic</Answer>

<Construct>Represent the solution to a graphical inequality involving a combination of vertical, horizontal and diagonal lines</Construct>
<Subject>Graphing Linear Inequalities (Shading Regions)</Subject>
<Question>
Which letter describes the region where \( \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y} \geq \mathbf{2} \) and \( \boldsymbol{x} \leq \mathbf{3} \) ? ![A set of axes with two straight lines drawn on. The line x-y=2 goes through points (2,0) and (0,-2). The line x=3 is a vertical line going through (3,0). The lines intersect one another at (3,1).
A is the region above x-y=2 and to the left of x=3.
B is the region below both lines.
C is the region above both lines.
D is the region below x-y=2 and to the right of x=3. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

\[

\]
</Question>
<Answer>Left \( 5 \) squares, down \( 3 \) squares</Answer>

<Construct>Find missing angles using vertically opposite angles</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( z \) ? ![A diagram showing 3 lines crossing at a point to form 6 angles. One angle is marked as 55 degrees. Another angle is marked as z. There are two blank angles between each marked angle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 125^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes vertically opposite angles sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using vertically opposite angles</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 55^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes vertically opposite angles sum to 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using vertically opposite angles</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that vertically opposite angles are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Tom is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (3,-4) \) and \( (-2,5) \) He labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{rrrr}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (3, & -4) & (-2, & 5)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the first bracket equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-5)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Brian is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (2,-3) \) and \( (-4,5) \) He labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{rrrr}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (2, & -3) & (-4, & 5)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the second bracket equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number from a positive number, uses a method which assumes one of the negative signs can be ignored</Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
How should you line up the digits to calculate \( 0.8+0.22 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A column addition of 0.8 + 0.22. The 0 of 0.8 is directly above the decimal point of 0.22, the decimal point of 0.8 is directly above the 2 of 0.22 and the 8 of 0.8 is directly above the second 2 of 0.22.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that when adding decimals with a different number of decimal places, you should line up the digits to the right</Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
How should you line up the digits to calculate \( 0.8+0.32 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A column addition of 0.08 + 0.32 with the decimal points lined up.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jack are discussing units of volume
Emma says millilitres is a unit of volume
Jack says \( cm^{3} \) is a unit of volume
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that units of volume are usually cubed</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>

Jamie says \( m^{3} \) is a unit of volume
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jamie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise litres as a unit of volume</Misconception>

Alex and Sam are discussing units of volume
Alex says gallons is a unit of volume
Sam says \( cm^{3} \) is a unit of volume
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise a unit of volume</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the notation for powers</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 47+2 \)</Answer>

<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
To calculate \( 47^{2} \) you need to do...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 47 \times 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of length</Construct>

<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
Tom has answered a question on length and got an answer of \( 200 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.
Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 200 \bigstar \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{km} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows the temperature in Dan's garden in a \( 24 \) hour period.

In which \( 4 \) hour period did the temperature fall the most? ![A graph showing the temperature in Dan's house over a 24 hours period. At 00:00 the temperature is -2 degrees, at 04:00 it is -4 degrees, at 08:00 it is 0 degrees, at 12:00 it is 5 degrees, at 16:00 it is 8 degrees, at 20:00 it is 3 degrees and at 00:00 it is 0 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}16: 00 \text { to } \\ 20: 00\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows the temperature in Dan's garden in a \( 24 \) hour period.

In which \( 4 \) hour period did the temperature rise the most? ![A graph showing the temperature in Dan's house over a 24 hours period. At 00:00 the temperature is -2 degrees, at 04:00 it is -4 degrees, at 08:00 it is 0 degrees, at 12:00 it is 5 degrees, at 16:00 it is 8 degrees, at 20:00 it is 3 degrees and at 00:00 it is 0 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}20: 00 \text { to } \\ 00: 00\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up colder and hotter when comparing temperatures</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows the temperature in Dan's garden in a \( 24 \) hour period.

In which \( 4 \) hour period did the temperature fall the most? ![A graph showing the temperature in Dan's house over a 24 hours period. At 00:00 the temperature is -2 degrees, at 04:00 it is -4 degrees, at 08:00 it is 0 degrees, at 12:00 it is 5 degrees, at 16:00 it is 8 degrees, at 20:00 it is 3 degrees and at 00:00 it is 0 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{aligned} 16 & : 00 \text { to } \\ 20 & : 00\end{aligned} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise negative numbers to powers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-3)^{2}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise negative numbers to powers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-3)^{3}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 1 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Impossible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Unlikely</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 1 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Even chance</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 9-5 \div 4^{2}= \) Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \div 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is carried out before a power</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 5+3 \times 2^{2}= \) Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 5 + 3 \times 2^{4}= \) Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>It doesn't matter: you get the same answer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which expression correctly represents the following description?
"Subtract three from \( \mathrm{x} \) and then multiply by four."
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4(3-x) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts from left to right, ignoring the word ‘from’</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which expression correctly represents the following description?
"Subtract three from \( \mathrm{x} \) and then multiply by four."
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3-x) \times 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts from left to right, ignoring the word ‘from’</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which expression correctly represents the following description?
"Add three to \( \mathrm{x} \) and then divide by four."
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+3) \times \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about what term could replace the star in this addition pyramid.
Tom says it could be: \( 4f \)
Katie says it could be: \( 6f \)
Who is correct? ![A diagram showing 3 rows of boxes. the bottom row has 3 boxes, containing a star, 2f and 3f from left to right. The next row up contains two boxes, overlapping the joins of the boxes below. Both are empty. The top row is one box, centered over the join of the two below, containing 5f + 6g.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes an addition pyramid works in a different way to how it actually does</Misconception>

Katie says it could be: \( 2 f \)

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(
y=x^{2}
\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-3 x-10
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
x^{2}-3 x-10 \leq 0 ?
\) ![A quadratic parabola which crosses the x axis at (-2,0) and (5,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -10)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x \leq-2\} \cup\{x \geq 5\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-4 x-5
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
x^{2}-4 x-5 \geq 0 ?
\) ![A quadratic parabola which crosses the x axis at (-1,0) and (5,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{-1 \geq x \geq 5\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-4x-5
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
x^{2}-4x-5 \leq 0 ?
\) ![A quadratic parabola which crosses the x axis at (-1,0) and (5,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x \geq-1\} \cup\{x \leq 5\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes inequalities cannot be combined</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe how many degrees you would turn, and in what direction, to move between North, South, East and West on a compass</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 90^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>

\( \frac{7}{12}-\frac{1}{4} \)

<Answer>\( \frac{6}{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>

<Question>
Calculate:
\( \frac{7}{12}-\frac{1}{4} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not consider the denominator when adding/ subtracting fractions. Adds/subtracts the numerator and makes the denominator the one with the highest value.</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>

\( \frac{7}{12}-\frac{1}{4} \)

<Answer>\( \frac{10}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a triangle using Angle-Angle-Side</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 8 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 60^{\degree} \) and \( 30^{\degree} \) either side?
</Question>
<Answer>- Draw a line \( 8 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 60^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 30^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle</Answer>
<Misconception>Draws both angles at the same end of the line when constructing a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which option gives a correct substitution into the quadratic formula to solve the quadratic equation? \( 3x^2 - 12x + 9 = 0 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12 \pm \frac{\sqrt{(-12)^2 - 4(3)(9)}}{2(3)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \pm \frac{\sqrt{(-6)^2 - 4(3)(2)}}{2(3)} \)</Answer>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value</Misconception>

\]

<Construct>Read values from piecewise functions</Construct>
<Subject>Other Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom has correctly drawn the graph of the following function:
\(
y=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
P \text { for } 0 \leq x<Q \\
2.5 \text { for } 2 \leq x<4 \\
1 \text { for } 4 \leq x \leq 6
\end{array}\right.
\)

What are the values of \( P \) and Q? ![The graph is three separate horizontal lines. It goes from (0,3.5) to (2, 3.5), then (2, 2.5) to (4, 2.5) and the last section is from (4, 1) to (6, 1)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}P=2 \\ Q=3.5\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>

<Question>

Which type of flower is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>Tulips</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when comparing fractions</Misconception>

Which flavour cake is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>Vanilla</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>There is the same amount of each.</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Jason and Lily are discussing how to calculate percentages.

Jason says to find \( 50 \% \) of a number, you divide the number by \( 5 \).

Lily says to find \( 50 \% \) of a number, you divide by \( 100 \) and then multiply by \( 5 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jason</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 5</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Jane and Mike are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Jane says to find \( 20 \% \) you divide by \( 5 \).

Mike says to find \( 20 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 20 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jane</Answer>
<Misconception>Error finding percentage value after finding 1%</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Jake are discussing how to calculate percentages quickly.

Emma says to find \( 40 \% \) you divide by \( 4 \).

Jake says to find \( 40 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 4 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Emma and Jake</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
John walks from home at a constant speed to a bench, stops for a rest, and then runs home at a constant speed. Which of the following displacement \( (d) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate John's journey?
</Question>
<Answer>![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with gentle, positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with steep, negative gradient that ends when it touches the horizontal axis.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a less steep gradient corresponds to a faster speed</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Sarah walks from her house to the park at a constant speed, stops to play, and then walks back home at a constant speed. Which of the following displacement \( (d) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate Sarah's journey?
</Question>
<Answer>![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is another sloped line with a steeper positive gradient.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes displacement continues to increase even when returning to starting point</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this sequence. ![3 consecutive patterns of a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a green triangle inside a square shape that is made from 4 separate red sticks. The second term is Pattern 1 but with 1 more green triangle and 3 more red sticks so that the 2 triangles are enclosed by squares made from red sticks. The third term is Pattern 2 but with 1 more green triangle and 3 more red sticks so that the 3 triangles are enclosed by squares made from red sticks.]() Tom says the number of triangles in the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term will be
double the number of triangles in the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term.

Katie says the number of sticks in the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term will be
double the number of sticks in the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term.

Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is a multiplicative relationship between values of terms in a linear sequence e.g. 10th term is double 5th term</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify vertical reflections in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=4 x+2\)
to the graph of
\(y=-4 x-2\)
</Question>
<Answer>Reflection in the line
\[
y=x
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes y=-f(x) is a reflection in y=x</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify vertical reflections in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=2x+3\)
to the graph of
\(y=-2x-3\)
</Question>
<Answer>Reflection in the line
\[
y=-x
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes y=-f(x) is a reflection in y=-x</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify vertical reflections in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=2x+5\)
to the graph of
\(y=-2x-5\)
</Question>
<Answer>Reflection in the
\[
y \text {-axis }
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes y=-f(x) is a reflection in the y-axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths involve algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Missing Lengths</Subject>
<Question>
What length replaces the \( \color{green}\bigstar \) ? ![A diagram showing a compound shape. It is an L shape rotated 90 degrees clockwise. The top full width is 4x+2, the partial width to the right is 2x+2. The left full height is 6, the partial height on the right is 4. There is a green star on the left partial width at the bottom of the diagram.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths involve algebraic expressions</Construct>

The full height is 8, the partial height at the bottom is 3. There is a green star on the right partial width at the bottom of the diagram.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
![A bar chart with blue bars. The x-axis is labelled with fruits and the y-axis is titled "Number of Children" and its scale is from 0 to 60 in steps of 10. The bars represent the following numbers of children: Banana, 20; Apple, 40; Kiwi Fruits, 50; Orange, 30; Pineapple, 25.]() Which of the following statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>Banana is the most popular fruit</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the smallest bar in a bar chart is the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise if two linear expressions are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing whether simultaneous equations are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted, or whether they need transforming first. Tom says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 x-3 y=10 \\
5 x+3 y=18
\end{array}
\) Katie says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 x-3 y=10 \\
2 x+y=4
\end{array}
\) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, believes the terms must be of opposite signs in order to be eliminated.</Misconception>

```xml
<Construct>Recognise if two linear expressions are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing whether simultaneous equations are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted, or whether they need transforming first. Tom says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 x-3 y=10 \\
5 x+3 y=18
\end{array}
\) Katie says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 x-3 y=10 \\
2 x+y=4
\end{array}
\) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, believes the terms must have the same sign in order to be eliminated.</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate non linear real life graph</Construct>

<Question>
\( p \) increases slowly at first, then quickly, then slowly again
Which of the following sketches best shows this?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with time on the horizontal axis and p on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin and curves right and upwards very steeply, then begins to level off slightly, then travels more steeply again.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a less steep gradient corresponds to a faster speed</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (x-13) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{2}{7} \)</Answer>
