<Construct>Recognise and name an identity</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Emma and Alex are discussing identities
Emma says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 3 x+2 \underset{\star}{2} 2+3 x \) Alex says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 3 x-2 \underset{\star} 2-3 x \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Emma</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word identity</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name an identity</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing identities.
Tom says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 3x + 2 \underset{\star}{2} 2 + 3x \)
Katie says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 3x - 2 \underset{\star} 2 - 3x \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative sign when thinking about the value of a term</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Recognise and name an identity</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing identities
Tom says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 3 x+4 \underset{\star}{2} 4+3 x \) Katie says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 3 x-4 \underset{\star} 4-3 x \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise addition is commutative</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving quadrilaterals</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing what coordinates would complete a square.
Tom says \( (2,4) \) and \( (6,4) \)
Katie says \( (4,2) \) and \( (4,6) \)
Who is correct? ![A pair of axes with no labels, 1st quadrant only. 2 points are marked with red dots and are labelled with co-ordinates: (2, 2) and (6, 2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of a square must be horizontal and vertical, not diagonal</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving quadrilaterals</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing what coordinates would complete a square.
Tom says \( (2,7) \) and \( (6,7) \)
Katie says \( (4,5) \) and \( (4,1) \)
Who is correct? ![A pair of axes with no labels, 1st quadrant only. 2 points are marked with red dots and are labelled with co-ordinates: (2, 3) and (6, 3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find the length of a line segment from coordinates</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(-4<3x-2<8\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(-2<x<4\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtracting a positive number from a negative number makes the answer less negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(-5<3x+2<11\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2<x<3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(-4<3x-2<8\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12<x<24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2(3 x+5)-4(x-2) \equiv A x+B
\)

What is the value of \( A \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the numerical terms when expanding a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract integers with more than 4 digits using a written method where carrying is not needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Emma wins \( £ 65850 \) on the lottery and gives \( £ 35350 \) to charity.
How much money does Emma keep?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 101200 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract integers with more than 4 digits using a written method where carrying is not needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Emma wins \( £ 45670 \) in a contest and donates \( £ 15340 \) to a local school.
How much money does Emma keep?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 61010 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{4} \times 4=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{16} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies both numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{8} \times 8=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{64} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies the denominator instead of the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{8} \times 8=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks converting an integer to a fraction means both the numerator and denominator are equal</Misconception>

<Question>
Which of the following would not be representative of this data?
\[
2,4,6,8,10,12,14,16,200
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Median</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes extreme values can affect the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the limitations of the mean</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would not be representative of this data?
\[
4,5,7,8,8,9,10,11,250
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Mode</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes extreme values can affect the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the limitations of the mean</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would not be representative of this data?
\[
3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10,100
\]
</Question>
<Answer>All are representative</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is always representative</Misconception>

\(
85,321 \quad \square \quad 523,180
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( > \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

\(
8,432 \quad \square \quad 567,341
\)
</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>

\)

<Construct>Understand key loci terms like equidistant and perpendicular</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
![A set of axes: x-axis from -4 to 4, y-axis from -4 to 4. A red line is drawn from (-2,2) to (2,2).]() The red line is _________ to the y axis.
</Question>
<Answer>Opposite</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a line segment can be opposite an axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand key loci terms like equidistant and perpendicular</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
![A set of axes: x-axis from -4 to 4, y-axis from -4 to 4. A blue line is drawn from (3,-3) to (3,3).]() The blue line is _________ to the x axis.
</Question>
<Answer>Equidistant</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the ratio of \( a \) to \( b \) ? ![A rectangle. The width is marked '10cm'. The height is split into two parts, one part is called 'a', the other is marked 'b'. A diagonal line goes across the rectangle from where the height is split into two parts. It is marked '4cm'. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the ratio of \( x \) to \( y \) ? ![A rectangle. The length is marked '20cm' and the width is split into two parts, one part is called 'x', the other is marked 'y'. A second line goes across the rectangle from where the width is split into two parts. It is marked '4cm'. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the ratio of \( a \) to \( b \) ? ![A rectangle. The length is marked '20cm' and the width is marked '10cm'. The width is split into two parts, one part is called 'a', the other is marked 'b'. A line goes across the rectangle from where the width is split into two parts. It is marked '4cm'. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve this equation, giving all solutions:
\(
4 x^{2}+16=64
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\[
x=4
\]
or
\[
x=-4
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the inverse of square rooting is halving</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>

\(
2 x^{2}+8=32
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\[
x=3
\]
or
\[
x=-3
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation</Misconception>

\(
2 x^{2}+5=25
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\[
x=5
\]
or
\[
x=-5
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( m=n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores numerical terms when setting up an equation from a question</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct way of writing: \( x \) divided by \( y \), then subtract \( 2 \) using algebraic convention?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x y-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks two letters next to each other is a division</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct way of writing: \( x \) multiplied by \( y \), then subtract \( 2 \) using algebraic convention?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \cdot (y - 2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not account for grammar when writing algebra e.g. ,then making a group</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct way of writing: \( x \) divided by \( y \), then add \( 5 \) using algebraic convention?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x-y+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used a subtraction sign to represent division</Misconception>

<Construct>Sort and class quadrilaterals into hierarchical families</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Emily and Jake are arguing about rhombuses. Emily says this shape is a rhombus ![A four sided shape. All sides are equal, opposite angles are equal. There are no right angles.]() Jake says this shape is a rhombus ![A four sided shape. All sides are equal, all angles are right angles.]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emily</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know a square is a type of rhombus</Misconception>

<Construct>Sort and class quadrilaterals into hierarchical families</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>

Tom and Katie are arguing about parallelograms. Tom says this shape is a parallelogram ![A four sided shape. All sides are equal, opposite angles are equal. There are no right angles.]() Katie says this shape is a parallelogram ![A four sided shape. Opposite sides are equal, all angles are right angles.]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know a rhombus is a type of parallelogram</Misconception>

<Construct>Sort and class quadrilaterals into hierarchical families</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing quadrilaterals. Alex says this shape is a rhombus ![A four sided shape. All sides are equal, opposite angles are equal. There are no right angles.]() Jamie says this shape is a rhombus ![A four sided shape. All sides are equal, all angles are right angles.]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not believe a shape can have two correct names e.g. square and rhombus</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Tom completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\[
q^{2}-12 q+3 \equiv(q-6)^{2}  \Delta
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \Delta=+36 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b = a^2 + the original constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Alex completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\[
q^{2} + 12q - 4 \equiv (q + 6)^{2}  \Delta
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \Delta = 32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 180° about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
![A pair of axes: x-axis is from -2 to 4; y-axis is from -2 to 4. A 6-sided polygon, labelled "P", is made by joining the following points, in order, with straight lines: (1, 2), (2, 2), (2, 3), (4, 3), (4, 4), (1, 4) and back to (1, 2).
The point (2, 2) is marked with a red dot.
Also, the following points are plotted and labelled with the following letters: A (-2, -2); B (2, -2); C (-1, -2); D (-2, -1).]() Shape \( \mathrm{P} \) is rotated \( 180^{\circ} \) through the origin.

Where will the red point be on the rotated shape?
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects instead of rotates</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( y=\frac{5}{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets that a number divided by itself is 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( y=\frac{4}{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a fraction with equal numerator and denominator cancels to 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A class of students were surveyed about how many siblings they have.

A selection of results are shown in the table. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  0  & \( 7 \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline 1  & \( \) & \( 144 \degree \) \\
\hline 2  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 3  & \( 4 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 4 or more  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 30  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Jenny wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{30}{360} \times 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that to find an angle for a pie chart sector you divide the total frequency by 360 and multiply by its frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A class of students were surveyed about how many siblings they have.

A selection of results are shown in the table. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  0  & \( 7 \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline 1  & \( \) & \( 144 \degree \) \\
\hline 2  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 3  & \( 4 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 4 or more  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 30  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Jenny wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{30}{7} \times 360 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a fraction means dividing the denominator by the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A class of students were surveyed about their favorite pets.

A selection of results are shown in the table. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Favorite pet & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  Dog  & \( 5 \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline Cat  & \(  \) & \( 90 \degree \) \\
\hline Bird  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline Fish  & \( 3 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline Other  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 20  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Alex wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \times 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you find the angle for a pie chart sector by doing its frequency multiplied by total frequency</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Add surds in the form mva + nvb</Construct>

<Question>
\(

\)

What is the value of \( d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not multiply the number in front of the surd with the square root of the largest square number that has been removed from the surd</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Add surds in the form mva + nvb</Construct>
<Subject>Operations with Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(
3 \sqrt{7}+3 \sqrt{63} \equiv e \sqrt{7}
\)

What is the value of \( e \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not square root the largest square number that goes into the number under the surd before putting it in front of the surd</Misconception>

```

\)

What is the value of \( d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding or subtracting surds, does not simplify the surd before adding the numbers in front of the surd</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
John and Emily are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{4 x+2}{2}=5\)

John says a correct next line of working could be: \( 4 x+2=10 \)

Emily says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{4 x}{2}=3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Emily</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{5x-1}{3}=2\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5x-1=6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5x}{3}=3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jake and Emma are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{4 x + 2}{2} = 5\)

Jake says a correct next line of working could be: \( 4 x + 2 = 10 \)

Emma says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{4 x}{2} = 3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the concept of inverse operations in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![The triangle numbers represented using purple circles with the first term having 4 purple circles. The second and third terms are also shown.]() How many circles will the next term in this sequence have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![The triangle numbers represented using purple circles with the first term having 5 purple circles. The second and third terms are also shown.]() How many circles will the next term in this sequence have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 35^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes angles around a point sum to 180</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 110^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles and angles around a point</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles around a point</Construct>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
Which element(s) is/are in \( Q^{\prime} \) ? ![A diagram showing a Venn diagram of 2 circles. The left circle is for Set P and contains cat in its left part, horse in the intersection. The right circle is for set Q and contains goat in its right part, horse in the intersection. Outside of the circles it says toad.]()
</Question>
<Answer>goat</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand set notation for complement (eg. A')</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
Which element(s) is/are in \( Q^{\prime} \) ? ![A diagram showing a Venn diagram of 2 circles. The left cicle is for Set P and contains cat in its left part, horse in the intersection. The right circle is for set Q and contains goat in its right part, horse in the intersection. Outside of the circles it says toad.]()
</Question>
<Answer>cat, horse, & toad</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the complement of a set includes any elements which are also in another set.</Misconception>

<Construct>Order integers with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these options show the numbers
\[
7,234,568 \quad 7,234,658 \quad 7,234,685 \quad 7,234,856
\]
in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}7,234,856 \\ 7,234,685 \\ 7,234,658 \\ 7,234,568\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a triangular-based prism when the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Amy wants to calculate the volume of this shape.

Which face should she work out the area of to help her? ![The diagram shows a right angled triangular prism with arrows pointing to one of the right angled triangle faces and the three rectangular faces.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![A points to 'the slope' which is the largest rectangular face coming off the longest side of the right angled triangle]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Think cross section of a prism is the biggest face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a triangular-based prism when the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Amy wants to calculate the volume of this shape.

Which face should she work out the area of to help her? ![The diagram shows a right angled triangular prism with arrows pointing to one of the right angled triangle faces and the three rectangular faces.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![C points to 'the top' which is one of the rectangular faces]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cross section of a prism can be any face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a triangular-based prism when the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Amy wants to calculate the volume of this shape.

Which face should she work out the area of to help her? ![The diagram shows a right angled triangular prism with arrows pointing to one of the right angled triangle faces and the three rectangular faces.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![D points to 'the side' which is one of the rectangular faces perpendicular to the base triangle]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cross section of a prism can be any face</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
A bus arrives every \( 15 \) minutes
A train arrives every \( 20 \) minutes
They both arrive at exactly the same time
After how many minutes will they next arrive at the same time?
To solve this problem you need to work out the  \( _____ \) of \( 15 \) and \( 20 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Highest Common Factor</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses factors and multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
A red light blinks every \( 9 \) seconds
A blue light blinks every \( 6 \) seconds
They both blink at exactly the same time
After how many seconds will they next blink at the same time?
To solve this problem you need to work out the  \( _____ \) of \( 9 \) and \( 6 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Product</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds a common multiple but not the lowest common multiple</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
A hot tap drips every \( 15 \) seconds
A cold tap drips every \( 10 \) seconds
They both drip at exactly the same time
After how many seconds will they next drip at the same time?
To solve this problem you need to work out the  \( _____ \) of \( 15 \) and \( 10 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Sum</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding two numbers finds their lowest common multiple</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to two decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{1 2 . 5 6 7 8} \) rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12.56 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to two decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{1 2 . 3 4 5 6} \) rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12.45 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 23.79 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values</Misconception>

<Construct>Assign probabilities to single events using percentages</Construct>

Give your answer as a percentage ![A six-sided die labelled with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16.67 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes all possible outcomes must have equal probability</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.5 \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10g in a kilogram</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 500 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise \( x^{2}+14x+40 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+5)(x+8) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise \( x^{2}+18x+80 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+10)(x+8) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise \( x^{2}+18 x+72 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+12)(x+6) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the distance travelled, complete missing values on a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
Work out the speed \( v \) if the distance travelled is \( 75 \) miles. ![A speed-time graph. The vertical axis is labelled Speed (mph) and has no scale marked except for the letter v four squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (seconds) and the scale is 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in even steps.
The graph consists of two sloped lines. The first is from (0,0) to (2, v) and the second is from (2, v) to (4, 0).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 150 \mathrm{mph} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes speed is distance multiplied by time</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the distance travelled, complete missing values on a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
Work out the speed \( v \) if the distance travelled is \( 75 \) miles. ![A speed-time graph. The vertical axis is labelled Speed (mph) and has no scale marked except for the letter v four squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (seconds) and the scale is 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in even steps.
The graph consists of two sloped lines. The first is from (0,0) to (2, v) and the second is from (2, v) to (4, 0).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18.75 \mathrm{mph} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the shape of the graph does not affect the area calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jodie was \( y \) years old on her birthday \( 3 \) years ago.
Her father was \( 43 \) years old. This year Jodie is half her father's age.
Which answer does not correctly represent this scenario?
</Question>
<Answer>![A bar model showing a bar for Jodie's age as \( y + 3 \) which is half the width of her father's bar.  Her father's bar is shown as \( 2 \times (y + 3) \), where the first \( y + 3 \) plus \( y \) total to 43.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jodie was \( y \) years old on her birthday \( 3 \) years ago.
Her father was \( 43 \) years old. This year Jodie is half her father's age.
Which answer does not correctly represent this scenario?
</Question>
<Answer>![A bar model showing a bar for Jodie's age as \( y + 3 \) which is half the width of her father's bar. Her father's bar is shown as 46 in total, split into 2 lots of 23.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
In which of the following inequalities could \( \boldsymbol{d}=\mathbf{5} \) ? \begin{tabular}{ll}
Inequality \( 1 \) & Inequality 2 \\
\( 3 d<16 \) & \( 16<d-3 \)
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Only Inequality \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Round decimals to the nearest whole number</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
John measures the length and width of his rectangular garden as \( 7.2 \mathrm{~m} \) and \( 14.6 \mathrm{~m} \).
Which calculation will give the best estimate of the area?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \times 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

Which calculation will give the best estimate of the area?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round decimals to the nearest whole number</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>

Which calculation will give the best estimate of the area?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \times 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up rather than to one significant figure</Misconception>

```
<Question>

If the train leaves London at 11:50, what time does it arrive in Bristol?
</Question>
<Answer>15:10</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes times in the afternoon as if they are morning on a 24 hour clock</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve problems involving adding a period of time on to a given start time</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>

If the train leaves London at 9:30, what time does it arrive in Birmingham?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12: 120 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

\hline
\end{tabular}

]() What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>

```
<Construct>Subtract decimals from integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
How should you line up the digits to calculate \( 7-0.612 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A column subtraction written as 7 - 0.612 The 7 is above the 6, the decimal point in 7 is above the 1 and the 2 is ignored.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Lines up the digits incorrectly when doing a subtraction involving two numbers with a different amount of digits</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of B? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-5" below the 1st dash and "4" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "B" is pointing halfway between the 3rd and 4th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Student thinks that negative decimals behave the same as positive decimals when positioning a decimal between two consecutive negative integers, placing the decimal with a greater absolute value to the right.</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of B? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-5" below the 1st dash and "4" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "B" is pointing halfway between the 6th and 7th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -7.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When placing a negative number on a number line student assumes numbers with a greater absolute value are placed to the right.</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of B? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-6" below the 2nd dash and "3" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "B" is pointing halfway between the 5th and 6th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
The \( 1^{\text {st }} \) term in a linear sequence is \( 5 \). The \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term of the sequence is \( 23 \). What is the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term of the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 46 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is a multiplicative relationship between values of terms in a linear sequence e.g. 10th term is double 5th term</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 63 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you multiply the constant difference by the term number to get the term value</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>

<Question>
![An image of 5 boxes, each box representing a number in a sequence. The first box contains a star, the second is empty, the third contains the number 488 and the fourth and fifth boxes are also empty.]() A descending linear sequence has a constant difference of \( 17 \) and the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term is \( 488 \).
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 471 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Write a missing term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
![An image of 5 boxes, each box representing a number in a sequence. The first box contains a star, the second is empty, the third contains the number 488 and the fourth and fifth boxes are also empty.]() A descending linear sequence has a constant difference of \( 17 \) and the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term is \( 488 \).
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 454 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you subtract rather than add when finding the previous term in a descending linear sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of a descending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
If the first term of a sequence is \( 50 \) and the term-to-term rule is \( -3 \), what is the \( 8^{\text {th }} \) term in this sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 47 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence just gives the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of a descending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
If the first term of a sequence is \( 50 \) and the term-to-term rule is \( -3 \), what is the \( 8^{\text {th }} \) term in this sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of a descending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
If the first term of a sequence is \( 50 \) and the term-to-term rule is \( -3 \), what is the \( 15^{\text {th }} \) term in this sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies how much repeated use of the term-to-term rule changes a number but does not apply to the sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve positive quadratic inequalities by balancing e.g x² ≤ a</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct solution to the inequality?
\(
x^{2}<49
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{-14<x<14\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve positive quadratic inequalities by balancing e.g x² ≤ a</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct solution to the inequality?
\(
x^{2}<16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x<4\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think a square root can be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve positive quadratic inequalities by balancing e.g x² ≤ a</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct solution to the inequality?
\(
x^{2}<49
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x<-7\} \cup\{x>7\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.8 \div 0.2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing decimals with the same number of decimal places as each other, assumes the answer also has the same number of decimal places</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.8 \div 0.4 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a chord</Construct>
<Subject>Parts of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
What is the correct name for the line marked on the circle? ![\( \theta \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>Diameter</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses chord and radius</Misconception>

```

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>Tangent</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses tangent and chord</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Identify a chord</Construct>

<Question>
What is the correct name for the line segment marked on the circle? ![\( \theta \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>Diameter</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses diameter and chord</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
8 x + 4 y = 24
\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\(
n-2 \geq \frac{n}{2}
\)

If \( n \) can represent any number, is the statement above...
</Question>
<Answer>always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Carry out division problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>

\(
n-2 \geq \frac{n}{2}
\)

</Question>
<Answer>never true</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>
```

```
<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which inequality is represented by the shaded region? ![A graph of a quadratic equation. There are dashed vertical lines through the roots of the quadratic. The shaded region is between these vertical lines. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+x-5 < 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a dashed line marking a region means the line is included</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which inequality is represented by the shaded region? ![A graph of a quadratic equation. There are dashed vertical lines through the roots of the quadratic. The shaded region is between these vertical lines. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-2x-3<0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1</Construct>
<Subject>Enlargement</Subject>
<Question>
Shape A has been enlarged to get shape B. What is the scale factor of the enlargement? ![Square A is three squares across and three squares up. Square B is nine squares across and nine squares up.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides length of original by length of image rather finding length of image divided by length of original to find an enlargement scale factor.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1</Construct>
<Subject>Enlargement</Subject>
<Question>
Shape A has been enlarged to get shape B. What is the scale factor of the enlargement? ![Square A is three squares across and three squares up. Square B is nine squares across and nine squares up.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides length of original by length of image rather finding length of image divided by length of original to find an enlargement scale factor.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate points that lie on the equation of a circle in the form x² + y² = r²</Construct>
<Subject>Equation of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following points lies on the circle with equation:
\(
x^{2}+y^{2}=10
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-3,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes squaring a negative number just changes the sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate points that lie on the equation of a circle in the form x² + y² = r²</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the following points lies on the circle with equation:
\(
x^{2}+y^{2}=16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Use area to write algebraic expressions</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the following formulae gives the area of this rectangle? ![Rectangle with base 4 and height 3x.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( A=12 x^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks measures of area must end in squared</Misconception>

<Construct>Use area to write algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following formulae gives the area of this rectangle? ![Rectangle with base 4 and height 3y.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( A=4+3y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Use area to write algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following formulae gives the area of this rectangle? ![Rectangle with base 5 and height 3x.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( A=10+15x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Calculates perimeter when asked for area</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Which option is the best estimate for
\[
15,984-2,507 ?
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15,000-2,000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Which option is the best estimate for
\[
34,215-4,789 ?
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35,000-5,000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
This pictogram shows the number of pizzas sold at a restaurant.

Which of the following numbers of pizzas could the restaurant represent with whole symbols? ![A pictogram showing the number of pizzas sold. Margherita has 4 and a half symbols, Pepperoni has 3 symbols, Hawaiian has 1 and a quarter symbols, Vegetarian has 2 and three-quarter symbols, and BBQ Chicken has 1 and a half symbols. Each symbol represents 2 pizzas.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Write the next term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the next term in this sequence?

\[
105, \quad 97, \quad 89, \quad \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the term-to-term rule rather than the next term in a sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Write the next term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the next term in this sequence?

\[
120, \quad 112, \quad 104, \quad \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find the next term in a sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form x(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve this equation, giving all solutions:
\[
m^{2}=6 m
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( m=6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can divide by a variable without checking whether it could equal zero</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Tom says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) about point \( (1,1) \) "

Katie says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) clockwise"

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two pentagons drawn on it labelled P and Q. Pentagon P has the coordinates: (-3,-1) (-3,0) (-2,3) (-1,0) and (-1,-1). Pentagon A has the coordinates: (-1,5) (0,5) (3,4) (0,3) and -1,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you do not need to give the direction when describing a rotation</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Tom says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) about point \( (1,1) \) "

Katie says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) clockwise"

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two pentagons drawn on it labelled P and Q. Pentagon P has the coordinates: (-3,-1) (-3,0) (-2,3) (-1,0) and (-1,-1). Pentagon Q has the coordinates: (-1,5) (0,5) (3,4) (0,3) and -1,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to give the centre of rotation</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Tom says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) about point \( (1,1) \) "

Katie says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) clockwise"

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two pentagons drawn on it labelled P and Q. Pentagon P has the coordinates: (-3,-1) (-3,0) (-2,3) (-1,0) and (-1,-1). Pentagon A has the coordinates: (-1,5) (0,5) (3,4) (0,3) and -1,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you do not need to give the direction when describing a rotation</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 42 \times 50 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 40 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 50 \) &   & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a multiple of 10, just multiplies the non-zero digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 42 \times 15 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 40 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 10 \) &   & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline \( 5 \) &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 200 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying by a multiple of 10, gives an answer 10 times bigger than it should be</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 42 \times 18 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 40 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 10 \) &   & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline \( 8 \) &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies when using grid method</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{4}{7} \div 2
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{3.5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides the denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{8}{12} \div 4
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{24} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>when dividing a fraction by an integer, both multiplies the denominator and divides the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{8}{10} \div 4
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{2.5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides both the numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the functionality of other non-numeric buttons on a calculator</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Calculator Use</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would allow you to type \( \frac{5}{9} \) on your calculator? ![A scientific calculator]()
</Question>
<Answer>![The number 5, then a calculator button labelled \( x^{-1} \), then the number 9]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the reciprocal button writes a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the functionality of other non-numeric buttons on a calculator</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Calculator Use</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would allow you to type \( \frac{5}{9} \) on your calculator? ![A scientific calculator]()
</Question>
<Answer>![The number 5, then a calculator button labelled \(\cdot\), then the number 9]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the decimal point button writes a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the functionality of other non-numeric buttons on a calculator</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Calculator Use</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would allow you to type \( \frac{5}{9} \) on your calculator? ![A scientific calculator]()
</Question>
<Answer>![The number 5, then a calculator button labelled \(-\), then the number 9]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the subtraction button writes a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
(2 n+3)(n-3) \equiv \bigstar \ n^{2} \triangle \  n \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(
\triangle=+0
\)
(no \( \mathrm{n} \) term)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can ignore the coefficient when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
(4 n+3)(n-3) \equiv \bigstar \ n^{2} \triangle \  n \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=+9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
(4 n+3)(n-3) \equiv \bigstar \ n^{2} \triangle \  n \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=-9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks signs are interchangeable when adding or subtracting positive and negative numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{3x + 4}{4x} = 5\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3x}{4x} = 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{4 t+3}{5 t}=6\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 t+3=6 t \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to maintain equivalence in fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{4x+3}{3x}=5\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{3}+x=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct expansion and simplification of the expression below?

\(
(x-5)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-10 x-25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct expansion and simplification of the expression below?

\(
(x+5)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these is not a factor of \( 15 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Fifteen</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think a number can be a factor of itself</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the Lowest Common Multiple of two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
What is the lowest common multiple of \( 4 \) and \( 5 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses factors and multiples</Misconception>

```

<Question>
What is the lowest common multiple of \( 8 \) and \( 9 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 17 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding two numbers finds their lowest common multiple</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
3,3,5,20,-15
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 23 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative sign</Misconception>

\[
5, -3, 8, 1, 12
\]

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
3,3,7,22,-8
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>To find the range adds the biggest and smallest number rather than subtract</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between m and mm</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
A \( 3 \) metre long rope has \( 0.2 \) centimetres chopped off the end.
What is the length of the rope that remains?
Give your answer in millimetres
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2980 \mathrm{~mm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 100mm in a centimetre</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand double brackets with an extra variable outside</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
n(n+3)(n-3) \equiv n^{3} \bigstar \ n^{2} \triangle \ n
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(
\triangle=+0
\)
(no \( n \) term)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Expand double brackets with an extra variable outside</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
n(n+3)(n-3) \equiv n^{3} \bigstar \ n^{2} \triangle \ n
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=+9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Expand double brackets with an extra variable outside</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
n(n+3)(n-3) \equiv n^{3} \bigstar \ n^{2} \triangle \ n
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=+9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying out 2 or more brackets, does not multiply all the combinations of terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the place value of each digit in integers</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the \( 2 \) in this number?
\( 7239 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not equate the value of a number with the place value column it is in</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the place value of each digit in integers</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the \( 6 \) in this number?
\( 26073 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the hundreds and tens place value columns</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the place value of each digit in integers</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the \( 5 \) in this number?
\( 62508 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the hundreds and thousands place value columns</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of both expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
If four apples and three bananas cost \( £ 5.80 \), and two apples and five bananas cost \( £ 6.20 \), what is the cost of an apple and a banana?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Apple }=0.8 \\ \text { Banana }=0.7\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include units in answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of both expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
If three apples and two bananas cost \( £ 2.80 \), and one apple and four bananas cost \( £ 3.00 \), what is the cost of one apple and one banana?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Apple }=£ 0.80, \\ \text { Banana }=£ 0.70\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths involve algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Missing Lengths</Subject>
<Question>
What length replaces the \( \color{green}\bigstar \)? ![A diagram showing a compound shape. It is an L shape rotated 90 degrees clockwise. The top full width is 3x+4, the partial width to the right is 2x. The left full height is 5, the partial height on the right is 2. There is a green star on the left partial width at the bottom of the diagram.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths involve algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Missing Lengths</Subject>
<Question>
What length replaces the \( \color{green}\bigstar \)? ![A diagram showing a T shape. The top full width is 4x+2, the partial width on the left is x. The full height is 3x+1, the partial height at the bottom is x. There is a green star on the right partial width at the bottom of the diagram.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
5(2-3x)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7-15x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
4(2-3x)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2-12x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
4(1-3x)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12x + 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer fraction problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{2}{3}+\frac{1}{3} \times \frac{1}{2}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer fraction problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{3} \times \frac{2}{3}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Sara has \( 20 \) apples. She receives \( 5 \) more apples from her friend.
How many apples does Sara have now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \div 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than adds when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Lily has a rope that is \( 40 \mathrm{~cm} \) long. She adds another piece that is \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) long.
How long is the rope now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40-5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Emma is tracking her savings. She had \( 20 \mathrm{~dollars} \). She saved \( 5 \mathrm{~dollars} \) more.
How much money does Emma have now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \times 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a.. ![An image of a square with shapes attached to each of its sides. To the left hand side are three identical squares all connected, in a row. On the top side is a hexagon. On the right hand side are two squares identical to the central square and the squares on the left. So there is a row of 5 squares along the middle of the image. On the bottom side is an identical hexagon to the top.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Hexagonal based pyramid</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses pyramid with prism</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a pyramid</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a.. ![An image of a square with triangles attached to each of its sides. To the left hand side are two identical triangles connected in a row. On the top side is a triangle. On the right hand side are two triangles identical to the triangles on the left. So there is a row of 3 triangles along the middle of the image. On the bottom side is an identical triangle to the top.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Triangle</Answer>
<Misconception>Names one of the faces of a 3D shape rather than the 3D shape name</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing how to solve:
\(
 \frac{4 x}{3} + 2 = 6
\)

Alex says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{4 x}{3} = 4 \)

Jamie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 4 x + 2 = 18 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jamie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
 \frac{5 x}{3} + 2 = 8
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5 x}{3} = 6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5 x + 2 = 24 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret what the numbers in each region of a double Venn diagram mean</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
All the students in a class were asked if they have a brother, sister, both or none.

The Venn Diagram shows the results. ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Brother and one labelled Sister. The number 11 is written in Brother without the intersection , number 7 is in Sister without the intersection, the number 4 is in the intersection of Brother and Sister. The number 6 is outside the circles.]() How many students are in the class?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the number of regions in a Venn diagram as the total number of entries in the diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret what the numbers in each region of a double Venn diagram mean</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
All the students in a class were asked if they have a cat, dog, both or none.

The Venn Diagram shows the results. ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Cat and one labelled Dog. The number 12 is written in Cat without the intersection, number 8 is in Dog without the intersection, the number 5 is in the intersection of Cat and Dog. The number 7 is outside the circles.]() How many students are in the class?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to include values outside of the Venn diagram when finding the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 2.7+35.9 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this? ![A diagram showing 3 thought bubbles from Dora's head. The first bubble says "I added the whole part first 12 + 4 = 16". The second bubble says "I then added the decimal part 0.3 + 0.5 = 0.8". The third bubble says "I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8. So 12.3 + 4.5 = 16.8".]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}2.7+35=37.7 \\ 37.7+0.9=38.6\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not interpret the correct order of operations from a worded problem</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Tom calculates the answer to \( 8.4+5.9 \) mentally. Tom uses the same method to calculate \( 3.6+27.8 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this? ![A diagram showing 3 thought bubbles from Tom's head. The first bubble says "I added the whole part first 8 + 5 = 13". The second bubble says "I then added the decimal part 0.4 + 0.9 = 1.3". The third bubble says "I then added 13 and 1.3 to get 14.3. So 8.4 + 5.9 = 14.3".]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}3+27=30 \\ 0.6+0.8=1.4 \\ 30+1.4=30.14\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores place value when adding a whole number and a decimal</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
42 \geq 6(2 n+1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( n \geq 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of an inequality can be switched without changing the direction of the sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
30 \geq 5(3n + 2)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{20}{15} \geq n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When expanding brackets, multiplies out the first term correctly but adds together the number outside the bracket with the second term inside the bracket.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>

<Question>
\[
2, 7, 14, 23, 34, \ldots
\]

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the square? nth-term rule:
\(
n^{2}+3 n \) \(\square\)
</Question>
<Answer>\[
+0
\]
(no number term)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>

\[
3,10,21,36,55, \ldots
\]

\(
n^{2}+3 n \) \(\square\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Use perimeter to write algebraic expressions</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( s+s \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify reflex angles</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>Obtuse</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify reflex angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
An angle measures \( 250^{\degree} \). This means it is...
</Question>
<Answer>Acute</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an acute angle is between 0 and 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify reflex angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
An angle measures \( 320^{\degree} \). This means it is...
</Question>
<Answer>A right angle</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that a right angle is 90 degrees</Misconception>

```
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and alternate angles</Misconception>
```

```
<Answer>opposite angles</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and vertically opposite angles</Misconception>
```

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=-4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the y-intercept with the turning point of a curve</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise that a sequence is quadratic when expressed as a pattern</Construct>

Pattern 1 is three small squares on top of one another, so the dimensions of the rectangle are 1 across and 3 up. Pattern 2 is a rectangle of dimensions 2 squares across and 6 up. Pattern 3 is a rectangle of dimensions 3 squares across and 9 squares up.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Linear</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving three or more linear variables</Construct>

like terms
\(4 a + 2 b - 3 c + b - 2 a\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(2 a + b - 3 c\)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, assigns positivity or negativity incorrectly.</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving three or more linear variables</Construct>

like terms
\(4 x + 3 y - 2 z - y + 5 x\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 x + 2 y - 2 z \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, assigns positivity or negativity incorrectly.</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
I increase \( £ 200 \) by \( 50 \% \).
Then, I increase the new amount by \( 20 \% \).
What percentage of the original amount do I have now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 170 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has taken the percentage from the original</Misconception>
