</Question>
<Answer>\( 170 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has taken the percentage from the original</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>

Then, I increase the new amount by \( 20 \% \).
What percentage of the original amount do I have now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 300 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they had to give the new amount rather than the total percentage that the original has been increased by.</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=6 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Describe a reflection in a diagonal line by giving the line of reflection as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>
Which line gives the reflection of shape \( P \) onto shape Q? ![A coordinate grid with two right angled triangles drawn, labelled P and Q. P has the coordinates: (2,5) (2,8) and (4,5). Q has the coordinates: (5,2) (8,2) and (5,4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=x \)</Answer>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 0.05 \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a decimal with one significant figure is a multiple of 10 when converted to a percentage, regardless of place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 0.25 \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.5 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer fraction problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{3} \times\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{2}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes squaring a fraction requires you to double both parts</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Without working out the exact answer, use estimation to decide which of the following answer is the most likely to be correct
\[
498 \div 199
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds every number up when estimating</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Without working out the exact answer, use estimation to decide which of the following answer is the most likely to be correct
\[
498 \div 299
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify perpendicular lines written in any other form</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is perpendicular to y = 3 ?
</Question>
<Answer>\(y=3\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify perpendicular lines written in any other form</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is perpendicular to y = 5 ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=-\frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that in the equation y=a, a is the gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.5 \div 0.7= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.5 \div 0.25= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.5 \times 0.6 = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a speed-time graph for a car.

Which of the following gives the best estimate for the distance travelled between \( 8 \) and \( 10 \) seconds? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and speed in metres per second on the y axis. The curve passes through the points (8,15) and (10,24)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 48 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when finding area under graph you can use the upper y value rather than average of upper and lower</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a speed-time graph for a car.

Which of the following gives the best estimate for the distance travelled between \( 8 \) and \( 10 \) seconds? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and speed in metres per second on the y axis. The curve passes through the points (8,15) and (10,24)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 75 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that area under a speed time graph gives distance because distance = speed x time</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand and simplify:
\(
(3x + 4)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3x + 4)(3x + 4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes expanding a squared expression means writing it as a set of double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand and simplify:
\(
(3x + 4)^2
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9x^2 + 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand and simplify:
\(
(3x + 4)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9x^{2} + 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert integer percentages with 2 digits to decimals</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
How do you write \( 45 \% \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divided by 10 rather than 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert integer percentages with 2 digits to decimals</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
How do you write \( 15 \% \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to just remove the percentage sign to convert from a percentage to a decimal</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert integer percentages with 2 digits to decimals</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
How do you write \( 45 \% \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 45.00 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Square then subtract \( 3 \)]() The first three terms of which sequence below is produced by this term-to-term rule?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2,1,6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes term to term rule is applied to position number, not previous term</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Square then add \( 5 \)]() The first three terms of which sequence below is produced by this term-to-term rule?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1, 9, 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Square then subtract \( 3 \)]() The first three terms of which sequence below is produced by this term-to-term rule?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2,-7,-16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Express a non-linear equation as a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine matches the equation \( y=x^{3}-2 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "𝑥" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "- 2" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "cube" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "y".]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Express a non-linear equation as a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine matches the equation \( y=x^{2}+4 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "𝑥" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "✕ 2" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "+ 4" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "y".]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Express a non-linear equation as a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine matches the equation \( y=x^{2}+4 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "y" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "- 4" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "square root" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "𝑥"]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
This pie chart shows the distribution of a company's sales across different regions.

Which of the following can not be found from this pie chart? ![A pie chart showing multiple sections: North America 35%, Europe 25%, Asia 20%, South America 10%, Africa 10% ]()
</Question>
<Answer>The fraction of sales in each region</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes percentages cannot be converted into fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
This pie chart shows the market share of different smartphone brands.

Which of the following can not be found from this pie chart? ![A pie chart showing multiple sections: Samsung 22%, Apple 15%, Huawei 14%, Xiaomi 10%, Oppo 9%, Others 30% ]()
</Question>
<Answer>The angle of each of the sectors</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you cannot find the angle size in a pie chart when given its percentage value</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
This pie chart shows the market share of different smartphone brands.

Which of the following can not be found from this pie chart? ![A pie chart showing multiple sections: Apple 22.3%, Samsung 20.9%, Xiaomi 14.1%, Oppo 8.6%, Vivo 8.3%, Other 25.8% ]()
</Question>
<Answer>The exact number of smartphones sold by each brand</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to read information off a pie chart</Misconception>

<Construct>Add surds in the form va + vb</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{20}+\sqrt{45} \) Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \sqrt{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, leaves the square root of the biggest square number under the root and puts the other number on the outside</Misconception>

<Construct>Add surds in the form va + vb</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{20}+\sqrt{45} \) Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{65} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding or subtracting surds, just adds or subtracts the numbers under the surd rather than first trying to simplifying to find like surds</Misconception>

<Construct>Add surds in the form va + vb</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{20}+\sqrt{45} \) Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be simplified</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise when a surd can be simplified</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out a reflex angle being measured by the protractor. The outer scale goes from 0 to 360 clockwise. The angle is between one red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale), clockwise to the other red line that is half way between 210 and 220 (outer scale) and halfway between 330 and 320 (inner scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 135^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out a reflex angle being measured by the protractor. The outer scale goes from 0 to 360 clockwise. The angle is between one red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale), clockwise to the other red line that is at 240 (outer scale) and 120 (inner scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 300^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 270° and 360°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out a reflex angle being measured by the protractor. The outer scale goes from 0 to 360 clockwise. The angle is between one red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale), clockwise to the other red line that is halfway between 300 and 310 (outer scale) and halfway between 60 and 70 (inner scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 300^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Correct scale but wrong value on protractor reading.</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 5, y-axis from 0 to 5. A purple triangle symbol is at point (2,1) and a yellow star symbol is at point (1, 4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \) squares down, \( 1 \) square right</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 5, y-axis from 0 to 5. A purple triangle symbol is at point (2,1) and a yellow star symbol is at point (1, 4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \) square down, \( 3 \) squares left</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses left and right</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the circle to the square? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 5, y-axis from 0 to 5. A blue square symbol is at point (3,2) and a red circle symbol is at point (1, 3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \) squares right, \( 4 \) squares down</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 3875 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Determine the function of a single function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Alex and Jamie are discussing this function machine ![A function machine with an input of b+2, the function is not labelled and then an output of 2b+2]() Alex says the function could be \( +b \)
Jamie says the function could be \( \times 2 \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Alex and Jamie</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Translate a shape given vector notation where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Sam has translated the red flag \( \left(\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 3\end{array}\right) \) ![Image showing two identical shapes on a coordinate grid. The red shape has the point (2,1) and the corresponding point on the blue shape is (0,4).]() What error has Sam made?
</Question>
<Answer>Sam has gone left when he should have gone right</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a positive x value in a column vector means to move left rather than right</Misconception>

<Construct>Translate a shape given vector notation where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Emily has translated the green triangle \( \left(\begin{array}{l}3 \\ 2\end{array}\right) \) ![Image showing two identical shapes on a coordinate grid. The green shape has the point (1,2) and the corresponding point on the purple shape is (3,5).]() What error has Emily made?
</Question>
<Answer>Emily has not moved up the correct number of places</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Translate a shape given vector notation where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Alex has translated the green triangle \( \left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 2\end{array}\right) \) ![Image showing two identical shapes on a coordinate grid. The green shape has the point (1,1) and the corresponding point on the blue shape is (3,4).]() What error has Alex made?
</Question>
<Answer>Alex has started counting from his initial position when counting right</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
24 \leq 3(4n - 2)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( n \leq 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of an inequality can be switched without changing the direction of the sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
45 \leq 3(4 n-2)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{47}{12} \leq n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

```
<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x - 9 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is multiplication</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Emma's book. Emma always records what operation she has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x - 5 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \div 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is division</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Emma is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Emma's book. Emma always records what operation she has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 5 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( +5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Mental multiplication and the laws of arithmetic</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
\[
18 \times 15=18 \times(3 \times \text { 年 })
\]
What should replace the star to make this calculation correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( w \) ? ![An isosceles triangle with a base angle labelled with w and the angle vertically opposite the vertex angle labelled with 33 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 78^{\degree} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and equilateral triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( w \) ? ![An isosceles triangle with a base angle labelled with w and the angle vertically opposite the vertex angle labelled with 45 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 46^{\degree} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that vertically opposite angles are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( w \) ? ![An isosceles triangle with a base angle labelled with w and the angle vertically opposite the vertex angle labelled with 45 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 63^{\degree} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that vertically opposite angles are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition or subtraction with multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 6 \) boxes of apples. Four of the boxes hold \( 15 \) apples each. One of the boxes holds \( 20 \) apples. The remaining box holds \( 18 \) apples.
How many apples are there in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 43 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise when to find a multiple from a worded question</Misconception>

<Construct>Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which symbol makes the following statement correct?
\(
\frac{4}{5}\space \square\space \frac{7}{10}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( < \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that fractions with larger denominators are greater in size</Misconception>

\(
\frac{4}{6}\space \square\space \frac{7}{12}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( < \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that fractions with larger denominators are greater in size</Misconception>

<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which symbol makes the following statement correct?
\(
\frac{4}{6}\space \square\space \frac{7}{12}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>

<Question>
What is the size of each interior angle in a regular hexagon?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90^{\degree} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to calculate the sum of interior angles</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the size of each interior angle in a regular hexagon?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 108^{\degree} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to calculate the sum of interior angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of each interior angle in a regular hexagon?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120^{\degree} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand to find each interior angle of a regular polygon you divide the sum by the number of sides</Misconception>

\( 0.4 \times 0.6= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.02 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Convert from kilometers to miles</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3 \) miles \( \approx 5 \mathrm{~km} \) \( 400 \mathrm{~km} \approx \square \) miles
</Question>
<Answer>\( 398 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Added rather than multiplied by a scale factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sam and Alex are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(7-3 x=2-4 x\)

Sam says you can write: \( 3 x=5-4 x \)

Alex says you can write: \( 7+7 x=2 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Alex</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative signs when adding positive and negative numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret what the numbers in each region of a double Venn diagram mean</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
All the students in a class were asked if they have a cat, dog, both or none.

The Venn Diagram shows the results. ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Cat and one labelled Dog. The number 12 is written in Cat without the intersection, number 8 is in Dog without the intersection, the number 6 is in the intersection of Cat and Dog. The number 11 is outside the circles.]() How many students are in the class?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the number of regions in a Venn diagram as the total number of entries in the diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret what the numbers in each region of a double Venn diagram mean</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
All the students in a class were asked if they like dogs, cats, both or neither.

The Venn Diagram shows the results. ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Dogs and one labelled Cats. The number 12 is written in Dogs without the intersection, number 8 is in Cats without the intersection, the number 6 is in the intersection of Dogs and Cats. The number 11 is outside the circles.]() How many students are in the class?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 26 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to include values outside of the Venn diagram when finding the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve missing number mental multiplication questions</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
What number belongs in the box to make the calculation correct?

\[
7 \times \square=147
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 882 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve missing number mental multiplication questions</Construct>

\[
7 \times \square=126
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 119 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does subtraction when division is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom wants to calculate the area of this trapezium using the formula: Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![A trapezium with the parallel sides labelled 8cm and 3cm, the slant height labelled 7cm and the perpendicular height labelled 5cm.]() What is the values of \( h \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the height of a trapezium as the perpendicular length between the parallel sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant height instead of perpendicular height to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Misconception>Finds the difference in a coordinate pair rather than the midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the number of burgers sold in Mike's Diner on Friday and Saturday last week.

Approximately how many Veggie Burgers were sold on Saturday? ![Composite bar chart with four bars, labelled Cheeseburger, Hamburger, Veggie Burger, and Chicken Burger. Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Friday and the upper one showing Saturday's sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Veggie Burgers bar's lower section is 3 ticks high, and the whole bar is 1 tick above 100 on the vertical scale.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 105 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading a composite bar chart, just reads total height of bar</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>

Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Monday and the upper one showing Tuesdays sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Cans bar's lower section is 3 ticks high, and the whole bar is 1 tick above 50 on the vertical scale.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misreads scale</Misconception>

Which of the following sketches best shows Sara's speed over time?
</Question>
<Answer>![This graph shows speed increasing very slowly and then maintaining a consistent level until it starts to gradually decrease until the end of the trip when it reaches 0.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes infinite gradient is not possible in real life.</Misconception>

<Question>
\(
(-30) \times(-4)=3 \times(-10) \times(-4)
\)

</Question>
<Answer>true because of commutativity</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs</Construct>

\(
-3<4x-2<7
\)

```json
{
  "Construct": "Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs",
  "Subject": "Solving Linear Inequalities",
  "Question": "What is the solution to the following inequality? \n\\(-5<2x+1<5\\)",
  "Answer": "\\(-2<x<2\\)",
  "Misconception": "Believes subtracting a positive number from a negative number makes the answer less negative"
}
```

```
<Construct>Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(
-5<2 x+1<5
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3<x<2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation</Misconception>
```

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
In a garden \( \frac{4}{6} \) of the flowers are roses, \( \frac{7}{12} \) of the flowers are tulips, and \( \frac{8}{24} \) are daisies.
Which type of flower is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>Tulips</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when comparing fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
In a garden, \( \frac{2}{5} \) of the flowers are roses, \( \frac{3}{10} \) of the flowers are daisies, and \( \frac{4}{20} \) are tulips.
Which type of flower is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>There is the same amount of each.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when comparing fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the size of obtuse angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the best estimate of the size of this angle? ![An obtuse angle]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 45^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates angle without using knowledge of degrees in quarter turns</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the size of acute angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the best estimate of the size of this angle? ![An acute angle]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates angle without using knowledge of degrees in quarter turns</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the size of acute angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the best estimate of the size of this angle? ![An acute angle]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates angle without using knowledge of degrees in quarter turns</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=\frac{1}{2} x^{2}\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{2}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When substituting a value into a non-linear term with a coefficient, multiplies by the coefficient then calculates the power.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=\frac{1}{3} x^{2}\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{3}{4} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise square numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the smallest even square number?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks numbers are a multiple of their index</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the smallest even cube number?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up odd and even numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the description of an algebraic term with no powers, write the term using algebra</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( x \) multiplied by two lots of \( y \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x y^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of \( 4^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 4</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of \( 4^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of \( 4^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds the index to the number</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\(
a^{3} \times a^{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 a \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\(
n^{3} \times n^{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 n^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses collecting like terms with multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(q-2)(q+4) \equiv q^{2} \triangle q \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=+8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(m+2)(m-4) \equiv m^{2} \triangle m \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the number of students in each year group who study French, Spanish and Chinese.

How many more Year 9s than Year 10s study Spanish? ![An image of a vertical bar chart with bars striped red and white for French, solid blue for Spanish and solid white for Chinese (a key shows this). The x-axis is titled 'year group' with labels for Years 7 to 11. The y-axis is titled 'number of children' and its scale is from 0 to 80 in steps of 10. The following data is shown on the bar chart.
Year 7: French 42, Spanish 35, Chinese 60; Year 8: French 80, Spanish 27, Chinese 25; Year 9: French 35, Spanish 70, Chinese 12; Year 10: French 12, Spanish 35, Chinese 0; Year 11: French 33, Spanish 26, Chinese 0.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 105 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds total instead of difference when asked 'How many more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a triangle using Side-Angle-Side</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
What is the length of the side marked \( p \) ? ![A triangle constructed with a compass and straightedge, with one side labelled with p]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.0 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates a measurement on a diagram rather than working it out</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two points and their midpoint. What should replace the star? ![A set of axis showing all four quadrants. Three points are marked in a straight line with a negative gradient. One lilac circle marks a point in the 1st quadrant and is labelled (-5, 5). One red circle marks a point in the 1st quadrant and is labelled (-2,1). Another lilac circle marks a point in the 4th quadrant and is labelled (gold star icon, green triangle icon) as the coordinates are unknown. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\(\color{gold}\bigstar\) = 5</Answer>
<Misconception>Given a line segment with a midpoint that is not the origin, assumes that the two end points will still have the same absolute value</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two points and their midpoint. What should replace the star? ![A set of axis showing all four quadrants. Three points are marked in a straight line with a positive gradient. One lilac circle marks a point in the 2nd quadrant and is labelled (-3, 4). One red circle marks a point in the 2nd quadrant and is labelled (-1,2). Another lilac circle marks a point in the 3rd quadrant and is labelled (gold star icon, green triangle icon) as the coordinates are unknown. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\(\color{gold}\bigstar\) = -5</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding coordinates of endpoint and midpoint of a line will give the other endpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of non-rectilinear shapes by counting squares, where all squares are either whole or exactly half-squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Each square is \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \)

What is the area of this shape? ![A 4 by 4 centimetre squared grid. A green right angled triangle is drawn on the grid with a base of 4cm and a perpendicular height of 2cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Underestimates the area of shapes when counting squares when some squares are neither wholes nor halves</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of non-rectilinear shapes by counting squares, where all squares are either whole or exactly half-squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Each square is \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \)

What is the area of this shape? ![A 6 by 5 centimetre squared grid. A purple right angled triangle is drawn on the grid with a base of 4cm and a perpendicular height of 4cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of non-rectilinear shapes by counting squares, where all squares are either whole or exactly half-squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Each square is \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \)

What is the area of this shape? ![A 4 by 4 centimetre squared grid. A purple right angled triangle is drawn on the grid with a base of 4cm and a perpendicular height of 4cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a triangle</Misconception>
